item.name: 10 Days in Europe
item.comment: Boring game of drawing tiles to get a sequence of 10 that corresponds to a viable journey on the map. Feels like it was designed to teach geography to kids more than as a serious game.

item.name: 100 Other Games to Play on a Chessboard
item.comment: Odd interesting mix of some extensively developed chess variants and some very short chess modifications, plus various other games, some cool, some less so. Useful and fun if you like thinking of ways to tweak games.

item.name: 2 de Mayo
item.comment:
Unexpected discovery at Essen 2008. Truly beautiful production of a small press game, with bilingual rules and cards (Spanish/English). A simple elegant wargame with simultaneous movement orders (that are not cumbersome due to low number of them being done!) and a bit of randomness from drawing a special card each turn, playable in 20 minutes! Very cool.
[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/352711]My review.[/url]
I created the [[2 de Mayo FAQ]] wiki page.

item.name: 2019: The ARCTIC
item.comment:
Unusual theme in an economic / war hybrid. Longer and more fiddly than I prefer, and some unfortunate art/color choices, but if you like medium/heavy economic games with conflict and ability to manipulate neutral forces (players are mining companies whose lobbyists are used to make countries do stuff), well worth checking out!
I revised the English translation and helped hash out some rules questions with Andrzej.

item.name: 20th Century
item.comment: The auction mechanisms are great and fresh, but some of the tile placement and garbage movement and extra road placement etc are just too annoyingly fiddly for me. (And in practice it seems people easily make mistakes and unintentionally cheat about some of this fiddly stuff.) So I have mixed feelings about this game.

item.name: 3, 2, 1... START!
item.comment: Kids game using arithmetic to drive race cars, but has a bit of interest for adults too as a nice little filler.

item.name: 51st State
item.comment:
It is sort of a quicker version of Le Havre (lots of buildings with specific abilities), plus card drafting, set in the crazy Neuroshima world. :)
I'm not so into games with tons of special cards in play in everybody's tableau which I need to remember and pay attention to.

item.name: 5th Martian Coaster
item.comment: How to rate a 5th Martian Coaster? It's just an accessory. If you need a 5th Martian Coaster, this one does the job perfectly!

item.name: 6 Nimmt!
item.comment: A combination of luck and card tactics and simultaneous decision psychology. Played a fair amount back in Austin, then finally in Poland 2007-10-15. I know it as "6 Nimmt!"

item.name: 7 Wonders
item.comment: Based on a couple plays, it seemed fun.

item.name: 9tka
item.comment:
A curious short abstract strategy game. The first phase (placement) feels arbitrary at first, and the second phase (movement) is more important, but upon further play it seems that the second phase has fairly few significant decisions, and that the first phase is where the important decisions are really made. Because all the pieces must be moved, yet many of the movements are forced (and often won't even change the game result), the second phase sometimes feels like an anticlimactic ceremony to me. But it is so short that perhaps that's not a real problem. A little analogous to the last phase of Fjords in that sense.
It's so short that it works fine as an abstract filler.

item.name: A la carte
item.comment: Silly random game which I guess people only play because of the cute little frying pans etc.

item.name: Abalone
item.comment: Suffers from the problem that rational play seems to dictate cautious defensiveness, so the game can draw out forever. I have read that there are various proposals to mend this, but the game according to its rules that I've played is not very exciting for me, even ignoring that issue. I wanted to like it more than I did. It's playable, but there are so many more enjoyable abstract strategy games.

item.name: Acquire
item.comment:
Classic tile placement and stock ownership game! I used to play often in Austin. I regret it's not as good with 2 players and has a rule hack to make it work.
2008-12-05 finally played in Wrocław.

item.name: Adaman
item.comment:
Nice enjoyable solitaire intro to Decktet. It even has a (slight) theme. Not easy to beat, at least at first!
It is possible to lose on the initial deal, which happened once to me... :)

item.name: Adaptoid
item.comment: I wanted to like it more than I did: the physical implementation is too cumbersome (trying to add new legs and claws to an adaptoid; trying to move an adaptoid without its legs or claws falling out). This distracted us from the gameplay itself.

item.name: Age of Empires III: The Age of Discovery
item.comment: It's hard to rate such a complex game after only 1 play (2007-06-30), but I enjoyed it. It took longer than I'd like, but I imagine it would speed up with experience. Lots of different subsystems and possible strategies. It reminded me of a blend of Puerto Rico and Age of Renaissance.

item.name: Age of Steam
item.comment:
Interesting system. I'm still getting used to it, and keep playing with the different rules of the different boards that Maks (who owns it) keeps bringing, so I've still never played the "standard" version.
2009-07-03: I've now played the standard map a few times, and continuing to enjoy AoS. I got obsessed enough to make the wiki page [[Age of Steam FAQ]] and to download some more maps to try out. The game does not feel elegant to me, and it's not ideal as a 2-player game, and it's a tough one to teach to newbies (because of its brutal "the game hates you" nature, and because it's a bit long for more casual gamers) - nonetheless it's an excellent game that I'm glad I am finally into, and I expect to keep playing. I'm also happy that my SO also enjoys it, despite it being longer than her normal preference.
2010: I've played on a variety of maps now and still like it. I wish the production weren't random though; that's my main gripe with the game.

item.name: Age of Steam Expansion #3: Scandinavia and Korea
item.comment:
Only played Scandinavia once, an unusual map with very few connection possibilities. Enjoyed the game.
Years later played Korea (2014-03-08 at Maks and Asia's, I won) and enjoyed it. The changing demands at cities depending on their current cubes there is a significant change! The stupid/bad map graphics show 3 different types of mountains, but according to some rules thread, they are all "hills" and cost $3.

item.name: Age of Steam Expansion: America / Europe
item.comment: I like that the Europe scenario has no randomness.

item.name: Age of Steam Expansion: Barbados / St. Lucia
item.comment:
St. Lucia is a cool 2-player game! Random setup and then purely deterministic from then on, very tense and interesting. In my first session of it, we played 3 times in a row. (One game ended in a bankruptcy in round 1... :)
The solitaire Barbados is nice but seems to be more for learning the system than for a serious challenge. At least I won it 3 times (final money after rebuying my shares = 19, 49, and 38) after having played other AoS games 6 times. More games = 13, 69, 45, 60.
2009-07-03: having played more maps, including the standard map finally, I'm a little less enchanted with St. Lucia due to its deviations from the standard rules. And as others have said, AoS ultimately seems more interesting multi-player. But still worth checking out.

item.name: Age of Steam Expansion: Germany & France
item.comment:
Annoying that this expansion map is mistakenly too large to fit in the game box.
France is an interesting map to play on since Paris accepts 4 colors, and "difficult" hexes (mountains) can be built on only if you take Engineer.

item.name: Age of Steam Expansion: Jamaica / Puerto Rico
item.comment: 2010-12-11: Played Jamaica twice with Adam, winning both times by going first and urbanizing in corner. Coincidence? I don't know. Need to play more. Very unforgiving map. Both times Adam went bankrupt.

item.name: Age of Steam Expansion: Scotland
item.comment: Seems like in the opening you pretty much have to start in the southwest, as the other cities are scattered fairly far apart. Sufficiently fun that we played 3 games in one day during our first trial of this map. Not sure what more to say without more experience.

item.name: Age of Steam Expansion: Sun / London
item.comment: 2010-02-19: Play London at Instytut (Maks won, I'm very close 2nd, a2na very close 3rd, then Asia and Rafał.) We like it. The instant production is very pleasing. The building cost variant is also interesting, and it makes Engineer more important than usual. Overall a good variant.

item.name: Agricola
item.comment: Kind of an overwhelming number options the first time you play. I was underwhelmed, and I like Caylus a lot more for a worker placement and resource collecting type game.

item.name: Agricola: All Creatures Big and Small
Alfred's Wyke
item.comment: Clever action queue mechanism where you can't repeat the action you or your opponent last played. The 5 actions are all fairly balanced, but one is slightly better (clearly by design) which gives a good incentive to choose it if you can, and a tactical reason to try to force the opponent to not be able to choose it by making a threat to win which requires them to use some other action.

item.name: Alhambra
item.comment: Attractive components. More luck than I'd prefer, and too much inability to plan when playing multiplayer, but it's a sort of enjoyable process collecting the tiles and making the simple decisions on laying them. (But the tile-laying is too much simultaneous solitaire.)

item.name: Alice Chess
item.comment: Mind-boggling chess variant well worth trying out. Chess skill carries over to it, but also many things you know about chess don't apply in Alice Chess. :)

item.name: Alien City
item.comment:
Very cool placement game! Starts off with mysterious open chaos and gradually becomes very tight and calculational and tactical. Well worth trying!
The maze-building mechanism and strategy reminds me a little of Quoridor or Fresh Fish etc, in that you can never make a move that cuts off access.
The opening phase can feel somewhat arbitrary, but at some point things start to snap into place and the game can then become VERY unforgiving of errors! Choosing the right moment to claim a tower is crucial, and a tower could be worth wildly varying amounts depending on what happens.

item.name: Amazons
item.comment:
Studied by combinatorial game theorists. A kind of predecessor of Hey! That's My Fish! except the destroyed space is not where you left, but somewhere you choose in a line from where your pawn ends its movement. Traditionally played on a 10x10 square grid, so the square grid gives different effects from the hex grid of H!TMF!
We played with scavenged bits.

item.name: Amber
item.comment:
Tile placement to connect key map points with roads. Fairly simple elegant little game, simple art.
I was a translator.

item.name: Ambush
item.comment: Seemingly a precursor to Quicksand, which seems a better game, since in Ambush it seems possible for players to turtle and not much happens, but dynamic bloodbaths are also possible. (Based on 2 plays.) I'll be happy to try this again, but Quicksand seems superior to me.

item.name: Anasazi
item.comment:
Won at [[Pionek]] 2009-06-14 for 2nd place in logical games tournament.
It seems the possibility of 2 players competing for the same secret goal color (and thus stealing it back and forth from each other) is a flaw in the rules. The art is hard to distinguish, especially the tiny dark murky base camp colors, and the yellow/white towers/cubes. The expedition bridges tend to fall off each other if you get them stacked oddly. You must be careful not to bump the table as pieces can accidentally slide, and the towers can fall over revealing their secret color. I'm not attracted to continuous space type games (one reason I never got into miniatures) where you can occasionally disagree about whether something reaches/touches something else. Also beware there is a little bit of memory element as well. But taken casually, the game can be fun, despite the flaws.

item.name: Ancient Battles Deluxe
item.comment:
Enjoyable tactical system. I like it enough that I created [[Ancient Battles Deluxe FAQ]].
It has more scenarios than I'll probably ever finish playing (especially with the expansions), but I am soloing my way through them (hoping that eventually I'll get some friend interested in playing them too).
Main downside: the hexes are a bit small, so it can get a little physically fiddly in dense map areas.
Also the counters are old style VPG quality, i.e. they shed weird white paper fuzz from their edges. But after trimming them with my Oregon Laminations counter clipper, I like them. And I still prefer old style VPG counters to the burned black soot of VPG's new laser cut counters, even if VPG's new game counters are thicker. :)
The unusual combat resolution seems to confuse people at first, but it's actually simple once you grok it, and it's clearly described.
ABD is much simpler and quicker to play than GBOH (typically an hour or 2 at most for a scenario), but of course is also less detailed/chromey than GBOH. If a more generic feel bugs you, then ABD might not be for you.
And it's more traditional / wargame-ish than C&C Ancients. So it seems to hit a nice "sweet spot" for me and other ABD fans.
item.wishlistcomment: Simple ancients wargame? Not sure. Alfred likes it. :)

item.name: Ancient Battles Deluxe Expansion Kit 1: Elephants at War
Ancient Battles Deluxe Expansion Kit 2: Hell's Horsemen
Andantino
item.comment: Nice simple abstract strategy/combinatorial game; seems to have noticeable first player advantage though.

item.name: Animalia
item.comment: Cute filler card game. The art is interesting but not so functional, as it's hard to tell some of the weird animals apart, and some of the color pairs look the same in dim light.

item.name: Anteel
item.comment:
Current mediocre rating (5) based on problems of balance. The core system is promising and clever and cool (a pure abstract strategy randomless spaceship combat game in 4 pages!), but as it stands, it doesn't work well as a finished game yet. But it has potential to be a good system.
[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/article/6682413]My review.[/url]

item.name: Antler Island
item.comment: Over-engineered overly detailed rules for the light theme (elks rutting) with cute game bits. We spent twice as long learning the rules as playing a game. The weight of the rules was out of proportion with the strategic interest of the system.

item.name: Apples to Apples
item.comment: This is more of a party/social game experience than an actual game, although ostensibly it is a game with scoring points. It can be mildly amusing in a party pastime kind of way, but I would never choose to play it when I want to play a game. [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/1938722#1938722]ellephai summed it up nicely here.[/url]

item.name: Aquarius
item.comment: A fine light hidden goal game of tile placement with colorful cards. I'm not a fan of the several Looney-style "big unexpected change of game state" special action cards, but the game is short enough that I enjoy it for what it is: something fun and casual (which so far I've played only at Esperanto meetings for some reason!)

item.name: Aquarius Rising
item.comment:
Feels like a work in progress to us:
There seems no clear incentive to actually place the 4th pyramid on a card since it gives the opponent control over what colors will be on the next higher level, and also gives them a chance to gain a bonus card.
So we found lots of started partial structures everywhere instead of the very tall towers shown in the rules. (Maybe we were playing too "seriously" instead of just for the fun of making tall structures? But the game has enough rules and lasts sufficiently long that it seems intended to go beyond mere light filler.)
And the random chaos actions make any attempt to plan ahead feel sort of pointless, as you have no realistic idea what your goal color will be in the end, so no idea what colors to hurt or help.
We tried without the random chaos actions which made it seem more strategic but again the problem of no clear reason to place the 4th pyramid and give the opponent control over the next level seemed too significant.

item.name: Architekton
item.comment: Attractive looking tile placement game, but I didn't like it as much as I hoped I would. Seemed like there wasn't a lot of strategy, and the choices each turn usually seemed fairly forced or obvious.

item.name: Aries
item.comment: Neat simple abstract strategy game of crossing to the other side, with ability to push enemy pieces off the board to remove them.

item.name: Arimaa
item.comment:
I'm not normally into chess-like games, but this one pleased us both. I also like that already there's a strategy guide written for it. Wish more combinatorial games would get that kind of support.
2010-01-06: a2na received it from her Secret Santa! :)
I recommend http://arimaa.com which not only has online play and a ratings system, but useful cool stuff like problems to solve and a bot ladder of increasingly challenging AI players to practice against, some videos with commentary by strong players, forums, etc.

item.name: Arkadia
item.comment: Played a couple of 4 player games 2009-04-26 and enjoyed it. Clever elegant system, not much randomness.

item.name: Arkham Horror
item.comment:
I played the original edition back in the 90s. Then 2008-01-05 I played a 5-player game of this new edition, with some expansions, and it took us almost 6 hours of collecting spell/weapon/skill cards and having wildly random encounters and cooperating to kill monsters and close enough gates.
The long play time was partly caused by 2 players selling their gate trophies instead of keeping them, but still, the game went way too long, and it got repetitive and frustrating.
The old me would have enjoyed that long slog more than the new me. It's a good game if you're into this sort of boardgame roleplaying adventure. It has some neat mechanics, and it's fun seeing the large amount of special cards. But I don't seem to be into this kind of game very much any more. My time is too short.
The components are quite well-done with some beautiful art, and some of the flavor text is nice. (Some of it is silly, e.g. the "Twin Peaks" cherry pie reference in a diner encounter.)
Beware it is VERY text-dependent, if you play with non-native-English speakers.

item.name: Armada
item.comment:
As written, it seems to have the all-too-common "fuzzy wuzzy fallacy" of lots of small fast ships being able to destroy a few big slow ships.
We want to try again with a couple rule tweaks to try to tone down the small/medium power vs larges: 1. Small ships move 3 steps (as you'd expect, instead of 4). 2. Range for ships is their ship size, instead of all ships firing long like big ships do.
Or play with equal forces on both sides.

item.name: Armadöra
item.comment: Very abstract game of enclosing areas and claiming them with your various-valued chips. Played 2- and 3-player, and we enjoyed both. Simple elegant rules; interesting strategy and tactics.
item.wishlistcomment: We played a couple times at a host's house on a trip and liked it. But there are too many higher priority games, so I demoted it.

item.name: Armenian Checkers
item.comment: Holy smokes, the 8-direction flying kings are powerful! Just remember that they only capture in the 4 orthogonal directions, or else they're erroneously even more powerful as in our first (mistaken) game. :)

item.name: Army of Frogs
item.comment:
Clever, and nice pieces. Army of Frogs is to Hive as Tantrix is to Trax, maybe. Simple rules make it nice for newbies and nongamers and kids too. Need to play more to see how much lasting power it will have over me.
Possible problem with endgame dragging in a deadlock of sorts sometimes, which gets broken only if someone makes a silly brainfart mistake and lets someone win.
Also the opening part with random drawing and placing is usually inconclusive and feels a bit ritualistic to get to the second part when all frogs are out and it becomes pure strategy with no chance.
[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/230704]My review.[/url]
item.conditiontext: Signed by John Yianni.

item.name: Asara
item.comment: Nice game which gives a vaguely Shipyard vibe (building long structures with a beginning, variable number of middles, and end) but much more streamlined and elegant and easy to grok rules. I like it more, therefore.

item.name: Astra Titanus
item.comment:
2012-01-16: Thanks, Secret Santa! :)
Fun solitaire sf wargame. It has a nice retro sf feel like Steve Jackson's Ogre (an obvious inspiration), but with Saberhagen-style berserkers in space instead of Laumer-style bolos on land.
The rules are fairly short and simple but unfortunately have some unclear places and errors; be sure to download the FAQ ( http://boardgamegeek.com/filepage/63672/faq-for-astra-titanusunofficial )
As a solitaire game it starts to feel repetitive in terms of strategy and tactics, but I still took about 30 plays before completing all 8 scenarios successfully, so I certainly got a lot of play out of it! I expect I'll still bring it out occasionally.

item.name: At the Gates of Loyang
item.comment:
Like Agricola and La Havre, it's a fiddly production engine type game, but shorter and easier to grok than La Havre and more interesting/appealing (IMHO) than Agricola. It's got a kind of addictive "I can do it more efficiently next time" appeal: we played it 3 times in one day (2-player) after borrowing it from friends. Cute wooden veggies. But perhaps too much luck of the draw...?
2010-12-26: I've realized I'm not so into these kinds of fiddly games with tons of different cards with unique effects all in play at the same time. Complexity from a complex system with lots of stuff is less interesting to me than complexity from a simple elegant system that has deep consequences.

item.name: Aton
item.comment: I played 5 times on the day I learned this game from Łukasz and Browarion. Quick and addictive. I like that there are various victory paths. The luck of the tile draws is a little annoying, but at least there's the one-time mulligan to get rid of a terrible draw. I want to play more.

item.name: Avalam
item.comment: Similar to Focus/Domination, which I'm terrible at.

item.name: Avverso
item.comment: Sort of Hex with GIPF movement. Oddly on a rectangle-shaped hex grid instead of a hex-hex. Such a small board makes it over pretty quick.

item.name: Axiom
item.comment: Played and bought at Essen 2008. Clever strange rules that really make use of the 3-dimensional nature of the game, and the 2008 version of the game has a weird organic sci-fi look to it.

item.name: Ayu
item.comment:
Quite cool fun game which has a bit of a Quoridor vibe (but your blocking walls can [i]shift[/i] to some extent, with interesting restrictions on how).
The interestingly restricted movement rule (you can't split groups and you must make the moving unit be a space closer to one of its closest neighbors) works out interestingly well.
And somewhat unexpected "win if you can't move" rule (instead of simply "win if you unite all your stones into one group") means that you must be careful not to isolate your opponent's remaining groups into separate disconnected regions, even though temporarily isolating them can be useful. That's cool.

item.name: Babel
item.comment:
We liked the nice tactile feel of the (new edition?) blocks at Essen 2012 and the building of the tower.
The game play felt opaque until the endgame. Like certain other games (e.g. Synapse-Ice), it seems like opening moves have no clear meaning/effect, and only near the end you become able to read ahead, and can clearly see "Aha, Player X will win!" I enjoyed it as a quick filler.

item.name: Backgammon
item.comment:
Easy rules, a dose of randomness, you can play quick and casual (as we tend to do), or put more thought into it and read existing strategy literature of this enjoyable classic game.
A childhood favorite in my family, and now I'm enjoying it again, since the evening I first met Anna at an Esperanto event in Helsinki in 2005 and she proposed playing Backgammon during a late night conversation.
2015-02-16: I realized that we enjoy playing this quite often, already 220 logged plays. So I increased my rating from 7 to 8.
item.conditiontext: Why do manufacturers of magnetic sets never seem to take care to align all the pieces' magnets in the same direction?

item.name: Bananagrams
item.comment:
Light realtime word game.
Birthday gift from my mom in 2011.

item.name: BANG!
item.comment:
A lot of details and special cases for what feels like it should be a more streamlined fast game. The gimmick of not knowing other peoples' roles didn't seem sufficiently interesting to me, and seems to cause people to shoot at others randomly, whether that will be good or bad for them. For shooting other people, I'd rather play the elegant fun game Cash and Guns.
Played Czech edition in Polish 2007-05-29.

item.name: The Barbarossa Campaign
item.comment: Quite well done solitaire wargame! Medium complexity with surprisingly few rules holes for such a game. The game really creates a dramatic feel, with the Germans starting out strong and making progress, then gradually bogging down as the USSR forces build up and push them back. I have won handily, lost ignominously, and finished in between. Good replay value for a long (several hours) solitaire game!

item.name: Basilica
item.comment:
Enjoyable 2-player tile-laying territory type game with some territories able to overlap due to 2-color tiles. Various euro-ish special actions.
I revised the English translation.

item.name: The Battle for Hill 218
item.comment:
2010-05-14: Received in [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/53295/item/1245082#item1245082]geekgold auction[/url] from Skadar. Thanks!
Enjoyable short game - reminds me somehow of Neuroshima Hex (random draw, then placement with deterministic combat), but much simpler rules.
It definitely has good replay value. Lots of good interesting gameplay in a small package and simple elegant rules!

item.name: Battle for Moscow (second edition)
item.comment:
Excellent intro-level wargame (and I've taught it to inexperienced wargamers who had fun playing it).
Perfectly clear elegant rules, less than an hour to play.

item.name: Battle Sheep
item.comment:
Quite clever game which feels a little like Hey That's My Fish, Amazons, Fjords, and the like, where you're essentially trying to cut off more territory than the opponent... but it's got a really interesting twist that you also have to commit a certain number of disks to different spaces, with each move, so you could end up with a big space all your own but not enough disks to fill it up, thus costing yourself.
The rules are dead-simple, and the strategy is cool and non-obvious. It plays quickly. Well worth trying out.
item.wishlistcomment: Very cool game; playable with scavenged bits, and we ultimately didn't buy it at Essen. But I think its box is compact and its disks were pleasing and stack well...

item.name: Battlestar Galactica
item.comment:
Not my type of game: (1) I'm not so into cooperative/team games. (2) There's no real planning, just reacting to a long series of random events that lasted way too long in the slow group I played with. (3) Lots of discussion about who might be a Cylon, acting/roleplay to look innocent and cast suspicion on others, voting/debating about other issues, etc which is hard for me in Polish...
But I was glad to try it to see what it's like, as it's quite popular and clearly has some clever ideas. The card play system is a good elegant variation of the failure cards from Kill Dr. Lucky, and it works well. The basic mechanics are simple and ultimately not so interesting - the point of the game is the suspicion and negotiation and paranoia and discussion. I would probably enjoy it a lot more if (1) I played in English or Esperanto instead of Polish and (2) all players were faster and more focused. My first game lasted roughly 5 hours, and that's just too long for this.
To enjoy the core experience (secret traitors thwarting the shared goal), I recommend the much shorter card game [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/9220/saboteur]Saboteur[/url] - it's small, easy to teach, and lasts a half hour instead many hours.

item.name: Bausack
item.comment:
Stack irregular pieces until your sculpture collapses: that makes it a silly party game like Jenga or something. (Plus it requires a VERY stable table, and suffers from the problem all such games have, of what if your tower falls down but it's not really your fault?)
Auction mechanism for bidding on useful pieces or paying to avoid difficult useless pieces: that makes it a Eurogame wannabe.
So it's a strange hybrid that was amusing once just to see what it was like, but I feel no compulsion to play it again.

item.name: Belote
item.comment: I'm probably not in the target audience. I am not a fan of partner-based trick-taking games, nor of weird traditional games which gratuitously reorder the value of the printed card values for no clear reason other than to confuse me... Also odd that the cards weren't fully shuffled between rounds but just stacked and redealt; no idea if that is normal or just one of the diverse variants.

item.name: Beowulf: Gra Planszowa
item.comment:
It's Auf Heller und Pfennig / Kingdoms with additional chrome and a few rules tweaks. We like the original game, and this chromed-up version seems nice, and the new special actions are interesting, though they may introduce too much chaos.
But the beautifully lush rich art is sort of overwhelming; we liked the simple elegant clear art of the original Auf Heller und Pfennig the best. The plastic figures are hard to read/distinguish until you get used to them; the little scoring diamonds are hard to see. I shouldn't have to think about painting them to make them clearer... It's a triumph of beauty over usefulness, which detracts from enjoyment of playing the game.
The Beowulf theme is a bit nonsensical since your unique powerful Beowulf piece goes away after using it once (even though thematically Beowulf should participate in all 3 parts) while the weakest pieces remain forever, so that's odd, but whatever.
item.conditiontext: Won Polish edition "Beowulf: Gra Planszowa" at Pionek, June 2008, thanks to winning Neuroshima Hex tournament.

item.name: Bharg
item.comment: A nice straightforward Decktet game, suitable for beginners to Decktet but also still a fun diversion for those familiar with the cards.

item.name: Biblios
item.comment: Enjoyable set collection card game with paper-thin (ha!) theme. I like the 2 phases: first cards are given out, then the cards not already given to players are auctioned in the second half of the game. The gameplay experience can be quite different depending on whether you get a lot of gold or a lot of non-gold in the first half (as we found in our first 2 games).

item.name: Blam!
item.comment: Very nice simple rules. Starts slow, then the board situation gets more and more complex as the game progresses. A cool little tactical combinatorial game!

item.name: Blefuj
item.comment:
Played Czech edition "Blafuj" 2007-05-29. Clever weird bluffing system leads to lots of fun laughs as well as interesting bluffing tactics. Very cool art of 8 kinds of bugs, with each card unique.
[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/294102]My review.[/url]
item.conditiontext: Won Polish version "Blefuj" at Pionek, June 2008, for second place in logical games tournament. Then impulsively gave it away to a couchsurfing host. :)

item.name: Blokus
item.comment: A longtime abstract pure strategy favorite of trying to fit all your pieces onto a grid while hindering your opponents. Its simple rules make it great for introducing to newbies. My only complaint is that I only like it with 4. For 2 players, I much prefer Travel Blokus.
item.conditiontext: I won a Polish version at a Blokus tournament during Pionek in Gliwice 2007-12-08.

item.name: Blokus Duo
item.comment:
Excellent 2-player pure strategy. I much prefer this specifically 2-player Blokus to the "each player takes 2 colors" 2-player version of regular Blokus.
[url=https://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/180916/act-random-kindness-winners]Thanks, clandaith![/url]
item.conditiontext: I own it thanks to an [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/1607670#1607670]Act of Random Kindness[/url]!

item.name: Blokus Trigon
item.comment: Played at Essen 2006. I think I like the original square grid more, but this was a cool change of pace.

item.name: Blox
item.comment: Played and enjoyed at Essen. Neat abstract game (with randomness) of building and tearing down towers for points. Rules had 1 or 2 unclear points that frustrated us (maybe just a translation issue?) but we think we grokked the intent.

item.name: The Blue Lion
item.comment:
We were kind of disappointed when we tried it out at Essen 2011: 1. The basic scoring mechanism seems OK but didn't thrill us. 2. The memory aspect was a turnoff for us. 3. The "beer coaster" type pieces seem like they'd be at risk of getting distinguishable marks, which breaks the intended memory aspect.
For this kind of "memory game with flipping tiles" I guess we'll stick with Logan Stones, which we already own and which has much sturdier bakelite tiles instead of beer coasters.

item.name: Boche
item.comment: Only played online; I suspect I'd enjoy it more with real cubes in a 3-D stack. But still an interesting fine game in the vein of Palago (a similar but 2-D tile game which I do own and play a lot more).

item.name: Boggle
item.comment:
A classic real-time word game, I like it OK perhaps partly due to nostalgia, as I used to play it a lot with my mom and even wrote a computer program to play it as a birthday gift for her once. :)
After playing it in Polish, I'm amazed by how many Polish words I still don't even passively recognize or know.

item.name: Bohnanza
item.comment: Not being able to rearrange your hand is a practical problem, since people are so used to sorting their hands in other card games that they easily forget not to in Bohnanza.

item.name: Bonaparte at Marengo
item.comment: The deterministic system and gorgeous components are cool, although the map is a little hard to read at first. Need to play more to assess it more; unclear how much replay value it will have for me.
item.conditiontext: When I [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/204766]read that it's officially sold out[/url], I ordered the last copy which histogame.de had, and received it 2007-09-14.

item.name: Bootleggers
item.comment:
Played once, 6 players, to my surprise I came in 2nd (124 points, only 4 points behind winner with 128).
A fine change of pace, but not my preferred type of game:
Too long for the heavy randomness.
Cute components help create atmosphere, that's good, but it's really stupid that all 3 types of black plastic truck look identical except for different barely visible numerals on their cab roofs. And a hassle that they all only hold 4 cubes comfortably. Stacking 9 in the "large" truck is a balancing pain in the ass. And it's awkward having to put one of your dudes on the truck (where it falls off) or next to the truck to remember whose is whose.
Heavy negotiation, not my preferred style. (Alas, especially since moving to Poland where I don't understand the language well.)

item.name: Boxes
item.comment: Classic abstract strategy game, and very interesting from a mathematical Combinatorial Game Theory point of view. Of course I play with paper and pencil, and not a silly plastic set.

item.name: Branches and Twigs and Thorns
item.comment:
Kind of a clever Blokus/Go hybrid as you try to place all your pieces touching your own pieces and have to pay if you touch someone else's. Very nice elegant system, and scales from 2 to 6 players. 2-player seems very unforgiving of mistakes - sometimes only one payment takes place. Multiplayer is more chaotic of course but interesting since then you sometimes have decisions about who to pay. Also nice that the initial setup of the blocks and roots can really influence the way the game unfolds. I also like playing it at http://superdupergames.org.
[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/525271/a-good-combinatorial-pyramid-placement-game]My review.[/url]
There seems to be a potential 2-player problem with first-player advantage, but I won't swear to it yet; quite possibly we'll discover more, who knows. Even if true, I still enjoy playing it a lot!

item.name: Breakthrough
item.comment: Abstract strategy game; simple rules, cross one of your pawns to the other side.

item.name: Brouhaha
item.comment: Silly noisy chaos; hunters too lucky.

item.name: Ca$h 'n Gun$
item.comment: Clever basic idea, spoof of Reservoir Dogs and such crime films. I played an early simpler version long ago. It's rather chromed up now. Silly fun, not too long.

item.name: Caledea: The Epic Strategy Game
item.comment: Neat elegant wargame. The map is cool looking but unfortunately difficult to read the many terrain types, most of which are drawn in black. :( On the plus side, a2na enjoyed it. The dice combat resolution is quite clever and elegant, and I don't recall seeing it in another game.

item.name: Callisto: The Game
item.comment:
So far, I've only played online vs AI at Marquand.net. The choice of when/where to play the 3rd pillar can be interesting. Callisto's a nice little placement game, and comparisons to Blokus seem inevitable.
I find Blokus to be more aesthetically pleasing (e.g. that Blokus has exactly 1 of each possible type of piece, where Callisto has an odd empirically determined distribution of pieces). And Blokus seems deeper.
2011-10-28: Played live finally, at Essen with Anna. The plastic set is kind of unpleasing. I like the gameplay still, but she wasn't thrilled by it.
2012-01-28: I won a copy as 2nd place prize in Callisto tournament in Brzeg, woot! :)

item.name: Caminos
item.comment: Looks and plays a bit similar to Kögl's earlier Rumis, but it's a cool connection game instead! Nice wooden blocks (with a different distribution than Rumis). Sadly for me, Anna seems to like it less than I do.

item.name: Can't Stop
item.comment: A classic random-but-fun filler game my old group used to play a lot. Finally played it again in Poland during Pionek 2009-06-13!

item.name: Cannon
item.comment:
Good abstract strategy game. Sort of Chess-like (kill the stationary enemy town on the back row) with a single type of moving piece, but 3-in-a-row of them form a "cannon" which can shoot targets 2 or 3 squares away, and also move as a unit (giving you effectively 3 moves in 1 turn).
It is also realistically possible to win even if you are behind on material (which is a satisfying win!) - position and maneuver are very important!
I mostly play online at Super Duper Games.

item.name: Caravaneers
item.comment: I like the unusual rules (very simple, neutral pieces which one player moves east and the other moves south). I totally don't grok the strategy though. In practice I don't enjoy it as much as I hoped I would from the clever elegant idea, at least so far...

item.name: Carcassonne
item.comment: A modern classic. I like tile-laying map-building games like this. Of the Carcassonne series, The Discovery is my favorite, but I also love this original one (even if has more luck) and have fond nostalgia for it.
item.conditiontext: I have a Czech/Polish/Slovakian edition.

item.name: Carcassonne - Hostince a katedrály
item.comment: The Inns and Cathedrals add a bit more variablity/luck to the game, but are fun. The megameeples add some nice tactical options.
item.conditiontext: 2008-03-09: a2na and I won the Czech/Polish edition "Hostince a katedrály" at Pionek 6 (thanks to coming in 3rd place in the trivia quiz game).

item.name: Carcassonne - Kupci a stavitelé
item.comment: After a couple plays, it seems fun with this extra chrome, though a big city can cause even more big score swings due to the resource points (our second game ended with a score difference of 103 points!)
item.conditiontext: 2008-03-09: a2na and I won the Czech/Polish edition "Kupci a stavitelé" at Pionek 6 (thanks to coming in 3rd place in the trivia quiz game).

item.name: Carcassonne: Hunters and Gatherers
item.comment: Nice variation, although I like the elegance of original Carcassonne. And the art on some H&G tiles is a little unclear.

item.name: Carcassonne: The Discovery
item.comment: A very nice Carcassonne variant. Being able to place a meeple or pull a meeple to score it, but not both, leads to some interesting tough choices. The game is more forgiving and arguably less luck-based than the other Carcassonnes because of this: there's no "majority takes all" in the scoring, and there's no "my meeple is trapped the whole game in a worthless unfinishable city". The new scoring systems for seas and mountains are interesting.

item.name: Carrom
item.comment: As flicky dexterity games go, it's OK. Nice to play on a good quality board.

item.name: Cartagena
item.comment:
A longtime sentimental favorite.
Very easy to teach simple rules; nice looking components; fun for newbies; interesting for experienced gamers also; works fine with all advertised numbers of players.
2011-03: received in Polish math trade (for Covert Action), hura! :)

item.name: Castellan
item.comment:
Interesting game with simple elegant rules and some nice strategic/tactical discoveries to make. Short enough that we want to play "just one more".
The bits lock together in a way we found occasionally annoyingly fiddly (both locking together during play and then unlocking the completed castle structure into individual pieces at the end to clean up). And the plastic feels a little "cheap" and light. But we still enjoyed it. Main complaint is the luck of the draw, but I guess the game is targeted at a filler / lighter / family type audience instead of more hard-core abstract fans. I imagine it will indeed have good "toy value" for fans of Lego and stuff like that.

item.name: Catan
item.comment:
Played this zillions of times with the first and second Mayfair editions in 1990s, then gradually burned out a bit. 2007-02-27 played Polish version "Osadnicy z Catanu". The trading aspect was challenging for me in Polish. :/
2008-08-23 played a 2nd time in Polish. Again, the trading aspect was frustrating in a language I don't understand well. :/

item.name: Catan: Seafarers
item.comment: Complicating chrome for Catan... not bad, but I prefer basic Settlers of Catan.

item.name: Cathedral
item.comment: Blokus mixed with Go Lite.
item.conditiontext: In February 2007 I made my own set from cardboard and acrylic paint. Much lighter and more portable than the wooden version!

item.name: The Cave
item.comment:
It seems much more of an "adventure/experience" game with lots of randomness, compared to K2, which was more strategic and interactive. I suppose it is inevitable that an exploration-themed game, discovering an unknown region, will necessarily have a higher luck factor, for better or worse.
Tons of bits with good-looking art - we even requisitioned one of my GMT counter trays to help organize the various counters. But it would have been good to have victory points more clearly indicated on all the bits and/or on the player mats.
I'm also not fond of the fiddly rules relating to the camp.
It is fun to play with the atmospheric custom music soundtrack! Download here: http://www.rebelgames.eu/x.php/7,381/The-Cave-soundtrack.html

item.name: The Cave: Additional Cave Tiles
item.comment: Adds a few hybrid tiles (e.g. squeeze with water, water with camera, etc) to the mix for a bit more variety.

item.name: Cavum
item.comment:
Played and bought at Essen 2008. Almost pure strategy (there is randomness of 5 cards being dealt out in each of the 3 game rounds). Beautiful components. Interesting game play that has been rewarding replay with various aha-insights.
My only complaint is the stupid huge box that's twice as big as it needs to be. I'm sick of anti-environmental price-increasing over-sized boxes that waste my valuable shelf space and are hard to take to game club to show the game to other interested players. Lucky for Cavum I liked it as much as I did, or I'd have not bought it because of that damn giant box.
[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/2767080]My review.[/url]

item.name: Caylus
item.comment:
Finally played (2008-10-13) after wanting to for a long time. No luck, no hidden information, but unlike a typical more elegant abstract [[combinatorial game]] Caylus has lots of chaotic interacting subsystems, so it's like Shadow of the Emperor in that regard.
Very cool game! The only drawbacks seem to be: 1. Hard to grok all the rules at first. But after both reading the rules and talking about them, we dove in and just learned as we went. 2. Takes longer than we'd like. (Our first game, with 2 players, took 2 hours.)

item.name: Cephalopod
item.comment:
Clever elegant combinatorial game with strange patterns of flow and change creating nonobvious strategy and tactics, but ultimately the clever idea doesn't translate into a lot of interesting fun. I enjoyed it for a few games, but then it slid off my radar.
Lasts longer than one would expect from a placement game on a small grid, due to the frequent captures, but still not [i]too[/i] long on 3x3.
It would be too pointlessly slow and repetitive for me on a larger grid than 3x3.
Trivially easy to make: you just need dice of 2 colors and a square grid (3x3, 3x5, whatever).

item.name: Cesarski Kurier
item.comment:
Played a couple times at Essen 2006. I like the various fiddly subsystems fine, but it felt like there wasn't enough real interaction and direct confrontation between players.
2011-04-11: Played again finally and we enjoyed it more than the first time. (I'd been wanting to try it again for a while based on occasionally reading about it.)
2011-04-28: a2na impulse purchases it in Bard. :)

item.name: Chaos Arena
item.comment: Very nice components, especially for such a self-published limited edition type game. A generic "2 wizards dueling" theme, which I enjoy, but the game itself had way too much chaos for my taste, although it doesn't take too long to play, which is nice. I had fun, but wanted to like it more than I did. For tactical fantasy combat, I think a game like Dungeon Twister is more up my alley.

item.name: Chase
item.comment: So far only played online at superdupergames; I think I'd enjoy it more live, since worrying about all the notation in the user interface is annoying.

item.name: Che
item.comment:
Another neat little abstract strategy game of tile placement to complete a closed area of your color, a bit like Palago, but with different details.
If a publisher would publish it with nice clacky tiles, I would buy it.

item.name: Checkers
item.comment:
Another classic abstract strategy game which I think people belittle due to childhood memories and a misconception that it has no depth. Still, it's not as interesting as Go. :)
International Checkers (10x10 with more movement) seems more interesting.

item.name: Cheops
item.comment:
Early German style game, nifty bits, fun nostalgia for me as I played it back in 1999 and finally reacquired it in 2013. :)
In the end game, you can read ahead pretty clearly to optimize; earlier on, depend on longer range strategy and opportunistic grabbing.
The variable set up of a subset of the price tables and law tiles each game reminds me of Donald X's Kingdom Builder and Dominion...
Note the rules error in the common English translation on the web: you [i]don't[/i] choose your new tile from a stack, you only take it from the front stack (conceptually it's a single very tall stack).

item.name: Chess
item.comment:
Have never played seriously. It never grabbed me like Go.
2011-04-30: a2na and I decided to play chess every day during April, and it was quite a nice experience. I enjoy and appreciate the game more.

item.name: Chicago Express
item.comment:
2010-01-20: Been wanting to try this for a long time. It's cool, and has no chance or hidden information, hurrah! Like Caylus meets Age of Steam, or something, but faster. :) I want to play more.
Adam and I tried it 2-player, and the system breaks. Maybe it still works as a game, but you totally lose the whole emergent alliance stuff of some people owning shares in a company versus others who don't. I think it's not suitable for 2.

item.name: Chinese Checkers
item.comment: Yet another nice abstract strategy game that seems frequently dissed due to being a childhood classic.

item.name: Chocoly
item.comment: A tile laying game that wants to be strategic, but I don't like the random drawing aspect. Having 3 colors of chocolate instead of 2 seemed to make the luck factor increase, compared to its sibling game Scho K. O.

item.name: Circus Flohcati
item.comment: Nice quick filler card game.

item.name: Citadels
item.comment: Played the Polish edition Cytadela, after hearing about the game for years. It's clever, but is chaotic and too luck-based for my taste. In the second game with 6 players, I lost 4 out of 8 turns and of course came in solidly last with no hope even for 5th place. Not a lot of fun being a spectator for half the game.

item.name: Clans
item.comment:
Almost pure strategy of merging adjacent groups of pieces, except for not knowing which player is which color. Not sure I like that one bit of hidden info in an otherwise pure strategy game. The other drawback is annoying tedious setup. But in practice I like the game, and you seem to figure out what color the other players are fairly soon anyway.
I don't get to play this as much as I'd like, so I am still not very good at it, but I like it a lot.

item.name: The Climbers
item.comment:
Neat simple 3D game of no chance, with interesting strategy. We enjoyed it and played several times the weekend we learned it (at [[Pionek]]). Big heavy solid cubes.
But the inability to easily see all the faces of the blocks, which is important, is a practical disadvantage for a pure strategy game.
It also seems the random setup can significantly favor or disfavor certain players.
We were taught sort of hastily at the con. The rules are fairly simple and easy to explain, but there seem to be some differences between the German rules we saw there and the English rules I found later online. Apparently the German rules had various ambiguities or holes, and the English rules cleaned them up, I gather. (E.g. do you move your pawn before moving a block? When everyone passes, does the next player get a final turn or not?) This is a drawback, having a game with different rule versions floating around.

item.name: Cockroach Salad
item.comment:
Not a game in the normal sense because the rules are ridiculously simple. You just play the top card from your deck and say what it is, except for certain conditions in which you must say it's something else. And so if you play it late night after a day of boardgaming and everyone is sleepy and silly, it's easy to make mistakes in this theoretically simple task, to the amusement of all. Especially when you're all trying to play it with the Czech names for the vegetables and bugs.
[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/295351]My review.[/url]

item.name: Coda
item.comment:
Sort of like reverse "What's that on my head?" (but simpler and less interestingly analytical).
I played the older version "Coda" in Bangalore in May 2008. Later I saw the rebranded "Da Vinci Code" version in Poland.

item.name: Code 777
item.comment: Code deduction type game. Maybe we were all incompetent, but it seemed it took too much time and effort to solve a code, and often people made mistakes... I think I prefer "Hey what's that on my head?" for this kind of thing. (Or that old standby Mastermind... or LAP!)

item.name: Coerceo
item.comment: [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/717009/]My review.[/url]

item.name: Coin Age
item.comment:
Simple short coin game with clever use of randomness and a tiny map.
(For a pure no-map coin game which has no randomness, I recommend [gameid=2284])

item.name: Coin Clusters
item.comment:
Clever little almost-combinatorial game that uses continuous space instead of a discrete grid. Playable with whatever random coins you have in your pocket! Very nice tactical filler!
It only takes a few minutes, so a good game to play anywhere when you've not brought a "real" game with you but have a little time to kill.
Continuous space in a game can theoretically lead to ambiguous situations and disagreements, but that doesn't seem to be an issue in this game.

item.name: Coloretto
item.comment: Coloretto reminds me a bit of Lost Cities, collecting cards in various suits. 3 of your colors will count positively, and any additional colors collected will count negatively. A nice short filler. First played 2007-09-25, and my first game to learn with the rules explained completely in Polish, with no English or Esperanto translation help. :)

item.name: Colorpop
item.comment: It's a somewhat physically fiddly physical implementation of little computer games like Bejeweled or whatever, where you "pop" out connected stones of the same color and the rest fall down, and columns slide left to fill emptied columns. Players have secret goal colors they want to minimize at the end. OK for what it is, but I'm not so interested in playing a physical version of the computer game.

item.name: Colosseum
item.comment: Big (physically). Various fiddly subsystems, but not too complex. Trading negotiation is very important, more than I would prefer. Since you only have five rounds, each decision is very important, and that was hard to fully grok the first time. Lasted rather longer than I'd like. Not sure how much I like it; would need to play more than once to have a more certain rating. First played 2007-10-12.

item.name: Combat Commander: Europe
item.comment:
Great fun WW2 tactical game, playable usually in a couple hours, unusually clear well-written rules, great support in the forum by knowledgable players and occasionally Chad Jensen the designer.
It comes with 12 fine scenarios, but I have particularly high praise for the [b]random scenario generator[/b]. (And I wish more tactical games had good RSGs, or RSGs at all, for that matter. CC has spoiled me and raised my expectations in multiple ways!) I sometimes get the impression I'm the only CC player active in the forum who does not instantly auto-buy every CC expansion! I'm sure the expansions are great, but be aware that if you're not a completionist, or if you're just trying to save money or shelf space, then the random scenario generator [i]really does[/i] create an endless supply of great scenarios, so one doesn't [i]need[/i] to keep buying expansions to enjoy playing CC again and again!
[i]Comparisons with other WW2 tactical games:[/i] Before CC I was playing Conflict of Heroes with a friend who owned it, and we both found we preferred CC. (But I am rather curious to try CoH again when its true solitaire module finally comes out, and CC's card-based core makes it notably less solo-friendly than non-card-based games for me, though I've tried solo CC a couple times.)
I've solo played some Panzer Grenadier, which is an interesting system, but notably slower and fiddlier than CC, so I doubt I'll ever convince a friend to play it with me, and I prefer CC.
I've recently started playing Band of Brothers, which has more simple elegant rules, but lacks the random event flavor and detail of CC, and like most tactical games, alas, lacks any kind of random scenario generator.

item.name: Combat Commander: Mediterranean
item.comment:
Apparently originally CC Europe and CC Mediterranean were intended as a single package, but split apart for practical/marketing reasons.
CCE is quite playable & replayable alone, but most CC players seem to buy CCM as well: more maps, more nationalities, more scenarios, somewhat different/improved random scenario generator!
In any case, an excellent fun WW2 tactical system with unusually carefully well-written rules. Great stuff, well worth trying.

item.name: Conflict of Heroes: Awakening the Bear! – Russia 1941-42
item.comment:
Cool, it satisfies my Squad Leader nostalgia, albeit with a very different (but similar scale) system. Very interactive interleaved actions. Nice components too! (But board warp seems to be an annoying minor problem.)
I started a [[Conflict of Heroes FAQ]] wiki page.
I've since tried Combat Commander and find that CC grabs me more. Although CoH is still good, CC seems to create a better sense of drama and story to me, and has more scenarios and a random scenario generator unlike CoH.
item.wishlistcomment: I feel on the fence about CoH. Combat Commander seems better, more fun, more replayable thanks to random scenario generator. Still, CoH seemed interesting when I played a few times and there's the Polish expansion...

item.name: Confusion: Espionage and Deception in the Cold War
item.comment:
Hard to categorize combination of abstract strategy game, bluffing game, deduction game...
It's essentially a chess-like game where you don't know what your pieces can do, so you ask your opponent if your proposed move is legal, and you take notes using a well-designed dry marker board. Figuring out what your pieces can do is interesting. It makes it take longer to play than a similar more conventional open information game would take, but it's still playable in under an hour.
The chunky pieces are very nice to handle.
I wish they had kept this new version abstract (as it originally was) instead of tacking on the "cold war" theme with flashy "spy" graphics and giving it a "big box" treatment, but it's still a nifty game!

item.name: ConHex
item.comment:
Interesting connection game. We played the wooden version several times at Essen 2011 and enjoyed it, but felt it wouldn't have staying power with us.
It's also a bit aesthetically awkward/unattractive that you mark control of the variously shaped regions with rectangular markers, and that the vertex markers are little balls that roll away too easily.

item.name: Connect Four
item.comment:
Like Checkers and Dots & Boxes, this abstract suffers from the "it's just a game for kids" stigma, with many people falsely believing it's somehow trivial like Tic-Tac-Toe, but it's not. E.g. see the ratings of strong players at http://littlegolem.net. It's not just a guaranteed first player win, or guaranteed draw.
That said, even though it's a strategically non-trivial game, it's still not all that exciting to me. :)

item.name: Connect6
item.comment:
Very simple rules: place stones, win by making 6-in-a-row.
Nifty game in terms of the 1, 2, 2, 2, 2, ... move protocol which works well to avoid significant first player advantage common to many similar games; here, after each move, the player who just moved is always ahead by 1 stone. This idea can be applied to other games as variants.

item.name: Conquest
item.comment:
A wargame created by a chess player who didn't know about existing wargames, supposedly. A neat deterministic ancient warfare themed game. I like it.
The only disadvantage is counting your action points up to 20 each turn, and keeping track of which units have already spent how many points.
I played this long ago in college! Got to play it again, enjoyed it, but don't know anyone local who's likely to play it much with me, alas.

item.name: Conquest
item.comment: Played 2-player version decades ago in college, then played 4-player team version at Essen 2008. Nostalgia! I want to like this more than I do: having to count up to 20 action points each turn AND remember how many actions each individual unit has spent, possibly while interleaving their actions, is simply cumbersome! But the bits and map are cool, and I like wargames, and I like combinatorial games, and I like that this game has history, published problems, etc, so I have a soft spot for Conquest. I am sad I don't know anyone interested in playing it.
item.wishlistcomment: Played this long ago with college roommate, then again in Essen/Spiel, which gave me nostalgia. Not sure if I'd get others to play it though. And there are many versions published over the years, so that's confusing. But it's a cool modern classic, and even has a problem book in some versions. Hmm. But Anna doesn't like it (having tried it at 2 different Essens...)

item.name: Container
item.comment: Clever tough weird economic game. We played 3 times in BGG.CON. I wish it worked for 2 players, not just 3-5. But very interesting and good. Auctions, price-setting, your best color doesn't count at the end ... neat tough choices.

item.name: Container: The Second Shipment
item.comment: Played at macike's on 2010-03-06. We like it! However the gold can cause a big effect in the auctions where a shipment is worth a LOT more for one player than the others. Perhaps it's a question of personal taste whether that's a bug or a feature. :) We enjoyed the expansion, and it felt like a reasonably natural extension in the elegant spirit of the original, but it also adds some complexity and doesn't seem necessary.

item.name: Continuo
item.comment: First played with German set during Arkones Esperanto event in Poznań, 2007-09-22. An interesting little optimization pastime, but not that exciting as a game due to no real interaction or planning ahead, just finding a good placement for each tile you draw. It also seemed to last longer than needed for what it was.

item.name: Copolymer
item.comment: Placement game with seemingly clever mechanism, but unfortunately the opening is opaque the play feels very repetitive and unexciting. Also the need to count a large number of claimed spaces makes it not good for manual play without a computer to count score.

item.name: Cosmic Coasters
item.comment:
I nostalgically remember enjoying this years ago in Austin!
It's quite clever and thematic for such a simple game, and having 4 different viable alien powers is nifty. Kind of like a 10-minute version of Cosmic Encounter. :)
Random fun filler. Not a great game, yet I enjoy it. And it's fun that they are real usable coasters.

item.name: CrackeD ICE
item.comment: I'm not in the target audience for this kind of silly dexterity / balancing game. It also lasts longer than I'd like (15 or 20 minutes) - for a "physical" game, I'd much rather just play [gameid=28985] in 1 minute. :)

item.name: Crazy Circus
item.comment:
It's like a very simple version of Ricochet Robots: players try to be the first to find a solution to change the positions of 3 circus animals stacked on 3 pedestals into a goal position. But you must "pronounce" the solution, as the various possible moves are each a one-syllable nonsense word. I liked it more than I expected to. it tests the geek/programmer algorithmic side of your brain and the real-time speed adrenalin part of your brain like Ricochet Robots, but also tests the linguistic part of your brain as you must "pronounce" the solution first.
I played the "Ma Ni Ki" version at [[Pionek]] in September 2008.

item.name: Crokinole
item.comment: I used to play this flicky dexterity game in Austin and never quite got why it's so popular. Played it again finally in Poland on a home-made board at Pionek 6 (2008-03-09), and I still think it's OK as flicky games go, but nothing amazing.

item.name: Crosscontrol
item.comment: Interesting mechanism. Gameplay feels oddly like a smoothed-out version of Go (in the sense that the boundaries between groups literally get smoothed out into straight lines).

item.name: Crossings
item.comment:
This 8x8 predecessor to Epaminondas plays quicker and more tactically. The rules differences (only kill the first piece in a line instead of the whole line; crossed pieces become frozen and can't move or be killed) seem interesting and give a somewhat different feel than Epaminondas.
[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/article/10164168]My review.[/url]

item.name: Crosswalk
item.comment: After 1 play, we were not impressed; too random and drawn out.

item.name: Cthulhu Fluxx
item.comment: Familiar Fluxx mechanisms and gameplay with a few new twists, nicely coupled Cthulhu theme, and cool art.

item.name: Cthulhu Rising
item.comment:
Light tile placement game with luck of the draw. OK on its own, but the misleading marketing that makes it look like a Lovecraftian horror game is very disappointing. The only thing eldritch about this is the flavor art.
[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/2767001]My review.[/url]

item.name: Cubulus
item.comment:
Unusual 3 dimensional game where gravity doesn't matter (unlike in, e.g., Connect Four) and all 6 sides of the cube are of equal significance. Pushing the black and white and red balls through the flexible rubber framework (possibly pushing other balls behind it into the following "cells") is an unusual & wacky physical solution to how to implement such a 3x3x3 game! A little awkward, but it works.
The game itself is fine: try to make a square in your color on any face of the cube. The square could be 2x2, or the 4 corners, or the 4 sides, of the cube face.
(a2na received as gift from her 2011 Secret Santa!)

item.name: Czarne historie
item.comment: Not really a game at all, but a set of (some difficult, some well known from old puzzle books etc) "20 questions" puzzles all involving some crime.

item.name: Dancing Eggs
item.comment: I'm not in the target audience for this kids game. Not anything I'd play normally, but a cute way to kill 5 or 10 minutes with kids.

item.name: Diamonds Club
item.comment: Not sure how to rate it yet. I've played it with 2, 3, and 4 players (in my first 3 games) and enjoyed them all. I worry about the tree strategy being too powerful. Also it's an awfully lot of fiddly setup with the many kinds of pieces, which hurts my rating of it. But quite pretty, and fun to play.

item.name: Dixit
item.comment:
A creative language game that doesn't depend on arbitrary decisions of what's a legal word/sentence/etc. Good! You can actually play it competitively. Cool art.
http://www.transparent.com/esperanto/first_time_abroad_and_at_ijk/ has a photo of people playing Dixit at an Esperanto event in summer of 2011. I have often seen Dixit played at Esperanto events, which is fun, since we share a common language but totally different national cultural backgrounds, so references to old songs and TV shows and such don't play a role as they often seem to when everyone plays in the same national language.

item.name: Dixit Odyssey
item.comment:
Essentially the same as Dixit. Handles more than 6 players (but I've not played it with more than 6.)
Better scoring track. Worse voting widget. Different art.

item.name: Dobble
item.comment: Fast pattern matching reaction time game... a genre I don't usually enjoy but seem to be learning to appreciate. This one is interesting due to the mathematical property of the cards (every pair of cards has exactly 1 symbol in common, which you want to find quickly). And it's amusing that I've played it in English, Esperanto, and Polish, sometimes with different players calling out what they find in different languages. Useful for learning vocabulary...

item.name: Dobble: Darmowa Wersja Demonstracyjna
item.comment: Even faster than regular Dobble! :)

item.name: Dominimum
item.comment:
Domino version of Nestor's earlier card game Mystique Energy. Try to minimize the sizes of groups of your own secret symbols while trying to deduce what secret symbols your opponent wants to minimize.
The port to dominoes is pleasing. They arguably feel nicer than cards, take less table space, and fit together in a grid more easily.

item.name: Dominion
item.comment: Surprisingly cool game! The fun of deck-building without the off-putting collectible nonsense. The central game mechanic is clever and elegant - play an action, buy a new card, discard your remaining hand, and draw 5 new cards. The couple dozen different types of cards that come with the game are all interesting. Play with 10 random sets of them, and every game is truly interestingly different. It really has that "That was cool, let's play again!" quality. (Partly that is due to the cumbersomeness of setting up and putting away, though... as long as it's out, let's play again!)

item.name: Dominion - Poseł
item.comment: Seems potentially rather powerful!

item.name: The Downfall of Pompeii
item.comment:
Seemingly too-long rules for a pretty simple fun eurogame that was enjoyable to play. (And calling your extra people "relatives" was just plain confusing.)
In the first half, players put their dudes into buildings. In the second half, lava starts flowing and dudes flee to escape the city. The lava flow is a clever combination of randomness and player controlled mayhem to cover or surround other players' dudes. Good fun (even if the theme is rather morbid if you think about it), especially when you get to throw someone's dude into the paper cone volcano.

item.name: Dragons
item.comment: Nice simple short card game, this version seems to have reduced the random chaos factor from what it was in Aquarius and has more staid/traditional dragon art instead of hippie Aquarius art.

item.name: Dragons
item.comment: Based on a play 2014-04-09, it seems not quite fully baked. Lower clarity for me and less fun than similar games like Palago and Che, and when camb got a position to win, I then created a long series of obligation moves for him, hoping to draw when the tile ran out, but eventually I ran out of opportunities to oblige him into a forced move instead of his winning placement. Seems to need rule tinkering.

item.name: Drako
item.comment:
Good short 2-player asymmetrical fighting game. Some luck of the draw, but strategy/tactics matter.
We did the English translation.

item.name: Drakon (third edition)
item.comment: The tiles in the earlier editions were more pleasing, alas.

item.name: Drip
item.comment: Pyramid version of Batik etc: drop pieces into a container until someone's piece extends up over the edge and they lose. Not normally my kind of game, but it's very short (like a minute or 2 max), so it's a cute filler. As such, there's no real reason you can't play with more than 2 people.

item.name: Duchy dobre i złe
item.comment:
Fun short light Stratego-like filler, a mix of abstract strategy game and bluffing/luck. Having 3 different victory conditions is good.
The Granna edition has quite nice art and bits, including a hex map variant on the other side of the board.
But the box at least twice as large as it should be, alas.

item.name: Duck Dealer
item.comment:
2011-02-21: Received in [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/63654/item/1553376#item1553376]Jack Vasel auction[/url]
The rules are not terribly long, but somehow hard to absorb, with non-obvious strategic implications. (That's good in principle, but a barrier to entry.)
The one game so far didn't last too long, yet it felt long and tiring.
I'm interested to play again, but none of the 4 others wanted to. :/
The gratuitously weird resources and art are a stumbling block.
I think if I and my regular players were more into heavy thinky economic games, we'd enjoy playing this more.

item.name: Dungeon Twister
item.comment:
Finally played once; didn't live up to my too-high hopes. The very flashy fantasy art and theme (and the randomness of the facedown tiles and their revelation during play) was a turn-off for what is sometimes touted as almost a pure strategy game. But I hesitate to rate it. I still want to like it.
After playing 2 times more at 2009 BGG.CON, I feel like it's a solid 7. The randomness/simultaneous decisions detract from it for me, but I still enjoy it. The graphics are too flashy, occasionally to the point of being unhelpful. But it's neat when you pull off a clever sequence of moves!

item.name: DVONN
item.comment: One of my favorites in the Gipf family, and definitely the most pretty board and pieces.
item.conditiontext: Signed by Kris Burm during Essen 2007.

item.name: EastFront II
item.comment:
Classic block wargame! The rules are longish but mostly clear, although various annoying little details and unclear things exist so it's well worth browsing the FAQ.
Cool that you can play a 6-month scenario in one session, or start in one scenario and continue to some later scenario, even a full campaign from first to last scenarios.

item.name: Eclipse
item.comment: OK chesslike game. After a couple plays, it's not exciting me, though I am open to trying more. Its physical chain gimmick is annoyingly implemented: the 2 players' chains should be different colors to more easily see which chain's on top. Also people seem to always mis-see how far the long chain can go and try to drag it 2 steps away in the direction it won't go.

item.name: Edel, Stein & Reich
item.comment:
Interesting fun clever little game with simultaneous action selection and nifty auctions between players who pick the same action to see who will get to do the action.
The simultaneous decisions add more luck than I normally like in a game. But I had fun with it and hope to play more at future conventions etc.
Nice quality cards and gems.

item.name: Egizia
item.comment:
2010-01-19: Interesting Eurogame in the tradition of all kinds of wacky subsystems and various ways to earn points. The central worker placement mechanism (of going in one direction along the Nile) is good. We were taught by Sawka and Tusia who'd only played it once a while before, so many rules were shaky. Playing in Polish with German cards detracted from my comprehension of various rules... I really would like to read an English translation of the rules. But the game seems cool.
But it has a bit more randomness than I'd like in this kind of game.

item.name: Emira
item.comment: 2008-08-28 played first time in Gumowa Róża. Not sure how much I like it.

item.name: Emu Ranchers
item.comment: Like a shorter version of Lost Cities.

item.name: Ennea
item.comment:
9 modular wooden boards with seemingly arbitrary intersections and curved connections carved into their surfaces. Players have balls and can play a variety of games. We played 2 at Essen; both were familiar mechanisms transported to this unusual board topology: one was a basic Halma / Chinese checkers type game and the other was a placement game of trying to have the largest connected group. Seems a potentially interesting game kit/family.
Somehow the sort of random haphazard looking curve layout was a slight turnoff for us, almost looking like a children's toy... for me a pure abstract strategy game should somehow look more regular/elegant, but that's purely subjective of course and probably unjustified snootiness on my part. :)

item.name: Epaminondas
item.comment: Neat slightly older abstract strategy game. Enjoying it online at SDG.

item.name: Essentia
item.comment:
Cool chess variant. The movement powers coming from the specific location instead of the specific piece is a neat twist which feels amusingly interestingly different.
Physical production annoyance: the pieces often make it difficult to tell the type of tile they are standing on due to unnecessarily large margin printed around the perimeter of the tiles.

item.name: Euclid
item.comment:
Reasonable abstract strategy game of maneuver to capture more of the other guy's pieces before they do the same to you. The capture mechanic is unusual and for some reason took me a while to grok in practice, although the rule is quite simple and elegant.
2011-03: After playing a couple more, it seems like with similar-strength play on both sides, it all comes down to an endgame where one person has perhaps 3 left and the other has 2 left and is being hunted down, possibly drawing the game out until someone makes a stupid mistake?

item.name: Eufrat i Tygrys
item.comment: Used to play this Knizia classic a lot in Austin, then finally played the Polish version "Eufrat i Tygrys" 2007-05-15.
item.wishlistcomment: How good is it 2-player? I'm not sure I ever played it 2-player.

item.name: Exago
item.comment: Played at Essen 2008. Based on a 2-player play, it seems like an OK abstract game to get 4 in a row. I suppose it's much more chaotic with up to 6 players.

item.name: Factory Fun
item.comment:
Pros: unusual idea, building a Rube Goldberg-esque factory with various machines feeding into each other. Geeky design/layout fun. Satisfying when you get a good layout built. Cons: can be cumbersome to rearrange your factory, and sometimes players get confused and forget where things were. Hassle to set up and clean up, due to many fiddly bits. Real time auction grab of machines each round seems a little at odds with the cerebral spirit of the layout phase.
2011-05-16: The game grew on me and I like it more, as I played during various conventions since a2na likes it so much. And the new Z-Man edition has nicer easier to use components (yay!) but (alas) a much larger box.

item.name: Famiglia
item.comment:
Surprisingly nice 2-player card game. Simple rules, very quick setup, plays in under a half hour.
Nifty system with pyramid hierarchy of 4 colors of cards (each color has its own special power) representing types of gangsters with cute individual portraits of each individual gangster (but the theme is pretty irrelevant).

item.name: Fangfrisch
item.comment: OK auction game of collecting fish to sell in sets. The real-time hitting the bell fastest decreases its rating for me and makes it more of a silly game, even though it could be more serious.

item.name: Fealty
item.comment: I like the modular map variety, the art style, and the game play. The purist in me wishes it didn't have the chaos of simultaneous decisions, but that's ok. :)

item.name: Felix: The Cat in the Sack
item.comment: Enjoyable filler card game with cute art and nice auction mechanism with the objects being auction getting progressively revealed as players pull out of the auction, leaving the remaining bidders with more info. But a lot of luck.

item.name: Fendo
item.comment:
I like Fendo, which is a bit in the vein of Amazons, Terra Nova, etc (move your dudes and place walls to seal off territory, in this case on a 7x7 square grid).
Nice clean simple rules. Each turn you can move one of your pieces in a straight line, making one optional turn, and then must place a wall on one of the 4 sides of the square your piece finished on.
It's got a neat core rule forbidding a move which would split the "open area" (containing more than one pawn) into two open areas, which leads to occasional interesting aha-surprises and tricky tactics as a piece. Additionally, instead of moving a piece, you can place a new piece on any square one of your existing pieces could move to. (One player might have no legal move, and so simply passes.)
The game continues until there is no open area (i.e. every piece is locked into its own walled-off area), and the player with more claimed territory wins. Termination with a winner is guaranteed.
You can play it with bits you probably already own or can easily make (e.g. matchsticks for walls), so I recommend trying it if you like abstract strategy games.

item.name: Fighting Formations: Grossdeutschland Motorized Infantry Division
item.comment:
