Superficially similar to Chad Jensen's earlier game Combat Commander - same WW2 theme, same designer, same SPI-style clean functional graphics, and an better cleaner rulebook than Combat Commander. Plus they're both good fun games. :)
But there are significant differences (and not just because FF has tanks). FF is less "cinematic"/chaotic and seemingly more strategic/thinky. The command/activation/order system is fundamentally different from CC, and it is quite clever and cool and interesting.
FF has a few similarities to Conflict of Heroes, e.g. unit facing (for vehicles), randomly drawn damage markers, asset cards.
The only real "negatives" for me so far: * Many scenarios take longer than I'd like * FF's lack of a random scenario generator. It comes with 11 scenarios, and that's what you get.

item.name: Finca
item.comment:
Enjoyable euro, fairly light rules, interesting planning needed, attractive art. Works fine with 2-4 players.
The only random element is the revelation of the tiles to be claimed; sometimes someone gets lucky as a new tile is perfect for the resources they have stockpiled. I'd be curious to try it with visible queues of tiles sometime.

item.name: Finca: El Razul
item.comment: A fine but inessential expansion for Finca. Adds several bits of chrome (with some rules which were unclear as written and sent us to the forum for clarification), but I like the base game perfectly well without the expansion too. The dude who lets you sell any kind of fruit seemed only occasionally relevant in the games we played.

item.name: Fire in the Lake
item.comment:
The Vietnam war in the COIN system (my first entry into the COIN series). It is quite rich and full of historical flavor, 4 factions. The core turn structure with event cards and the choice in player order printed on the card to do the event or do faction-specific operations is quite nifty and pleasing. Good looking components, good physical quality (and great cover art). Very carefully written rules give me the rare pleasing positive vibe of quality which I get reading rules by Chad Jensen (Combat Commander, Fighting Formations). The excellent manual also includes tutorial game walk-throughs, historical/development notes, event card detailed explanations + tactical tips + historical notes, etc. Works solitaire (human vs bots), 2 player (2 factions vs 2 factions), 3 and 4 player, even interesting to solo all 4 sides noncompetitively. Large number of event cards, so that even the longest scenario only uses a subset of them. The variety of options on your turn can be bewilderingly complex with many strategic and tactical factors to consider. COIN author Volko Ruhnke is active in the BGG forum, answering questions and taking suggestions for rule text improvements/clarifications as is coauthor Mark Herman and bot author Örjan Ariander. All this is great.
Downside? The bot/AI player rules add significant time and complexity and is notably more confusing/subtle to grok than the game rules themselves. Each faction has its own set of operations and actions so there is a lot of detail to remember, even though it's almost all well & clearly explained. Game length: your first solo learning "short scenario" game may last 5 or 6 hours. (But fear not, experience makes you faster!)
So far I've played soloing all sides, solitaire (one side vs 3 bots), and 2-player (US/ARVN vs VC/NVA) and enjoyed them all.
If you are willing to make the investment of time and effort, it is quite a pleasing game, plus an interesting take on the Vietnam war as a 4-faction affair.

item.name: Fist of Dragonstones
item.comment:
Very Faidutti-ish, with simultaneous sealed auction bids on randomly revealed cards: lots of chaos and luck. Not a serious game, but I had fun playing it and liked it more than the vaguely similar Citadels, which seemed more prone to screwing a player with bad luck than this game.
We get it in Polish Math Trade #4 (2010-03)

item.name: Fjorde
item.comment: I read the rules online and liked the sound of it. I finally bought it 2007-06-30 and am not disappointed. I like tile-laying games, and I like territory maximization. It's like combining Carcassonne and the endgame of Go!
item.conditiontext: I have the German edition "Fjorde", bought in Warsaw.

item.name: Flowerpower
item.comment: Nice little filler I'd like to try again some time to see if I underestimated it.

item.name: Fluxx
item.comment:
On the one hand it's quite random and chaotic and silly. Not the kind of game I'm normally into!
But on the other hand, it's fun watching the rules change and the various kinds of card interactions that can occur. For a game with so many unique special cards, the rules are pretty well done without many rules issues in practice. I like that.
And as a 2-player game, it's quite enjoyable (more planning is possible than with multiplayer) and generally doesn't last too long! My wife proposed playing it every day for our July 2011 monthly home tournament. :)

item.name: Focus
item.comment:
Played long ago once or twice, and then recently 4-player with 2 teams. I'm not a big fan of team play, so hard to rate. I think I prefer DVONN and Stack Control, maybe only due to familiarity and owning them.
In the 2-player game (played mostly online) I find my terrible playing skill makes me have less fun. :/ But it is a modern classic.

item.name: Folium
item.comment:
Nice little minimalist game of reading ahead to preserve parity. (It's an impartial Nim-esque game, so it boils down to parity.) The lookahead exercise is fun if you enjoy that kind of thing (which I do). :)
The proposed physical implementation (writing X or O on paper slips and picking up the stacks of slips to move them) seems a little inconvenient, we found. In practice, I think it might work better with 3 colors of cubes/disks/whatever, and there's no need at all to stack them: just remove the one you land on.

item.name: Folko-Boks
item.comment:
Abstract, ostensibly about boxing, very quick and tactical.
Free insert in magazine, very thin cardstock, so not easy to pick up pieces.

item.name: Formuła 1
item.comment:
2008-09-08: I won "Formuła 1" at [[Pionek]] 8 (thanks to winning 3rd place in the logical games tournament)!
2009-05-24: Finally played it! It uses basic race mechanisms common to many race games, e.g. turn order each turned determined by who's in the lead. Fun game which rewards tactical planning, but rolling the die when taking a curve too fast introduces a lot of luck (possible effects range from no effect, to minor damage, to wipe out and start next turn from speed 0). Besides that, the game is pure strategy, so such wild randomness on taking curves too fast seems too much to me.

item.name: Foundation
item.comment: We liked it ok, but there are other similar Blokus-like placement games we enjoy more. Anna remarked that you score similar numbers of points every turn, so it seems the scores are likely to be close with little potential for drama.

item.name: Four
item.comment:
Good placement game!
When learning, it can be easy to forget about the restriction that you can't place the color or size which the opponent just placed. It's somehow easier to remember that you can't place adjacent to the same color or size (since you directly see the mistake if you do it). :)

item.name: Friday
item.comment:
Interesting (and challenging to win) deck-building / deck-thinning game. Finish a game in under a half hour: after losing, I feel like trying again.
The rules seem initially a little complex for such a small solo game, and the setup is rather fiddly, but it's worth it.
[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/716751/]My review.[/url]

item.name: Friedrich
item.comment:
Interesting unorthodox system that's not too complex, with a beautiful map, but it's sometimes hard to get 4 people together and finish such a potentially long (but unpredictable length) game, it seems. Arguably too random for such a long game, but this game is so cool that I like it a lot anyway. :)]
I made the [[Friedrich FAQ]] in the wiki.
====
But a complaints about sub-standard markers:
The 110 square markers are very lamely die-cut: They have white side nubs sticking out where they were attached to the sprues, which are very hard to try trimming off, and make the markers look cheap and ugly. :( Most modern game companies know to have the markers attached at their corners, not in the middles of their sides.
(At least the nubs are a bit less obvious & cheap-looking than on my counters from Maria.)
A beautiful game designed with such care deserves better markers than these, which are not congruent with the rest of the game's otherwise excellent physical design.

item.name: Funkenschlag: Der Liefervertrag
item.comment: Fun promo card which seems quite powerful (maybe too powerful?): for the rest of the game its owner gets to be 1 space lower than normal in the turn order, quite an advantage! It's auctioned immediately whenever it appears, so there's some luck to this: if it appears when only one player has much money, that one player is quite happy. :)

item.name: Futbol Ligretto
item.comment:
I played the Polish version "Futbol Ligretto". Very fast silly simultaneous card play, ostensibly simulating a football match. Basically just fast reactions and luck. Fun for a silly filler game, although it seems to only make sense for an even number of players. (But if the two teams have different numbers of players, who really cares? It's for laughs, not a serious game.)
[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/2448473]My review.[/url]
item.conditiontext: I won the Polish version "Futbol Ligretto" in a contest in June 2008, thanks to Kraina Gier.

item.name: Galaxy Trucker
item.comment: Got to learn this from the publisher at Pionek in Gliwice 2007-12-09. Real-time turning over tiles and choosing whether to add them to your spaceship grid reminded me a bit of Factory Fun, and sure enough FF was apparently an inspiration for this, which removes the occasional too-long pondering and is much faster moving. Build your ship with various gadgets hooked together, then everyone flies them on a trade run, suffering various random events. Despite the wide variety of random events, there is clearly skill in the ship design to attempt to handle the various stuff that can happen during the flight. It was fun and interesting and had some clever ideas; I would need to play more to be more sure of my rating.

item.name: Gambit 7
item.comment: I'm not into trivia/party games. But this one's more enjoyable than most, due to the clever idea of ordering people's answers and then betting on them. Apparently it's a less US-centric version of Wits and Wagers, which I've never played.

item.name: Gambit 7
item.comment:
Trivia party game that I liked more than many trivia party games. Doesn't overstay its welcome - only 7 question rounds.
Kind of shoddy components though. The betting disks are thin slippery cardstock - real chips would work much better.
(I also played its original US version Wits and Wagers once, and found W&W to be far too US-centric, to a degree that not just the foreign player but the US players also felt that way. So I prefer and recommend Gambit 7.)

item.name: Gemblo
item.comment:
Fine Blokus-esque game. Basically the same rules as Blokus but with a different definition of what a legal placement is.
But I am not fond of the optional/advanced secret random special action cards. They add luck and hidden info and silly chaos to what (seems to me) should be a pure elegant abstract strategy game.

item.name: Genesis
item.comment: Another elegant Knizia design with tile laying and area control. I like the twist of counting only your largest connected group of animals in an area instead of just all your animals as would be typical in such games. Unusually, this uses dice to tell which color of tiles you can place each turn, but the randomness didn't seem annoying. There some fun aha-insights about strategy and tactics in the first couple games I played. I liked it, although when all the bits are thrown loose into the box, it takes as long to segregate them to set up for play as it does to play the damn game, which was annoying.
item.wishlistcomment: Little-known Knizia game gets little love it seems, but we enjoyed it fine. But it's too low-priority.

item.name: Geniusz
item.comment:
Another nice tile placement game with points earned in an interesting way at each placement. Sometimes randomness in the final turns can be too decisive, but the game is short enough that I don't mind.
Good default game for cons and club meetings - many people know it, and it's quick and easy to explain to those who don't.

item.name: Geniusz: Edycja Podróżna
item.comment:
Nice portable 2-player version. The bits are almost [i]too[/i] small for comfort, but that's what you get for a travel edition. The game itself is good; if you like the regular version, this is the same game, just limited to 2 players.
2010 Xmas gift from a2na. :)

item.name: Gheos
item.comment: Cool game, superficially like Carcassonne with triangular tiles, but really quite different from Carcassonne. Maybe Eufrat/Tigris meets Acquire?

item.name: Ghoulash
item.comment: I like the clever basic idea, but it wasn't as fun as I hoped. Maybe the intro scenario's map is simply too big, which made it feel repetitive.

item.name: GIPF
item.comment: One of my favorites in the Gipf family, though Dvonn has a prettier board and pieces.

item.name: GIPF Project Set 1
item.comment:
The TAMSK ability is cool. Push a loaded piece onto the center square (which is not necessarily a common event) and unload it, using the potential to get an extra move immediately. Even in our first game, we had some fun situations come up with this, e.g. I made 4 in a row with a loaded piece at the head, unloaded it and pushed the row one more, to reach an enemy piece which otherwise wouldn't have been destroyed when the row was removed.
Price drawback: only 12 new pieces in the box, whereas the 2nd and 3rd potential sets include 2 sets (total of 24 new pieces) in their boxes.

item.name: Gipsy King
item.comment:
Played 2 quick games at Essen 2007 and enjoyed it much more than I expected! Once 3-player, once 2-player, and both seemed good. It's like an elegant quick version of Titicaca, in that you place units in areas according to numbered sequence and try to get control of the areas, and also have large connected groups. I am really starting to actively enjoy and seek out games of pure strategy with random starting positions, and this is a fine example of such a game.
[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/227315]My review.[/url]

item.name: Gleebs and Grues
item.comment: It's extremely short (player will make 6 placements and at most 6 moves), and probably perfectly solvable by brute force by a weak computer :) , but it seems a clever and fun light pure 2-player abstract strategy game which also makes nice use of a single Treehouse set (5 different colored trios, with each player meaningfully controlling 2 colors (where it matters that they are 2 colors, not just 2 treated as 1 color) and a neutral 5th color (which actually does stuff too). The rules are short and pretty clear.

item.name: Glen More
item.comment: After 1 play, we both liked it a lot and both felt like it seemed like an improved faster less fiddly version of Shipyard in terms of the central mechanism. I want to play it more.
item.wishlistcomment: Original German edition or newer English edition, either is fine!

item.name: Glik
item.comment:
Nice straightforward abstract pure strategy game. Move your 7 pieces (like Ricochet Robots) through a simple maze to get them all to your goal in the center.
At first I thought the 2-player game had boringly obvious moves, and it was more interesting with the chaos of 3 or 4 players. But after playing it more, I noticed more tactics and decided that 2-player is quite nice and interesting.
item.conditiontext: Limited edition (100) wooden set from Essen 2007, signed by Adam Kałuża.

item.name: Gnostica
item.comment:
Very cool icehouse pyramid game with Tarot cards for the map! It has the clever elegant unified feel of Homeworlds (e.g. 4 actions: create, grow, move, attack), but in a "fantasy" wargame. Much more sophisticated than the similar simpler Zark City. But it can take a long time e.g. 2+ hours to finish. Games can feel epic.
Nice replay value because whatever random subset of Major Arcana cards (as well as minor arcana) starts out in the 9-card initial map can greatly influence how the game unfolds.
So far only played 2-player.

item.name: Go
item.comment:
The abstract strategy game which made me realize I can love abstract strategy games. A new cow-orker taught several of us in the mid 1990s (thanks Rob) and I was hooked immediately. Such surprising beautiful strategic depth arises from such simple minimalist rules. As one of the classics, it's easier to find opponents in real life and online than for most abstract strategy games, and the simple yet functional handicap system is a big advantage over most games. The long history and huge body of literature and culture significance is frosting on the cake.
While I lived in the US, I went to the US Go Congress each summer and most local tournaments. Now I play lots of other abstract strategy games in addition to Go, but I have no doubt I will be enjoying Go for the rest of my life.

item.name: Gobblet
item.comment: Not sure I like the memory aspect in what seems to be otherwise a pure strategy game.

item.name: God's Playground
item.comment:
Xmas 2009 gift from a2na!
Fiddly and inelegant, and a bit longer and more complex than a2na normally prefers, but interesting theme/experience.

item.name: Goro-Goro Dōbutsu Shōgi
item.comment: Similar to [gameid=28389] in scope, more open/strategic/fun than the truly tiny [gameid=56796].

item.name: GOSU
item.comment:
Familiarity with the deck of zillions of different goblin cards is important for this kind of game. Neat elegant core system though!
I'm not so into this kind of fantasy card game these days, but did enjoy my play of it as a change of pace and burst of nostalgia. :) If my wife were more into such games, I could imagine getting back into this kind of thing.

item.name: Gothic Checkers
item.comment:
Another fun traditional checkers variant.
Different versions of rules in the net are inconsistent and confusing; see this thread if you want to play: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/724683/jumps

item.name: Gracias
item.comment: Depends on guesswork and luck but is quick and short and cute filler.

item.name: El Grande
item.comment: A nice area control game that also has a bunch of special effect cards. Longer than I would like, but that may have been due to having 5 players, not all familiar with it, and a non-player wanting continual conversation with us. Played it a few times long ago in Austin, then finally again in Wrocław 2008-07-29 in the garden of Gumowa Róża. I want to play it more.

item.name: The Great Dalmuti
item.comment: I used to play this a lot years ago in Austin. I got to play it again at a game con (Pionek 2012-06-03) and enjoyed the nostalgia trip. A fine light casual game with nice art which encourages silly fun table talk.

item.name: Grim Reaper
item.comment: An odd hybrid sort of luckless perfect information game (like an abstract/combinatorial game), but it has fiddly not very elegant rules like a themed simulation (of biological species reproducing).

item.name: Guillotine
item.comment:
Nice whimsical art and a macabre theme of collecting heads of executed nobles. A silly enjoyable game with luck and tactics. Fast simple rules; you pick up a lot of info from text on the cards themselves.
I used to play this a lot in Austin, and then 2008-01-10 in Poland I finally played again, with a German set, and a terrible translation aid that showed the German cards in random order with their Polish names, then you had to look on a second sheet to find the Polish names (again in random order) and the Polish descriptions. This made the game slower!
2008-11-30: played at Pionek with German cards with Polish descriptions pasted on them. This did not help me the American nor the 2 Czechs in the group. :)
item.wishlistcomment: fluffy filler

item.name: Gyges
item.comment:
Abstract combinatorial game that you can play with a stash of Icehouse pyramids and 6x6 board!
Cool strange tactics, potentially long clever chains of jumps, shared pieces. The kind of game whose strategy and tactics are opaque to a newbie the first couple of plays! :)
Also the game's official website is quite nice with some tutorial info and AI player to practice against. :thumbsup:

item.name: Hanabi
item.comment:
I'm not into coops, so not sure how to rate this as I'm not really in the target audience. Based on a 3-player game, I enjoyed it more than I expected to, perhaps partly because it's short and simple/elegant. The communicating only through formal information ("this and this are green" etc) reminds of communication with a Bridge partner, something which I find theoretically interesting but sort of off-putting in practice. I felt like I got to "play with"/experience that kind of formal narrow communication in Hanabi for a much lower time/effort price than if I were to get into Bridge.
I've since played and enjoyed it several more times. Not something I'd actively seek out, but it does seem more interesting than traditional coops (which could usually just be a solitaire game with a single player running everything - or an alpha player running the team) due to the limited communication channel. So that is cool.

item.name: Hannibal: Rome vs. Carthage
item.comment:
I'd played AH's [gameid=68] once or twice back in Austin in the 90's.
2008-12-06 I finally played the earlier game in this series, Hannibal, with a friend in Wrocław. Yay! Real wargaming again! The first time went slowly, as we kept having to check stuff, roughly 20-30 minutes per turn. I think of myself as most interested in WW2 for wargame purposes, but I enjoyed the subject of this one too, maybe because of my interest in Latin. :) I was Rome and won by capturing Carthage. We've since been playing a couple times a month and enjoying it a lot!
2009-04-01: After playing 10 games and still finding it to be a great game, I'm upgrading my rating to 9. This game has acquired special meaning for me. Normally I don't rate long games so highly, because practically speaking I [i]can't [/i] play them frequently. It's too long to [i]literally[/i] want to play all the time, but when I [i]do[/i] have the opportunity to play a long game, Hannibal is always one I'd like to play.

item.name: Hansa Teutonica
item.comment:
Archetypal euro game with various interacting rules subsystems and slapped on medieval theme. I enjoy it! Pleasing that there's virtually no randomness, but (like Caylus) there's enough going on that it has the feel of chaos/randomness. And various different strategic approaches to victory.
Too bad the 2-player version is generally reviled. I will happily play it when I get the chance at conventions but won't own it due to length/complexity and non-2-player-ness.
item.wishlistcomment: Main drawback is apparently weak 2-player rules.

item.name: Harzdame
item.comment:
Interesting natural adaptation of International Checkers (men move forward diagonally, capture all 4 diagonal directions; kings fly diagonally and don't have to stop on space right after captured piece) to a square board rotated 45 degrees, which certainly changes things!
It seems more natural to play with the board rotated with corners close to players than to play with the board in usual orientation (sides close to players) and pieces move straight ahead or to the right. Either way, it takes a little getting used to. :)

item.name: Havannah
item.comment: A modern classic abstract connection game I'd heard about for a while but hadn't tried until the "mix and match" online abstract tournament. The 3 different ways to win add a nice race element so that it's not enough to secure an unbreakable connection (e.g. as in Hex or Twixt), but you must do it [i]faster[/i] than the opponent. The 3 conditions feel a bit arbitrary and there's wonky details about how the corners don't count as sides (as they normally would in a connection game) - but it's a case of "it works well in practice even if it's slightly inelegant".

item.name: Le Havre
item.comment:
Interesting pleasing core system, but way too long and fiddly for me, I think, and it requires too much specific knowledge of all the buildings to play it competently and rapidly. I found myself continually having to refresh my memory about what building produces what resource which I need to do what again?
It reminded me of why I got sick of programming - too much time learning very specific functions and libraries, not enough general principles. If that makes sense to anyone but me. :)
I admire it but didn't like it as much as I wanted to, ultimately.

item.name: Hellas
item.comment:
I like the hex tile map building: similar to Fjords, with a nice simple wargame element added.
2 problems (which make me wonder if they even playtested the final version, and compel me to give it a lower rating):
1. The game is seriously hindered for newcomers by terribly unclear text on the cards. This is really annoying and disappointing. A game of this simplicity should NOT have so many rules holes and ambiguities.
2. The little plastic soldiers and ships are cheesy quality with small bases, causing them to fall over too easily. I think it might have been better to use wooden cubes for soldiers and long wooden prisms for ships, or some such.
I created the [[Hellas FAQ]] wiki page. Read that before playing!

item.name: Hellenes: Campaigns of the Peloponnesian War
item.comment:
Thanks, Secret Santa!
This is a cool wargame! I need to play more.
I created [[Hellenes FAQ]]. I highly recommend reading it to avoid repeating mistakes we made in our early games. :)

item.name: Helvetia
item.comment:
I find Glen More more enjoyable. This has too much of "important cards that you use to turn X into Y are spread among all the player's tableaus and you need to remember or re-find them" that I am not fond of, but Helvetia is moderate compared to extreme cases like Le Havre. So it's a playable potentially enjoyable version of such a game for me.
But the physical implementation is really bad:
1. The resource icons are not sufficiently different looking. Especially the brick and wood (which both have a sort of rectangular grid symbology) are way too similar.
2. The male and female meeples are way too similar.
3. The center double-sized tile of villages looks too indistinguishable from the "real" tiles.
Many people we played with all agreed that these physical problems made the game needlessly harder to play.
Also the 2-player version looked sufficiently unappealing to us (having to set up a dummy 3rd village, with a whole page of rule changes for 2 players) that we didn't even bother trying it... :/
It seems probably a fine game of its sort, but the lousy physical issues and the unappealing 2-player rules make me rate it a bit lower than I might otherwise.

item.name: Heptalion
item.comment:
Cool little abstract strategy domino tile placement game, each player starting with a random subset of the dominoes.
I like this kind of placement game a lot. It feels sort of reminiscent of Kris Burm's Quads to me (all pieces different, all possible combinations, first player unable to place a piece loses) but is quite different in its details.

item.name: Hera and Zeus
item.comment: Played it once or twice years ago in Austin, then played the German "Blitz und Donner" 2007-12-06. An OK filler game, but too much card-play randomness for my taste. First time you play you need to learn about the special abilities of lots of different special cards.

item.name: Hermit Boxes
item.comment:
It has the common impartial game property of an opaque opening and mid-game (since both players have the same possible moves and same goal, there's no obvious way to play to help yourself and hurt your opponent) until at some point someone can read ahead until the end and see "Aha, I win!" or "Aha, I lose!"
But it's a reasonably enjoyably quick light game in that vein.
It is cool that the instructions come with various problems to solve.

item.name: Hex
item.comment: A classic elegant abstract strategy game of connecting opposite sides of the board by placing pieces; I've read about it more than I've played it. I should change that.
item.wishlistcomment:
On the off chance someone is feeling insanely generous, there is this deluxe acrylic 14x14 hex set for 190,00€ ... :)
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/boardgameversion/133502/nestorgames-14x14-deluxe-edition

item.name: Hexxagon
item.comment: Othello-ish game. Good AI player at http://www.emilystrange.com/beware/games/hexx/index.cfm

item.name: High Society
item.comment: Very clever elegant auction game, with nice components (in both editions I've played). I regret that it doesn't work for just 2 players.
item.wishlistcomment: The drawback is it's for 3 or more players. But we both like it.

item.name: Hippos & Crocodiles
item.comment: Played vs AI at iggamecenter multiple times and in real life. Basically a nice simple Blokus kind of "fit as many pieces as you can" kind of abstract strategy game.

item.name: Hive
item.comment:
Wonderful hefty clacky bakelite pieces and a neat tactical game that rewards replay. Plays quick enough that we sometimes use it to decide who has to wash the dishes.
Unfortunately as players gain experience, the game often leads to a tie result. But then the tournament rule appeared: you can't play the queen as your first move. This greatly solves the frequent tie problem! Play with it.
Of the expansions, I like Mosquito best.
I created the [[Hive FAQ]] wiki page.

item.name: Hive: The Ladybug
item.comment: The ladybug's movement can be quite powerful/useful. It's more straightforward than the Mosquito expansion (which I like since the Mosquito's power is "meta"), but still an interesting worthy expansion. Unless teaching a newbie, we like playing with both expansions.

item.name: Hive: The Mosquito
item.comment:
It's a clever meta 6th bug! The white mosquito tile is slightly pinker than the base set's white tiles. Maybe the mosquito sucked some blood recently!
Update: having now played with ladybug (which seems less interesting to me than mosquito) and pillbug (which introduces a more radical change/concept) I still like the mosquito best of the expansion bugs.

item.name: Hive: The Pillbug
item.comment:
It is a fairly radically different (albeit interesting) bug which takes some getting used to, and also introduces a slightly annoying minor memory element (whatever bug moved on the last turn cannot move on this turn).
If first player starts by placing pillbug, that can be challenging to overcome, it seems to us...

item.name: Homeworlds
item.comment:
What a weird cool clever game!
Seemingly simple rules, but a little hard to learn due to the abstract nature of the "space war". And the whole hidden good-vs-evil identity thing is very odd; not sure if I like that. But it's a cool game which I enjoyed, as I hoped I would, and I hope to try it again, including 2-player (to get rid of the hidden identity weirdness).
Played again twice at Pionek in December 2009, with the "kill the player to your right" variant instead of "good vs evil", and I think I like that more. A2na enjoyed it too, so we bought some pyramids for ourselves for Xmas. :)
Playing 2-player eliminates the good-evil weirdness, and with multiplayer the "sinister variant" is pleasing (win by killing the player to your left).
Enjoyable to play live and online at superdupergames.org!

item.name: Honeypot
item.comment: Pure strategy game. Maybe from playing a lot of Tzaar and Dvonn lately, I'm not as into games like Honeypot that have lots of individual pieces with various values and marked hex facings on them, which seems less elegant. But it was still an interesting little pure strategy game that I played once at BGG.CON 2007 and enjoyed. Practical problem of cloth map that has creases that won't lie flat, and round pieces with hexside arrows would work nicer as hexagonal pieces with hexside arrows.

item.name: Hooop!
item.comment: Clever [[combinatorial game]]. Jump your frogs to reach the other side, and each time you jump, the bridge they used is removed. Each player has 4 special actions usable once in the game. Quite nice for 2, 3, or 4 players. The 3-player version uses a triangular map topology, while the 2 and 4 player versions use a square grid. Quite nice components, in too-large box.

item.name: Icehouse
item.comment:
I've heard it was an inspiration for Lightspeed. It seems more strategic than Lightspeed (that's good) but when we played it the first couple of times, it was confusing real-time chaos, with players confused about strategy.
Based on what I've read, it's just a matter of getting used to it, and it seems worth pursuing, since the game clearly has a dedicated following, annual tournament, many articles published, etc. It seems to be part of the Icehouse pyramid culture, for obvious reasons. :)
Meanwhile, for easier to learn real-time pyramid action, I have found [gameid=9386] to be quite fun, fast, and popular! I think I'd recommend starting with it instead of Icehouse.

item.name: IceTowers
item.comment:
Real time like Icehouse, but without the continuous space and distance issues. Fast and simple and fun, seems to encourage "just one more". I'm not normally into real time games, but I enjoyed this more than expected and was glad to finally get to play it!
It is also much more accessible and easily explainable than Icehouse.
I've played it at a con and found it easy and fun to explain and play with new players.
2012-10-12: We try the new (to us) [url=http://www.looneylabs.com/rules/icetowers]official 2-player variant with a "ghost player"[/url] and it works fine!

item.name: If Wishes Were Fishes!
item.comment: Cute, very euro-ish mechanics, collecting fish to sell or use the wish that the fish will grant if you free it. Cute rubber worms are used as a sort of clever purchasing mechanism. Nifty ideas, but perhaps I'm less into kitchen-sink game designs lately with so many diverse subsystems.

item.name: Igloo Pop
item.comment: Weird very light filler game. It combines real-time grabbing (which I don't like) and careful listening to distinguish sound subtleties (which I don't like) as you must shake sealed opaque plastic igloos with various numbers of balls inside and try to guess how many balls are in an igloo. Groan. At least it doesn't take long to play and so is tolerable as a quick filler.

item.name: Imagination
item.comment:
OK, but for this kind of "find a solution quickly" real-time search game, I prefer Ricochet Pyramids, Ricochet Robots, Dobble, Ubongo Duel, Set, Trio.
Also seems undesirable that the last player has as much time as they want to choose their line on the card. Several user comments suggest starting a timer after the first player picks; this sounds like a good house rule.

item.name: In the Shadow of the Emperor
item.comment:
Played first 2007-04-17 with rules explained in dark smoky pub, not ideal for a game with relatively complex rules and various special actions to remember; I may like it more if I can read the rules and get some experience. I do like that it has no chance (apparently) except for which player is the emperor initially.
2008-03-03 played again. I still like it, but the strategy is elusive and complex, so I suck at it.

item.name: In the Year of the Dragon
item.comment: So many things you want to do in your turn, but you are strictly limited. Tough choices! Virtually no randomness. The random setup of the order of events gives a big influence on what follows, much more than the random setup of the 6 pink buildings in Caylus. We played it with 4 and with 2, and enjoyed both ways.

item.name: Infinite City
item.comment: Disappointingly chaotic/random.

item.name: Innovation
item.comment:
After 1 4-player game, it seems like chaotic fun with nicely clear elegant rules (I like that) and tons of special actions on every card (I'm less fond of that). A more complex "serious" Fluxx? I'll have to play more to decide whether I think it has staying power or not.
2011-08-08: 3 more games (4, 2, and 3-player) in Miodosytnia, and it still reminds me of a more complex Fluxx. Fun, but really big luck swings can happen!
Nice that it seems best instead of worst with 2 players. :)
item.wishlistcomment: Like a jazzed up Fluxx. :) Nice smallish box. But Anna's not interested, so probably shouldn't get it.

item.name: Inside
item.comment: Superficially similar to Pylos, but actually rather different tactics and victory conditions. Similarly simple elegant rules, yet non-obvious strategy and good replay value. Short enough for "just one more".

item.name: International Checkers
item.comment: Bigger board, more interesting movement/capture than the 8x8 US checkers I grew up with.

item.name: Italian Checkers
item.comment: Fun checkers version; men not being able to capture kings is an interesting twist.

item.name: Jacynth
item.comment:
Quick play, simple elegant rules, combination of strategy and luck of the draw; nice game! The overlapping district scoring remind me strongly of [gameid=38931].
[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/693816/a-month-of-jacynth-every-day-in-august]My session report from playing every day in August 2011.[/url]

item.name: Jaskinia Trolla
item.comment: 2-player works better when played on only half the board. Art on the pieces is annoyingly dark and murky, and the green and blue difficult to distinguish in a dark pub.

item.name: Jenga
item.comment: A classic social/party dexterity game and ice-breaker. Not really the sort of game I normally like, but great for when among non-gamers. I don't really take it seriously as a game [i]per se[/i] since it's more of a dexterity exercise, so I decided not to bother logging plays of it. I typically play it at Esperanto events when it happens to be there.

item.name: Julius Caesar
item.comment:
Very pleasing asymmetric strategic wargame. Caesar starts with significantly more military strength, while Pompey starts with significantly more victory point cities (and is closer to additional neutral VP cities to grab them more easily). So the burden is on Caesar to attack.
For our first few games, Caesar was losing horribly, but as we gained experience, both sides seem to have similar chances of victory, and some games have been very dramatic and exciting. Despite the fixed historical setup, every time has played out interestingly differently, and there are various strategies to try out.
The only caveat is that ships seem more powerful/necessary than I would expect/prefer (and a huge fleet can even attack and capture a lightly defended coastal city with no help from any attacking land units), but my opinion may evolve on that. (I don't know enough about the war - perhaps this is historically accurate.)
Good simple rules with very little fiddly chrome. Probably quite suitable as an intro/newbie block wargame for an experienced gamer interested in trying a wargame. Certainly a good first block wargame for any wargamer interested in block wargames. Easily playable in 2 or 3 hours max, but also can end sooner, e.g. we had a game end after the 1st year (of 5 years).
-----
After 17 plays, the game continues to show its good replay value (and we've still only played with the historical fixed setup) and remains quite fun and interesting. So I'm increasing my rating from 8 to 9. In terms of fun, excellent clear rules, and playability in an evening, this is a great block game.

item.name: Jungle
item.comment:
A sort of chess/Arimaa type game. Played it a couple times at IJF 2010 (with its French title "Jeu de la Jungle"). Hard to tell after only 2 plays whether there's much depth to it or not, but at least it was enjoyable trying it out with Tomio from Sweden!
The 2 rivers create some interesting tactical implications.

item.name: Jungle Speed
item.comment: I suck at fast reflex games. The only reason to play this is as a filler when everyone else wants to and you're waiting for more people to show up for the real gaming to begin.

item.name: K2
item.comment:
Simple elegant rules surprisingly capture the risky feel of mountain climbing. Great art.
Note: I was a rules translator.

item.name: K2: Broad Peak
item.comment:
2 new different scenarios, each with some rules tweaks. We are in fact still content with the standard game and don't even feel the need for new K2 scenarios! :)
Note: I was a translator for Broad Peak.

item.name: Kahuna
item.comment: Interesting card play and geographical tactics. I like that the rounds are not independent, and you keep your cards and your placed markers on the map... but that sometimes causes a problem that once once one person is ahead, they'll stay ahead. But surprise turnarounds do happen. Card-counting skills (which I lack) would be useful for playing well.

item.name: Kakerlakensuppe
item.comment: Sequel to Kakerlakensalat, very similar. Great art on the cards, very silly real-time card play with the need to remember and react to changing conditions, leading to hesitations, stammering, and laughter.

item.name: Kaleidoscope Classic Puzzle Game
item.comment:
Game of placing as many of your pieces as you can, analogous to Blokus, Rumis, etc, but the rules here are that the colors on the squares of your piece must match the board squares they cover. Enjoyed it, and I like that it comes in such a small portable well-made box.
Played again a few weeks later and feel more confident that it's a worthy [[combinatorial game]]. (I have spent no time trying the many solitaire puzzles that come with it.)
First played at Essen 2008.
item.wishlistcomment: Interesting Blokus kind of game with many variant maps.

item.name: Kamisado
item.comment:
Ridiculously simple rules, fun quick abstract strategy game!
Only problem would be if you're colorblind. But the back side of the board has squares with symbols in them to help if you can't distinguish the colors.

item.name: Kamisado Schnupperspiel
item.comment:
6x6 board plays quicker and simpler of course.
The pieces are just thin cardstock disks, so it's not as pleasing to play on as the real 8x8 version, but it's so remarkably tiny and thin that it's a neat travel version!

item.name: Karo
item.comment: Played at Essen 2006. Nice little abstract game. It's a bit misleading to have a single rating for Karo, since it's actually a game kit with several different independent games. I like to imagine that SCHLEICHER & HÜPFER is like a simple abstract version of Dungeon Twister, and the advisability of keeping your pieces close together as they progress to the other end reminds me of Devil Bunny Needs a Ham (if players were moving their groups in opposite directions).
item.conditiontext: We play it nicely with Carcassonne meeples standing or lying on upside-down Carcassonne tiles.

item.name: Katoiz
item.comment:
Played at Essen 2008. Some clever ideas, but didn't seem quite "there" for me as a game, and the randomness may be more than I prefer. The very large tiles added to the "for children" feel of the game for me, alas.
Not-quite professional graphic design: e.g. the tile colors include white, so then the die for colors has a barely visible white dot and uses purple to indicate "wild", but the die for shapes uses empty (white) to indicate "wild".

item.name: Ketchup
item.comment:
Nice little game! Very simple elegant rules, interesting game play.
[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/505032/good-short-elegant-abstract-combinatorial-game-of]My review.[/url]
====
The game's rules have evolved through several iterations since that review.
I'm a bit bothered by the inconvenience of counting the sizes of the largest groups, as in real life this proves cumbersome and error-prone once the groups get large and twisty.
Playing online, the computer can precisely track the group sizes for the players, which is convenient.
This raises a sort of philosophical question for me about how to rate the game, since I prefer playing games as boardgames, not online.
I started playing it fairly often at http://littlegolem.net and I like playing it there. Since I most play online, I raised my rating from my original 7 to 8. But at the same time, this fiddliness about needing to accuratedly count the group sizes is a wart on an otherwise fine interesting game. It's sort of like playing a computer wargame and the computer doing all the calculations for players, so players start lazily paying less attention to those details - it's not quite the same as playing a boardgame. Maybe other people who only play games online won't even think about this issue or be bothered by it.

item.name: Khet: The Laser Game
item.comment: It's a real-life version of various Flash games of laser beams and mirrors, with tactical chess-like movement, trying to zap the enemy king. I liked it more than I expected, but it seemed like a risk of deadlock if both players defend their kings too passively with the double-mirror thingies. But certainly worth playing for the novelty value in any case.

item.name: Kingdom Builder
item.comment:
Nice simple almost minimalist rules. Nifty varying powers and ways to earn points and map setup each game.
My only concern is whether the one element of randomness, namely the important terrain card draw each turn, is too much randomness. Possibly house rules can fix it if so. But so far we're enjoying it as is.
(UPDATE 2012-08-04: we sometimes play with my randomless variant: you simply choose your terrain type each turn. That works fine!)
I believe many negative comments are from people who only read the rules or only played once or twice and overstate the impact of randomness. The early turns are crucial and you can lessen the possible damage of the randomness, but that is not obvious the first time you play.
Played 4-er at Essen, bought it, playing 2-ers at home and continuing to enjoy it.

item.name: Kingdom Builder: Capitol
item.comment: Simple elegant addition gives an additional way of getting points. Nice way to spice up the basic game. In a 2-player game, it probably forces both players to try to get near the capitol to roughly split its points; if only 1 dominates it, it's worth potentially big points.

item.name: Kingdom Builder: Caves
item.comment: Fine simple expansion (easy to make your own, analogous to the Capitol).

item.name: Kingdom Builder: Nomads
item.comment:
Adds some natural "expected" new abilities (e.g. location tile to build on flowers) and some qualitatively new stuff (location tile to place stone wall barriers, and the one-use nomad tiles). Plus 3 new goals (which provide points for doing things in your turn instead of points in the final scoring). A fine expansion though certainly not necessary to enjoy the game. I'd play just the base set first to get used to it before using Nomads.
Be sure to read [[Kingdom Builder: Nomads FAQ]] as the rules are unfortunately inconsistent about whether a "built" settlement means strictly "built" or "built or moved"...

item.name: Kingdom Quest
item.comment:
Clever game, hampered by overly ornate portraits (different for each of the 4 players) instead of functional symbols on the nice plastic cubes. The central cube rolling mechanic to reveal a different character each move is clever and interesting, although a bit cumbersome in terms of analysis paralysis and needing to figure out what's on the sides of opponents' cubes to help decide your move. Presumably with experience one would automatically get to know that "OK, the king is on top and joker is facing me, so I know that side has the princess" or whatever, since mercifully and sanely the cubes all have the same orientations of the 6 characters.
Complaint: packaged in larger than needed box. Other Dr. Wood games I played (Kogworks and Kaleidoscope) had a better focus on usefulness (clean elegant components and not buying a box with a lot of air).

item.name: Kingdoms
item.comment: Clever elegant tile placement game with some tile-drawing luck but also lots of tactical decisions to be made. Fast-moving. Used to play it years ago (as Auf Heller und Pfennig), then again while visiting Austin in 2007-11.

item.name: König von Siam
item.comment:
This game seems very cool: a Euro-feeling game with various actions and nontrivial scoring of 3 colored points, but pure strategy with no chance except the random map setup. Read the rules online, looked forward to playing at Essen 2007, and liked it even more than expected. Plus it's got very pretty art.
I created the [[King of Siam FAQ]] wiki page.
item.conditiontext: Signed by Peer Sylvester.

item.name: Kopano
item.comment: Strange interesting brain-twisting connection game, because your own placement can so easily hurt you (by making an illegal place for your opponent suddenly become legal). I find it harder to visualize/read than many other connection games and easier to make a silly blunder!

item.name: Kosmiczna Eskadra
item.comment:
I usually dislike realtime games, and I usually dislike games with continuous measurement instead of discrete grids. So it was quite nice that I actually enjoyed this realtime game with continuous measurement! It's fast fun and quite clever.
Occasional inevitable problematic ambiguities about whether a ship hit another arise.
Light Speed inspired the Looney pyramid game Torpedo which nicely has simpler scoring.

item.name: Kosmonauts
item.comment: Tried it out at Essen. The basic movement system with momentum on a hex grid, and orbiting planets to visit, works fine (though there are some odd simplifications for playability's sake, e.g. that you automatically halt at a planet regardless of how fast you were going). The secret goals and event cards introduce a bit more randomness that I'd prefer, and by necessity (given the solar system setting) the large map takes up a lot of table space, so we decided not to buy it, but it was fun and I'd be happy to play it again sometime. Meanwhile it makes me want to go old school and play [gameid=18481] again. :)

item.name: Kraby
item.comment: Quite nice elegant system. Random luck of the draw might be too important, especially when filling in the last spaces, but it's nice and quick, so that's OK. The art looks great (same artist as Hooop!) but the cardstock tiles are too thin/cheap.

item.name: Krumble
item.comment:
Abstract random game masquerading as thematic "Indiana Jones escaping from crumbling temple" game. Lasted too long for the random sort of family game it seems to be trying to be.
The rules were too long and complex for what should be a fast simple family game. The English rules published with it were unclear in places and simply badly translated with bad English, surprisingly so for such a professional looking game with nice looking art and bits.
Some dubious production/design decisions, e.g. triangular prism blocks that are hard to pick up unless you balance them on their triangle sides, and gratuitous black silhouettes of the characters on one side of their stand-up cardstock figures (which were too thick to fit easily into the tight plastic bases, causing tearing of the bases of the figures), making them hard to tell apart if you're seeing that side of them.

item.name: Książęta Florencji
item.comment:
I have hazy memories of playing it a few times years ago in Austin.
Finally played again 2009-01-17, with the Polish set. A fair amount of text on the cards slowed me down. The Polish edition has gorgeous art. Enjoyable game, want to try it again.

item.name: Księstwo
item.comment: Seemingly a "generic euro", but we enjoy it! Attractive bits. The central mechanism of trading cards between your hand and the central queue, which loses its head card and gains a new card at the tail each turn, introduces some interesting tactics. There is definite luck of the draw in what order the cards come out, but still plenty of room for intelligent planning and tactics. I also like that there is not a huge number of various special action cards, but rather a small easy-to-teach set of card types.
item.conditiontext: Received as 2nd place prize in Qwirkle tournament at [[Gratislavia]] on 2012-04-01, yay! :)

item.name: Kulami
item.comment:
Neat modular board that you can set up differently each time, pretty red and black marbles.
Area control (most marbles on a board claims points equal to number of holes on the board).
Each move determines the row or column in which the following move must be made. Neat elegant little game. Didn't read the rules, but looks like it has various variants.
If it had been cheaper, we'd have probably bought it at Essen 2011.
item.wishlistcomment: We enjoyed it at Essen 2011.

item.name: Kyoto Shogi
item.comment:
Amusing odd small (5x5, 5 pieces per player) Shogi variant which does NOT use the standard pieces rules (so I wouldn't recommend it for learning or practicing standard Shogi - try Mini Shogi, Judkins Shogi, Goro-Goro Shogi, or Simple Shogi for that).
The pieces have nonstandard promotion values, and every time you move a piece, you flip it over! Fun weird change of pace.

item.name: Labyrinth
item.comment: Master Labyrinth is more strategic and better, since you have more knowledge of other people's goals. In Amazing Labyrinth it seems hit or miss whether you accidentally thwart or help your opponents, so I feel like why play this instead of Master Labyrinth? But the basic mechanism of both games (shift the maze, then move) is cool. As a long-time fan of Master Labyrinth (the good 1991 version), it was interesting and fun to play this earlier version, 2007-10-11.

item.name: Lady Alice
item.comment:
Alas, not 2-player! Only for 3-5 players.
Very nice art, good simple Clue-like game. We played 4-player (which seems the ideal number since the mystery has 4 aspects to discover) at Essen and enjoyed it.
There is more psychology / bluffing than Mr. Jack (obvious comparison of mystery game from same publisher) as you "invest" in possible clue solutions based partly on what other players seem to invest in.
Also it is a symmetrical game, unlike Mr. Jack.
But it's not simultaneous (mostly) solitaire like P.I. (other obvious comparison of another Essen 2012 mystery game). You definitely pay attention to what the other players are doing.

item.name: LAP
item.comment:
"Owned" as described in 2 different books: Gamut of Games & Świat Gry.
Cool paper and pencil game, a sort of hybrid of Mastermind, Battleship and Polyominous type puzzles.

item.name: Lascaux
item.comment: A quite nice bidding and set collecting game. Very pretty art and stones, and a clever auction mechanism. It sometimes suffers from the randomness of simultaneous secret decisions, but is short enough and clever enough that I don't mind.

item.name: Letnisko
item.comment:
Nice short game with unusual historical theme!
I was a translator. (Note that a clarification was added to the Polish rules afterward which isn't in the English: passengers who were not invited by a player will stay in their train wagons, and might be claimed (along with future passengers) in a later turn.)
Tangential note: I highly approve of Letnisko's shelf-friendly and environment-friendly small square box; too many publishers put similar games in much larger boxes mostly full of air.

item.name: Liar's Dice
item.comment: I know it as Bluff. Finally played in Poland 2007-06-29. An old favorite from Austin, where we once enjoyed a game of it with 14 players... :)

item.name: Limit
item.comment: Interesting abstract strategy game with 2 phases: opening setup with creation of the playing area, then movement and shrinking of the playing area. Non-obvious strategy at first, but then some key ideas start to click.
item.wishlistcomment: Sounds like another interesting abstract from Cameron Browne and nestorgames.

item.name: Lines of Action
item.comment:
I'd heard this pure strategy game recommended for years, and it didn't live up to the hype for me. (Played once sometime in 2006 before I started logging games; more importantly, before I got really into abstract strategy games as a genre...) Possibly I need to try it more.
2010-10-30: Yep, I like it more now that I like abstract strategy games more. Upgraded from 5 to 7. :)
2012-12-14: Upgraded to 8. :)

item.name: Linja
item.comment: Played at Essen 2006. Nice little pure strategy abstract game of moving your pieces to the other end of the playing field.

item.name: Linkage
item.comment: Interesting combinatorial game with an unusually arbitrary sounding winning condition (players are fighting to get fewer than 12, or at least 12, connected groups on the board), it works nicely and we had various "aha" moments in our first set of 7 games.
item.wishlistcomment: Played this online at iggamecenter and also made a crappy cardboard set a while back. :)

item.name: The Little Prince: Make Me a Planet
Livingstone
item.comment: The dice claiming mechanism is quite clever, and I liked that idea a lot. But the gem-drawing was way too random. Overall I felt the game was not bad, but not particularly fun or special; perhaps too long for what it is.

item.name: Lobo 77
item.comment:
The decisions generally seemed pretty obvious (and sometimes you have no meaningful choice as any card play loses). More of a light social pastime with simple rules, no need for in-game thinking, so time for chatting with other players.
Played late-night in final socializing at the end of a week-long event chatting with friends old and new, and in that context it was fun, but it's nothing I'd intentionally seek out.

item.name: Logan Stones
item.comment: The third game of nice clacky Bakelite tiles from John Yianni! This one's quite different from Hive and Army of Frogs because it includes the need to remember what's on the bottom side of tiles... I find it very humbling that I forget what was on the other side of a few tiles so easily! :)

item.name: London
item.comment: Much more clear elegant system than some Wallace games. Seems it would be very easy to remember and play again after a long time of not playing, e.g. if you get a chance at a convention. But a bunch of cards with unique descriptions to keep track of, and a little bit longer than we normally prefer - in that sense, it reminded me of a somewhat quicker/lighter Le Havre. Very nice components! Played 4-player and 2-player and enjoyed it fine.
item.wishlistcomment: Played twice at local con, 4-player and 2-player. A bit longer and fiddlier than we normally like, although possibly quicker with more experience?

item.name: Loonacy
item.comment: Real-time pattern recognition, enjoyable if you enjoy similar games like Set and Dobble/Spot It!

item.name: Loopit
item.comment:
Played at Essen 2008. Enjoyable light game, sort of Scrabble meets Ta Yü.
A little disappointing that the different topologies of loops on the tiles are meaningless; it could just have well been tiles with 2 colors of sides, and sides must match.

item.name: Lords of Waterdeep
item.comment: Fun fairly straightforward worker placement game with the usual pros and cons of "increasing numbers of relevant cards coming into play"; we found the text small to read across a large board.

item.name: LOT
item.comment: Clever meta "3 in a row" type game where you get 3 normal pieces in a row to create a promoted piece, and need 3 promoted pieces in a row to win. Various aha-effects to be had - more to it than meets the eye at first!

item.name: Love Letter
item.comment: Fun simple "hot game from Essen 2012". Clever fun with 16 cards.

item.name: Love Letter
item.comment: Fun simple "hot game from Essen 2012". Clever fun with 16 cards.

item.name: Magnate
item.comment:
Quite enjoyable; sort a Decktet mashup of Schotten-Totten and Settlers of Catan.
Drawback: Requires 2d10 and d6 and various Decktet-colored markers/cubes/discs.

item.name: Magnet
item.comment:
Pros: Good solid chunky square plastic pieces, well-made and indistinguishable from the opponent's side (which is important in a Columbia block type game). Interesting tactical game play and bluffing. I like Columbia block wargames, and this gives a bit of that feel in a much shorter more elegant abstract game.
Cons: Garish lens-flare sci-fi graphics on the board. Over-sized box: if the board had folded into quarters instead of halves, I'd have bought this game. But the box that's twice as long was a turn-off for me with my limited shelf-space and desire to carry games to club meetings.
Played at Essen 2008.
item.wishlistcomment: Played and enjoyed, but too-large box annoyed us so we didn't buy it.

item.name: Mahjong
item.comment: Takes too long for what it is, but playing with a nice quality set and friendly people is kind of cool.

item.name: Manalath
item.comment:
Reminds me a little bit of [gameid=27172] in that you place pieces but can't make a contiguous group above a certain size (5 in this case). You can place your own color or your opponent's! Try to cause an opponent's group of size 5 to win.
There are tricky tactics to discover!

item.name: Mandala
item.comment: The "moving ahead as far as you like" somehow reminds me of Glen More. I like the game more than others I've played it with, alas.

item.name: Manhattan
item.comment: Fun clever system of cardplay and stacking skyscraper pieces, pleasant and quick, although a bit too lucky for my taste. I like the older smaller edition with New York neighborhoods more than the newer pointlessly larger version with world cities.
item.wishlistcomment: NOTE: Would only like the smaller original Mayfair edition with New York neighborhoods. The larger edition in oversized box is uglier and takes up too much space.

item.name: Manila
item.comment: First played 2007-12-06. Some interesting/amusing mechanisms with decisions to make, but man, what a bunch of luck as well. And the rich get richer.

item.name: Manoeuvre
item.comment:
I read the good reviews and was looking forward to this one for a while. Finally got a chance to play it twice at [[Pionek]] in September 2008, and I like it. My only complaints are: 1. The rules have a few too many unclear fiddly bits that require errata to be sure what is meant. 2. It took longer than I expected. I hope it will become faster with experience. It seems in a way like a historical equivalent to Neuroshima Hex: a "wargame" that's really more of a eurogame with a thin theme. Quite enjoyable. I want to play more.
2008-11-04: played with a2na, but sadly it's not her cup of tea. Too explicitly about real historical war, and too much randomness (dice + cards).
item.wishlistcomment: The initial excitement wore off, and a2na doesn't like it.

item.name: Margo
item.comment:
Good very natural-feeling extension of Go to 3 dimensions by way of stacking spheres.
Some of your Go knowledge/intuition will be useful and some of your Go knowledge/intuition will surprisingly totally mislead you. :)

item.name: Maria
item.comment:
A little bit more complexity and chrome than its 4-player predecessor Friedrich, but just as playable and interesting, with the same fascinating characteristic look and feel. The rules are odd & subtle (e.g. one must pay careful attention to distinctions of major and minor powers, allied and cooperating and enemy and neutral, etc.), yet pretty carefully/precisely written and not too complex.
The card-based combat system is odd but fun with beautiful stylish components.
I suppose if you like one, you'll like the other! I like both. Maria seems easier for me to get to the table just because it needs only 3 players instead of 4.
====
But 2 complaints about sub-standard markers:
The 132 square markers are very lamely die-cut: They have white side nubs sticking out where they were attached to the sprues, which are very hard to try trimming off, and make the markers look cheap and ugly. :( Most modern game companies know to have the markers attached at their corners, not in the middles of their sides.
Also why do most fortress markers have fortress on front and question mark on back, but some of them annoyingly have question mark on front and fortress on back? Pointless confusing inconsistency.
A beautiful game designed with such care deserves better markers than these, which are not congruent with the rest of the game's otherwise excellent physical design.

item.name: Marrakech
item.comment:
Fun filler game. A stark mix of pure strategy (in the decisions of which way to face Assam and where to lay one's carpets) and die-rolling luck (in how far Assam moves).
The carpet-laying mechanic is nice, and the little carpets made of actual cloth are cute, as well as being a good clever solution to the mechanical problem of stacking carpets partially covering other carpets, so that the two halves of carpets are often at various heights. (The game would not work well physically with traditional rigid tiles instead of soft flexible cloth.)
Thumbs down for them doing the penny-wise pound-foolish thing of giving 15 carpets in 3 colors and only 12 in the 4th color, so that when playing with 3 colors, no player can choose that 4th color.
After 4 plays, with 2 players and 4 players, it seems the luck factor is too high for me to really take the game seriously, but it is a fun filler game. First played a couple times 2008-06-05, then twice more at Pionek 2008-06-08.

item.name: Martian Chess
item.comment: The first few games are full of aha-epiphanies because of the way piece ownership depends on which part of the board they're on, not on the color. Forget what you think you know about chess-like games! Fun stuff. The strategy seems more interesting than I expected. Need to try more multiplayer.

item.name: Martian Coasters
item.comment: A light random filler, more fun than Treehouse since I like shifting tile maze type games.

item.name: Masons
item.comment: Played only one time, at Essen 2006, with a bit of vagueness in the rules explanation, so my rating is hesitant.

item.name: Master Builder
item.comment: The basic idea is fine, but: 1. The 3-D cardstock buildings to be assembled during play are a bit gimmicky and inconvenient. 2. The random events each turn are too chaotic and can really screw you.

item.name: Master Labyrinth
item.comment: This 2007 edition is gussied up with dragons and dice and craziness that we couldn't understand from the German rules, but it was too much chrome. I was sad and hoping for the classic elegant 1991 edition when we sat down to play this at Essen. We had the rules partially explained to us, and it was not pleasing compared to the classic original. They should not have added all the plastic chrome, and they should especially not have done so while keeping the same title, which just causes confusion. This is quite different from the excellent 1991 Master Labyrinth.

item.name: Master Labyrinth
item.comment:
I'm talking about the original 1991 edition here, not the 2007 version. It's an elegant clever strategy game of moving through a shifting maze to collect numbered tokens in order. Serious gamers/adults and casual gamers/kids can both enjoy it.
There is a separate BGG entry for the highly revamped 2007 edition which is gussied up with dragons and dice and craziness that we couldn't understand from the German rules, but it was too much chrome, and they should have changed the title if they were going to change the game so much.
item.wishlistcomment: Note this is the OLDER version, NOT the recent cheesier one with big plastic dragon and other silly chrome and extra rules. See http://boardgamegeek.com/image/94616/master-labyrinth No interest in the newer version.

item.name: Mastermind
item.comment: Childhood nostalgia! Not really an interactive game [i]per se[/i], but still a classic fun puzzle/game experience.

item.name: Masterplan
item.comment:
Placement game, earning points (tracked by pawns along the edge of the square grid board, which somehow felt slightly odd).
Enjoyable, but felt more tactical/opportunistic; not sure what long term strategizing exists in it. On average, score similar numbers of points per turn; it didn't seem likely a grand dramatic upset would happen.
Elaborate pricey wooden production.

item.name: Matrix
item.comment: I learned of this game since my mom has an old copy she used to play with her dad in the 1950s. It's a direct representation of classical game theory with simultaneous selection of options from a payoff matrix, but better than I'd expect, and a complete game is playable in less than 10 minutes. The second phase could be played optimally if one cared to solve the payoff matrix, but I suppose in practice people just pick an option based on intuition and trying to psyche out the opponent. The first phase (interactively creating the payoff matrix) is more interesting than I thought it would be, and arguably the core of the game, as you both want to make the matrix more favorable for your side - the first part is essentially a pure combinatorial strategy game!

item.name: Mecanix
item.comment:
Interesting pure strategy game with the clever gimmick that you physically turn the gears to verify that the board state conforms to the rules (e.g. a triangle of adjacent occupied points is illegal). Try to get a chain of gears from your home corner to the goal corner to win, or force your opponent to lose by not being able to turn their home gear.
More experience gives an aha-experience: the goal is not really to reach the yellow gear (despite the emphasis on that in the rules), but to jam the opponent's home gear before they jam yours. See [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/350546/gold-kog-unreachable]this forum thread[/url] for more discussion, especially if you (erroneously) think the game is broken and draw-ish.

item.name: Medici
item.comment: My group used to play this game a lot in the old days. Got to play it for the first time in years at Pionek in Gliwice 2007-12-09, and I was pleased that I could remember the rules so well. A nice auction game.

item.name: Medici vs Strozzi
item.comment: Reasonable 2-player auction game; I liked it more than a2na did.

item.name: Memoir '44
item.comment: Annoying fiddly setup time, too much randomness, but it's a nice simple fun system, and you can play a scenario in less than half an hour. I enjoy playing this sort of fast Ameritrash sometimes.

item.name: Metro
item.comment:
I remember playing this a few times years ago and enjoying it; got to play again 2008-08-29 and still enjoy it. A nice track-laying game, with a fair amount of luck but still good strategy and planning too. Pretty components.
2008-11-30: Anna won it at [[Pionek]] for 3rd place in the logical games tournament!

item.name: Metropolys
item.comment:
Played first at [[Pionek]] September 2008. Didn't know what to expect and was quite impressed. Very clever unusual central mechanic that combines auction mechanics with territory control tactics. All 4 of us liked it a lot, and I want to play more. Plus the art is unusual and cool looking.
Have played it 2-player, and it works well.

item.name: Mijnlieff
item.comment:
2011-12-19: Thanks, Secret Santa! :)
Nice short abstract strategy game where your move restricts where the opponent's next move must be, in the vein of Synapse Ice and Coffee. Nice hand-made wooden bits. The ability to arrange the 4 board quadrants arbitrarily, not just as a big square, during setup gives good variety.

item.name: Milestones
item.comment: Low interaction euro, but interesting and has played out surprisingly different in our several initial plays.

item.name: Mini Shogi
item.comment:
Seems a fun little "gentle introduction" to Shogi, using only 6 piece types, so easier to learn the kanji symbols and get used to some of the tactics.
After playing about 20 times: yes, it is a good fun way to learn the kanji and get basic Shogi tactics. Some comments complain about draws, but we've never had one; most of our games last 10-15 minutes, it seems, but occasionally longer.

item.name: Mirador
item.comment:
Very clever connection game that uses line of sight in a way I'd not seen before. Lots of weird little clever tactics and strategies and aha-insights to uncover.
It's also quite playable with ordinary graph paper and pens, which is nice, or online at superdupergames.org (I've been enjoying it both ways).

item.name: Modern Art
item.comment: We played this Knizia auction classic a lot in the old days before the flood of many German games hit the US. I think I burned out on it a bit, but I recently played it again finally (2009-06-13), and it still holds up. Only real complaint is the luck of getting double-auction cards.

item.name: Mondriaan 2020
item.comment:
OK tile placement game. Scoring with each placement, a bit like Ingenious. I wanted to like it more than I did. It seemed to lack a certain mysterious spark, as I found it OK but not great, and both my opponents were less impressed than I and didn't want to play again, though I would have.
The tiles are unnecessarily inconveniently large, which made it awkward to play - we had to shift the arrangement several times each game.
Tried at Essen 2011.

item.name: Montego Bay
item.comment: Too long a game for having so much random chaos from 4 players making 2 simultaneous decisions each turn. And the final round is disproportionately important from all ships sailing.

item.name: Mow
item.comment:
A cute filler, a bit like a simpler quicker version of 6 Nimmt.
It also has an incredibly large number of languages in its multilingual rulebook, even including Esperanto!

item.name: Mozaika
item.comment: The central element of trying to make certain patterns to score points somehow doesn't quite have a spark for me. Not as polished and clean as some other games by Folko.

item.name: Mr. Jack
item.comment:
Very clever 2-player puzzle/detective game full of "aha" moments!
Beginners think it's terribly hard to win with Jack, but that's false. The game is pretty balanced once you know what you're doing. (See the [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/261489]strategy article[/url] by FerrumEtBombyx.) Newbies make mistakes like trying too hard to escape with Jack instead of keeping all the suspects together and visible.
The only real downside is that often the detective must guess between the remaining suspects in the end, so all the cleverness by both players can come down to a matter of a lucky/unlucky guess.
But sometimes Jack can arrange things so that in the final turn the Detective knows for sure who Jack is, but can't reach him to accuse him - leading to delightful wails of anguish from the Detective player!

item.name: Mr. Jack Extension
item.comment:
Pricey for 5 new characters, so we held off on buying it since the original game kept holding our interest. But I got it as a birthday gift, and now we're quite happy to have it! If you buy it, be sure you ask about the cards since the original printing screwed up and made square-cornered cards.
[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/294096]My review.[/url]

item.name: Mr. Jack in New York
item.comment:
The same core idea as the original game, but totally different map and character abilities, plus a little additional chrome to learn.
If you're new to Mr. Jack, I recommend playing the original game first, then the expansion, then New York.
item.wishlistcomment: We used to play tons of Mr. Jack, but not so much lately. Not sure how much the New York version would hit the table.

item.name: Mr. Jack Pocket
item.comment:
Very interesting! A truly tiny little game which has a theme and interesting tactics analogous to the original, yet quite different in the specifics, with simpler rules and seems to play in a shorter time. I am impressed. Feels less deep, but it's nonetheless fun and clever and enjoyable.
2010-12-24: Xmas gift from a2na! :)

item.name: Mr. Jack Pocket: Goodies
item.comment: Conceptually fine extra character, but unfortunately mis-die-cut from the opposite side as the base game pieces so that the alibi card is a bit recognizable from its different edge cut. :/

item.name: Munchkin
item.comment: A quite random and silly "take that" game that drags on too long. I kind of wish I liked it more than I do, since the idea amuses me. Its positive points are: 1. The rules seem fairly clear and unambiguous (impressive for such a card game with zillions of special effects). 2. Often stupidly humorous text and art on the zillions of cards. I played it once before years ago in Austin, then again at Gumowa Róża 2008-07-01. Possibly once every few years is about right.

item.name: Murus Gallicus
item.comment:
Clever Roman-themed abstract that sort of chess-like, sort of mancala-like.
Check out the downloadable playable version in the Files section. Very nice easy way to get a feel for the game against an AI player if you have no live opponent at hand.

item.name: My Word!
item.comment: Simple word / party game my mom taught us and gave us. Fun in the way that games like Bananagrams are fun.

item.name: Mystique Chain
item.comment: An enjoyable impartial game of the type "keep alternating moves until the game state is simple enough that you can read ahead".

item.name: Mystique Energy
item.comment: Card version of Nestor's later domino game Dominimum. Try to minimize the sizes of groups of your own secret symbols while trying to deduce what secret symbols your opponent wants to minimize.

item.name: Mystique Maze
item.comment:
Interesting weird idea of navigating through the 3-dimensioal (number, color, suit) space from one corner to the far corner by a series of 1-step moves (it takes 9 steps: 4 to move from 1 to 5, 3 to move from suns to arms, 2 to move from yellow to blue). The taxicab/Manhattan geometry is tricky to visualize in 3 dimensions!
Seemingly the strategy is to hope to get a midpoint card (e.g. red 3 of moons or crowns) to maximize your later options before and after it. In some sense it seems to come down to luck of the draw, but it's an interesting mind-twisting experience. If I get more experienced, I'll pay more attention to what the opponent seems to be going for... as a newbie, the main challenge seems to be maximizing one's own options and keeping things straight without trying to much to worry about what card to discard without helping the opponent too much. :)

item.name: Napoleon's War: The 100 Days
item.comment:
Fairly simple wargame. I'm not a fan of miniatures, which are somewhat cumbersome to manipulate and require the map hexes to be larger than they'd be with counters.
There are also too many annoying minor vague points in the rules, although overall the important points are mostly clear.

item.name: Network
item.comment:
A bit reminiscent of the (much later) game Mirador: a connection game where lines of sight between placed pieces form the connection from one side to the other.
But the 8x8 board of Network seems small and thus seems to give a notable first player advantage, at least in our games so far...
And it doesn't seem to be as interesting/deep as Mirador: the board seems too small. At this point, I don't expect this will be a game I'll want to play a lot. There are other games with disks on an 8x8 board that are more fun.

item.name: Neuroshima Hex!
item.comment:
Interesting abstract placement game in the guise of a postapocalyptic wargame. The only chance and hidden information is the order you draw your tiles (like Cave Troll). Plus you can set up, play, and put it away in less than a half hour.
[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/152943]My review.[/url]
