During September 2007, [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/207664]I gave away a free copy of this game[/url].

item.name: Neuroshima Hex! Babel13
item.comment: I was involved in testing and translating this Neuroshima Hex supplement.

item.name: Neuroshima Hex! Doomsday Machine 1.0
item.comment:
This 5th army seems weaker and its rules have some unfortunately unclear places, but there is a new ability for a unit to receive friendly fire as an input and redirect it out another direction (or directions!) which is cool, and there is a Grab action that seems neat, sort of the opposite of Push.
[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/325781]My review.[/url]
2011-12-17: Although this army lost a lot for a while, as we gained experience it started to win. It may just be harder to play well until you get a sense for it.

item.name: Neuroshima Hex! Mad Bomber
item.comment:
The Mad Bomber introduces some strange new tactics to Neuroshima Hex!
[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/291331]My review.[/url]

item.name: Neuroshima Hex! Mephisto
item.comment: Clever! New type of "implant" units are placed anywhere on the board to enhance the HQ (Mephisto's only attacking unit!) in various ways.

item.name: Neuroshima Hex! Sharrash
item.comment:
The HQ's "sewer movement teleport" ability is clever, potentially making it hard to target the HQ (unless they get netted, for example!)
Several other new unit abilities are thrown in.

item.name: Neuroshima Hex! Steel Police
item.comment:
Such individual army packs seem a very good idea! No wasteful boxes of mostly air.
The tiles are a nice matte finish, but thinner than the tiles of past NH armies.
The army itself seems interesting. The new gimmick is some units have a reflecting shield which not only stops damage but reflects it back in the direction it came from. And the HQ can lose a hit point to put a special net on any enemy unit. Need to play more to evaluate balance, but so far it won its first 2 games, with each of us playing them once. :)

item.name: Neuroshima Hex! The Dancer
item.comment:
Unusual Neuroshima Hex army due to having only 3 units ("objects") on the board instead of a single HQ! New type of action tile lets one of the objects perform one of its actions (a shot or hit... or a new healing action). Each object has 10 hit points, and if any of them die, Dancer loses. This introduces some different strategic thinking.
Unfortunately it required some new rules on how its weird 3-object-no-HQ paradigm interacts with various other armies, but on the whole it's straightforward. We only felt significant uncertainty with respect to how it interacts with Steel Police's steel net.
[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/blogpost/20020/monthly-tournament-may-2013-neuroshima-hex-the-dan]We played with it every day in May 2013.[/url]

item.name: Neuroshima Hex! Uranopolis
item.comment: Fun new expansion army with pretty good clear straightforward rules. The main new concept here is that many units need to be connected to power (from HQ or a few other special power supplying pieces) to work. Easy to grok and clear "plug and socket" iconography for that. A few new special units/actions, too.

item.name: Nice Weather
item.comment:
Played at Essen 2008. At its core, it's a rail network building game. The track laying and money systems are elegant and pleasing. There's a clever nice mechanic about buying track from other players that works well. We enjoyed the game.
But: There are some cards and special effects that add random flavor with some overt environmentalist preaching which I agree with, and some amusing gamer geek in-jokes about Essen being special, but I would have preferred a more "pure" elegant rail game. The cards have rather busy art, and are dominated by cryptic tables of data only used in the setup, so I'd rather have seen the setup info handled differently.

item.name: Ninja Versus Ninja
item.comment: Cute but random fluffy tactical filler.

item.name: No Retreat! The Russian Front
item.comment:
Fun game, good physical quality, with lower unit count and thus shorter turns than East Front (my main game to compare with No Retreat). So that's good.
But it has some interesting-but-weird mechanisms which take some getting used to (e.g. the confusing counterblow stuff; the whole initiative thing of "we're tracking only German VPs until the middle of the game, then we're tracking only Soviet VPs"; the confusing business about Soviet units being 1-step but upgradable to their 2nd side, then becoming 2-step later in the game; different types of "white strength" units which are immobile fortifications or sometimes not; the needlessly complex explanation about tracking victory points and separate event victory points; etc) and lots of special case chrome to worry about (e.g. the myriad of special abilities for the two sides which become enabled and disabled in various circumstances depending on calendar time and weather, the difference between sea hexsides & lake hexsides matters but is never actually mentioned, etc). (EF has special case chrome as well, probably like all WW2 East front games, but it feels like more confusing weird details in NR to me.)
And as a fan of Combat Commander's excellent rules quality, I'm rather frustrated and disappointed by the much lower quality of NR's rulebook. Lots of different vagueness and unexplained things and blatant editing/proofreading errors. Basic stuff which should be covered isn't like about timing issues when cards are played in reaction to other cards and the usual ambiguities about "play anytime" type cards. So NR simply feels underdeveloped compared to CC. And there seem to be continual tweaks and changes to the system for various game balance and/or historical accuracy reasons, as well as to correct errors (in rules and in scenario info) or unclear rules.
Be sure to download and read GMT's "living rules" and not just play based on the paper rulebook. At least NR's Carl Paradis is fairly active in the forum here to answer questions, so that helps. I wish Chad Jensen had been hired to write/edit the rules, though... as it stands, it seems a good game trapped in a mediocre-at-best "work in progress" rulebook. I'd rate it higher if it had a good clear stable rulebook. Probably some wargamers are used to dealing with these issues and don't mind as much as I do.

item.name: Noah
item.comment: Based on a 5-player game. The penalty for not being able to play a card (take all the cards in the stack into your hand) seemed way too harsh to us. An OK filler I could imagine playing again at a con (as we played it), and I can see that with more experience one could play better (so it's not just totally random), but it just didn't seem all that fun.

item.name: Novem
item.comment: Classical game theory distilled into a pretty wooden game. Opponents simultaneously pick row/column of the current payoff matrix to claim the points there. Repeat until a row or column is empty. I liked it ok, Anna was "meh".

item.name: OddVille
item.comment: Based on one 3-player game. Fun. Some interesting decisions to make, enjoyable city building map puzzling, not too long.

item.name: Ogre: Pocket Edition
item.comment:
Classic quick fun science fiction asymmetrical wargame. (Also a good introductory wargame.) Long ago I played it a lot. It was the first and arguably most influential of the Metagaming MicroGames.
The recent over-produced Designer's Edition did not appeal to me, but I am happy to own and enjoy the simple classic $2.95 edition again! Thanks for the memories and for the chance to play the classic edition again, SJG!
item.wishlistcomment:
Nostalgia. In summer 2014 the reprint of the original $2.95 finally goes on sale!
The over-produced behemoth designer's edition with weird shaped counters and 3-D figures is definitely NOT for me. :)

item.name: Okiya
item.comment:
Good game, gorgeous Japanese-themed art on the cardstock tiles.
The multiple victory conditions work nicely.
The "lose if you can't move" makes it feel perhaps like one of those where the opening is somewhat opaque but near the end you can read ahead with certainty to see "Player X will win". But there is actually some clear strategy as well early on due to the 4x4 grid spatial positioning with threats to make a square or line!
Short gameplay, simple easy rules.

item.name: Omba
item.comment: Not so interesting game for us; looks like a potentially interesting abstract, but you roll a die for movement points each turn, and make usually reasonably obvious moves until luck turns out to be on your side and you win, or vice-versa. OK filler.

item.name: OMEGA
item.comment:
I was worried the clever multiplicative scoring idea might be "too clever" and not actually "fun", but we liked it! Interesting and fun.
And it's a plus that various other good games like Havannah can be played with this set. :)
item.wishlistcomment: We liked it at Essen, plus it is possible to play large-board Havannah with it, which I'm currently enjoying online!

item.name: Once Upon a Time: The Storytelling Card Game
item.comment: Not a game in the normal BGG sense, it's a shared storytelling experience that is better if played with people who aren't focused on winning it as a game. With people who are in the right spirit it can be a fun activity. With people who aren't in the right spirit, it's boring and annoying. The cards are useful as a language learning game also. I can also say from experience that it's very hard playing with a group of people playing in their native language that you don't understand very well. :)

item.name: Onirim
item.comment:
2011-12-22: Thanks Secret Santa! :)
Unusual theme/art in this nice solo game. Fun, but has drawback of needing to shuffle many times, theoretically you might need to shuffle after every turn, and in practice it feels like you do shuffle after about half the turns, more or less.
item.wishlistcomment:
Not normally into coop games, but this looks different and surreal and cool. Plus it works solitaire.
And I bought the solo card game Friday in Essen 2011 and enjoyed it.

item.name: Onirim
item.comment:
You must collect the doors in a specific order randomly determined at setup, so that's harder.
You can permanently spend discarded spells to activate several different spells (e.g. spend 10 discarded cards to deal with a revealed nightmare with no further penalty), so that's easier.
The 2 changes don't seem particularly thematically linked, but it's a fine little expansion. I've not played enough yet to know if it makes it harder or easier to win...

item.name: Onirim
item.comment:
A new type of labyrinth card in your deck: 12 towers. They are a second required victory condition in addition to the 8 doors: you also need to have 4 towers in play. If you're not careful, you may find yourself with too many discarded towers as the game's end approaches! Especially since you can discard a tower to look at and re-order the top cards of the deck.
Seems a fine little expansion. Mildly inconvenient that the cards are mixed into the main deck, making it harder to play later without the expansion if you are so inclined. Also I found the red towers look confusingly similar to the red doors if I'm not paying close attention...

item.name: Onyx
item.comment: Connection game on very weird unfamiliar grid. Takes some time to adjust to the grid and also to the weird rules about playing and capturing on the vertices of squares. Playing because of the "mix and match" online abstract tournament. So far it seems OK but not compelling to me.

item.name: Ordo
item.comment:
Playing online and enjoying it. The pieces can move arbitrarily far, but the restriction that your entire set must stay contiguous keeps it manageable and not "chess-like" for me. I find a good strategy seems to be not trying to reach the goal soon, but rather forcing the enemy to capture my stones - eventually I'm reduced to a tiny group (e.g. 1 stone) that is highly mobile and easily runs to the goal.
2010-12-16: Noticed I'd still not rated it, so rated it (hesitated between 7 & 8, went with 7 till I play more). Starts gradually, often leads to intense midgame if one player makes a rush to the goal, otherwise a careful game of maneuvering and careful reduction. Still only played standard version, not Ordo X (which sounds less appealing to me, but who knows.)
item.wishlistcomment: Been playing this abstract a bit on superdupergames.org and enjoying it.

item.name: Othello
item.comment:
Pre-2010: I used to not like it...
2010-01-07: Played several times with a2na during the new year's event JES and enjoyed it a little more, so I hesitantly increase its rating from 4 to 5. But I still suck frustratingly at it.
2010-12-20: It's finally grown on me. I played against AI and read about it off and on during 2010. a2na just got it from her Secret Santa and we enjoyed playing a game immediately afterward. I'm looking forward to playing it more with her, so realized my 5 should be a 7. :)

item.name: Owlman
item.comment: I wanted to like it more than I did. And the revised version's rule about having to count 50 turns or whatever is a turn off.

item.name: P.I.
item.comment:
Played 2-player at Essen. It's enjoyably clever as a simultaneous [gameid=2392] sort of game (disks and cubes as clues function analogously to black pegs and white pegs in Mastermind). Nice "hard boiled detective" style illustrations.
But:
* Seemingly very little interaction (other than indirect interaction of me maybe taking the card you want).
* Unhelpful graphic design. (Suspects, locations, crimes all printed with same color/font makes the cards annoyingly similar looking. The board is rather chaotic/garish/confusing looking.)
* Perhaps inevitably in a hidden info / mystery solving game, there can be a lot of luck in the guessing.
Because of it being simultaneous independent puzzle solving, we would hesitate to play it with many players and have to wait that much longer to get back to your turn.

item.name: Packeis am Pol
item.comment: Played and bought at Essen 2007-10-18. Very simple elegant pure strategy game with cute theme. At first we forgot penguins can move more than one space, and it felt like the endgame of Fjordes, and seems fine as a variant! Then playing it with full mobility made it like Yinsh or Terra Nova. (I later learned it is similar to the game Amazons, studied by combinatorial game theorists.) Quite good and plays very quickly.
item.conditiontext: Have the German "Packeis am Pol"... but the tiles & penguins have gone AWOL, leaving only the box! :(

item.name: Palago
item.comment:
Played a few times at boardspace.net, and the bots kicked my ass. It's like Trax and Spangles in that if you make one mistake, you lose, and you really need to learn some standard patterns and tactics.
Playing online and getting more and more addicted. If you like Trax, it's well worth checking out Palago; they feel very similar in spirit.
Clacky bakelite goodness with a real set!

item.name: Pandemic
item.comment: Enjoyed more than I expected, but overall I'm not much into coop games.

item.name: Panzer Grenadier: Elsenborn Ridge
item.comment:
The rules are fairly clearly written, and the game works OK, so I'm glad I tried it... but compared to some other tactical WW2 games, e.g. Combat Commander or Band of Brothers, it's slower, and for me there wasn't extra benefit for paying that price of slower play.
After playing 4 times, I paused; I don't rule out playing it again, but I personally prefer the gameplay of CC and BoB. Fighting Formations is a bit more comparable to PG (in terms of game length which I wish was shorter), but I also prefer FF's system.
I can see why some players enjoy Panzer Grenadier. E.g. the leadership system (with random leaders at the start of scenario), and the huge number of scenarios and games available in the PG system.
If you're interested in the system, check out the impressive fan site http://pg-hq.com
(Thanks, kenosha_kid.)

item.name: Paradux
item.comment: Better than I expected - looked like Yet Another Mediocre Game with marbles on wooden board at Essen, but we enjoyed playing it several times as very short filler.

item.name: Paris Connection
item.comment: Simple pleasing railroad game system where cubes can be track or shares. Sort of surprising that it has hidden shares. Surprisingly short playing time!

item.name: Pędzące żółwie
item.comment:
Fun fast filler with cute turtles and board. Sort of like Knizia's earlier Honey Bears. Looks like a random kid's game, but it's not. I've won 15 of 18 games as of now. :)
I created the [[Schildkrötenrennen FAQ]] wiki page.

item.name: Pelican Cove
item.comment: OK real-time solution-searching game. I found some of the pairs of colors a bit too confusingly similar, and the icons on some cards counter-intuitive.

item.name: Pennywise
item.comment:
We used to play this a lot in Austin years ago. Good pure strategy game! We even tried to motivate ourselves to write AI players for it as a meta-competition among ourselves, but were too lazy to do much with that. :)
Finally played again in Poland.
If you happen to have a lot of coins with you, it's a good game you can play anywhere!

item.name: Pent-Up
item.comment:
Good small short (you have 12 turns) abstract strategy stacking game, with nice chunky laser cut pieces.
Quick enough that it encourages "Best 2 out of 3" or "Just one more game". :)

item.name: Pentago
item.comment: Very simple rules, but quick to play and sometimes tactically surprising. The earlier wood edition is much more appealing to me than the newer plastic edition.

item.name: Pentalath
item.comment:
Like Yavalath, it's got very simple rules and goal. The strategy is utterly different. Easy to get too distracted by capturing (in "Go mode") and then - whoops! - the opponent can't be stopped from making 5 in a row!
The small board (size 5 hexhex) makes us wonder if it might get repetitive but a dozen games in, we're still exploring and seeing lots of variety in how it plays out.
Try the pie rule since starting on the center seems powerful.
2012-06-05: UPDATE: Playing on the trapezoidal board instead of the hexhex board is an interesting change! http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/811876/published-with-its-original-board
Also there's more subtlety to the timing issues of capturing than meets the eye. It can take nontrivial time to capture and remove "dead" stones, and that time can be important! That aspect reminds me of the frequent race situations in Havannah.

item.name: Pente
item.comment: A childhood classic I'd not played in years, until someone reintroduced me to it at the European Go Congress in 2007. A nice game, playable with Go equipment.
item.conditiontext: I own a Go set, therefore I can play Pente.

item.name: Phoenicia
item.comment: Interesting new sort of eurogame I got to play at a con and would enjoy trying again.

item.name: Phutball
item.comment: Somewhat classic (in the combinatorial game literature) abstract strategy game. Very simple rules, not so obvious strategy. I successfully taught it to a little kid, who later taught her mom. :)

item.name: Pick & Pack
item.comment:
Played at BGG.CON 2007 and came very close to buying it. Nice 2-player pure strategy, with special action chrome.
2010-12-07: Thanks, Secret Santa!

item.name: PiFroG
item.comment: Asymmetrical checkers-like game. Seems like the pigs are stronger than the frogs, and the "kids game" art was a turnoff for us both.

item.name: Pikemen
item.comment: This classic icehouse pyramid game is much more classically chess-like than Martian chess. Its non-chess-like twist is that you can only move a piece in the direction it's pointing. And such a prone piece is vulnerable to being attacked, unlike a standing piece (which can only be attacked by a larger piece). Nice classic-feeling game!

item.name: The Pillars of the Earth
item.comment: First played 2007-08-15, Polish edition "Filary Ziemi". Very archtypically "euro-ish" with various subsystems for earning points and special abilities and such.

item.name: Pinguin-Party
item.comment: Fast simple fun filler card game. Good for a con, very easy to to teach and short playing time. Doesn't seem very deep, but there are important decisions to make nonetheless.

item.name: Pirate's Cove
item.comment:
At least with 5 players, it seemed way too random. The lucky players who don't pick the same destination as other players get a nice advantage. Once a couple players get damaged in combat, it is hard for them to reequip. We had several with damaged cannons, so they always lost in combat to the stronger opponents, and could never get their cannons high again.
If you want a pirate game, I recommend [gameid=22287] or (less explicitly about pirates) [gameid=826].

item.name: PitchCar Mini
item.comment: 2007-08-28 played first time in Gumowa Róża. I'm not very good at flicky dexterity games, but it's kind of silly fun and doesn't last too long.

item.name: PIX
item.comment:
The basic concept of using low-resolution pixel art to give clues is fun.
But it suffers from the problems of all such "Password" style games:
1. You need to guess the exact word. This can sometimes get annoying (e.g. distinction between singular and plural or other variations). It also raises practical problems if not all players are equally fluent in the language of the printed cards. (E.g. me playing with a set of cards translated to Polish.)
2. Someone who knows the clue cards (e.g. the game's owner) will have an obvious advantage in guessing.
The original edition's box is an inconvenient cube shape. Apparently later editions come in a more standard portable flat box.
For me, it's an OK filler to play at a game conventions, but nothing I'd actively seek out.

item.name: Playing With Pyramids
item.comment: If you're into the pyramids, this book is well worth owning. Besides having a nice printed bound set of the rules, it also has some strategy notes and historical info.

item.name: Plutonian Poker
item.comment: Interesting pure strategy game of assembling "poker hands" (out of pyramids).

item.name: Pojedynek Robotów
item.comment:
VERY minimalist clever Shogi variant! Surprisingly interesting and diverse ways it can play out, given the tiny board (3x4) and tiny number of pieces (4 per player). Ultimately a sort of "shogi filler", but fun.
If you like it, I also recommend checking out [gameid=28389] (5x5) and [gameid=141467] (5x6) which are also small but more open and strategic and varied than this 3x4 variant.

item.name: Polowanie na Robale
item.comment:
Appealing attractive clacky tiles with cute worm art. Silly fun lucky push-your-luck game. Enjoyable fluffy filler that rewards a little number-crunching but is still very lucky.
Update: 2012, decided to trade for it in Math Trade and we're having silly fun with it. Also easy to teach to less serious gamers.

item.name: Ponte del Diavolo
item.comment: A nice discovery at BGG.CON 2009. I'd wanted to play for a long time, finally got the chance. a2na and I both like it.
item.wishlistcomment: We enjoyed it at BGG.CON.

item.name: Portobello Market
item.comment: We played the pure strategy version and enjoyed it, and got our butts kicked by a more experienced player. But felt a little like a collection of arbitrary mechanics lacking some central spark. Need to play more to decide how much I like it, and to try it with 2 players.

item.name: Power Grid: Australia & Indian Subcontinent
item.comment:
India: resource buying is a bit tedious but an interesting change of pace.
Australia: the uranium mines are an interesting twist. And that there is a 20-cost connection between every pair of cities.

item.name: Power Grid: Brazil/Spain & Portugal
item.comment: 2010-12-07: Thanks, Secret Santa!

item.name: Power Grid: China/Korea
item.comment:
The 2 Korea markets are interesting! Have played it now with 2 and with 6 players, and it works at both extremes. :)
China is quite different, with a different system of power plant auctions, but has an annoying disadvantage of needing to sort all the cards to set it up for play.

item.name: Power Grid: Factory Manager
item.comment: Played obsessively during/after Pionek of December 2009. Cool clever game. Very mathy/thinky in a way I enjoy. Unfortunately fiddly setup.

item.name: Power Grid: Flux Generator
item.comment: Technically we played with this, added to the China map deck, but in fact the game ended before this power plant appeared. :)

item.name: Power Grid: France/Italy
item.comment: More maps for Power Grid! Italy can be enjoyably nasty due to the map being so long and thin, with a lot of high connection costs and more expensive starting resources.

item.name: Power Grid: Northern Europe/United Kingdom & Ireland
item.comment:
I like UK/Ireland fine. Has a no-nuke zone and a 20-connection cost to jump from one island to the other.
The Northern Europe scenario has new power plant cards to replace some existing ones in the deck, which changed the flavor of play a bit but also caused annoying tedious setup time.
Maybe if someone else in our group traditionally set up the deck, I wouldn't mind it as much. :)

item.name: Power Grid: Russia & Japan
item.comment:
Received from a2na as birthday gift 2011!
Japan map is interesting with the 6 start cities where 2 players can start, the cities with only 2 houses, and the ability to make 2 independent networks.

item.name: Power Grid: The First Sparks
item.comment: It's kind of like Power Grid, yet different, and significantly shorter (in time and in number of turns). We borrowed it for a weekend and played intensely, enjoying it fine.

item.name: Power Grid: The Robots
item.comment:
After playing a half dozen 2-player games plus a robot, I definitely recommend the robots expansion to make 2-player games [i]much[/i] better, for those times when you don't have multiple human opponents. There is quite a lot of cool interesting variety in the various robot powers. Good fun! One time the robot even won. :)
You can also play with more than one robot player, but that can get confusing and bog things down.
It is also fun to add a robot to a "normal" game with e.g. 4 human players.
And even possible (unofficially) to enjoy playing solitaire: one human vs several robots.
====
A disappointing problem with this expansion is that some of the robot rules are too unclear/ambiguous (e.g. does "cheapest resource" refer to the cost of a single such resource or the cost for as many of them as a given plant needs; etc) and there are various ambiguous or unspecified situations which arise. And unlike some Power Grid expansion, the publisher/author don't seem as actively answering questions in this expansion's forum. :(
So players will need to apply "common sense" and check the rules forum and agree how to interpret some things. :/
This prompted me to create the BGG wiki page [[Power Grid: The Robots FAQ]] which should contain all the collected wisdom from the rules forum.

item.name: Power Grid: Transformer Station
item.comment: Acquired at BGG.CON 2009? Or Essen? - discovered tucked into old BGG.CON stuff 2011-04-07. Whee! :)

item.name: Powerboats
item.comment:
Nicely done racing game with clever acceleration 3-sided dice system. Nicely done modular maps and flexible race course design, plastic boats, cheesy cardstock buoys that fall apart and fall over. We all enjoyed it but also all felt like it's not the kind of game that makes you want to play it again right away.
After my 2nd game 3 months later, I think I want to like it more than I do. The system is too catastrophic in the sense that a random difference of one die point often has huge consequences. I wonder if I'd like it more if it was a pure strategy game, in which you choose your dice rolls.

item.name: Prêt-à-Porter
item.comment:
Portal makes an economic worker placement game about the fashion industry, with art of women in pretty dresses instead of zombies and mutants shooting each other?! :)
Played once at Pionek 2010-12-04, and we enjoyed it a lot. Good serious game, well worth checking out. We hope to play more, even though the Polish card text slowed me down a lot. But I think with more experience I will know the cards pretty easily anyway. As usual in a game with lots of cards with special actions (especially from Portal) there are various murky rule ambiguities...
Played several more times and continued to enjoy, although it's longer and more complex than my preferred type these days (and has that element of "everyone has various special cards that do special stuff in their tableau and you should keep it all in mind if you want to play well" which I find I'm not so fond of, e.g. in extreme cases like La Havre). But the core system works fine and is enjoyable.
The 2011 Essen release version apparently improves the rules, definitely improves the board layout problems, and supposedly makes the cards non-text-dependent with icons which clearly represent what they do. I've not tried this version yet but heard positive comments from some who have.
2012-01-09: Gave 2nd edition to Anna for Xmas (delivery delays).

item.name: Przez Pustynię
item.comment: One of my favorite Knizia games. Very elegant, similar to the endgame of Go, quite nice for 2 players, and also with more. A bit of a fiddly setup, though.
item.conditiontext: I have the Polish version "Przez Pustynię".

item.name: Puerto Rico
item.comment: Used to play this long ago in my Austin group when it first appeared. Then didn't play for many years, finally played again 2012-12-02, and enjoyed it again. A modern classic indeed.

item.name: PÜNCT
item.comment: This connection game feels less simple and elegant than the other Gipf games, due to variously shaped pieces and slightly more fiddly rules. But at least it's not real-time like Tamsk.
item.wishlistcomment: We have the other 5 GIPF series games. We didn't get PUNCT since it's less elegant and was our least favorite, but I've played it more and start to like it, although a2na's still not into it, alas.

item.name: Pylos
item.comment:
After seeing it and for some reason not being interested for many years, I finally played it in the logical games tournament at [[Pionek]] 2008-11-29 and was impressed. Interesting elegant game!
Now we own it (as of Christmas 2008) and play it a lot. It's short enough that we want to play "just one more". It [i]seems[/i] so simple, yet often surprises. The strategy remains subtle and nonobvious as I keep losing more than my fair share. :)

item.name: Pyramidion
item.comment: Enjoyable, a bit fiddly in terms of various types of tokens and cards and locations doing various types of things. For a euro in an Egyptian setting, I prefer Egizia, but Pyramidion is also interesting.

item.name: Quads Magnetic
item.comment:
Got to play once at Pionek 2008-06-07. Surprisingly interesting (the fancy packaging and components made me wonder if it was going to be more flash than substance). Now I read it's an early Kris Burm design. No wonder the gameplay was interesting! :)
The gameplay is different from Burm's more well-known Gipf series, which mostly have a small number of types of pieces. In Quads, every piece is unique. In a sense that feels less elegant to me, but I still like the game!
A placement game - in a loose sense analogous to Blokus (each player has their own set of diverse unique pieces to place).
2008-12-12: Thanks, Secret Santa! :)

item.name: Quantum Leap
item.comment:
Enjoyable game of "keep moving (jumping onto enemy pieces to replace them) until you lose by not having a move", where the number of spaces a piece moves is equal to the number of friendly neighbors (so an isolated piece is immobile, at least temporarily).
The movement rule feels very natural and elegant, yet not used much in other games that I'm aware of. Feels sort of like TZAAR meets Lines of Action, but not really. :)

item.name: Quarto!
item.comment:
Some criticize it for being a sequence of mysterious moves until suddenly you can read ahead and see how to win (or that you're doomed to lose), but I find that entertaining. Plus it's quick to play.
It is fun to play with the advanced rule that a 2x2 square also wins, not just 4-in-a-row. And then to play that ANY square wins.

item.name: Quebec 1759
item.comment:
Early block wargame, pretty simple rules and low unit count, only 12 map locations, playable in less than an hour, good intro block wargame.
But it seems quite hard for the French to win... (At least in my Columbia Games first edition set; I know later editions made some rule/unit changes.)

item.name: Queen's Necklace
item.comment: This has what I think of as Faidutti-esque elements of various special actions and luck and chaos (from simultaneous decisions with all-or-nothing results).

item.name: Quentin
item.comment: Sometimes surprising connection game where many stones can suddenly get placed at once in a "territory".

item.name: Quest for the Auburn Pelt: A PageQuest Game
item.comment:
Simple solitaire dungeon crawl. Clever map discovery and magic systems. Insanely tiny hard to read instruction text. Worth printing and trying if you like solo dungeon crawls: 10 minutes to read the rules and a half hour of questing.
Hard to rate it, since by design it has rather low replay value... :)

item.name: Quicksand
item.comment:
Good icehouse pyramid game! Sort of hybrid of ZERTZ/Pentago/Blam!
[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/537200]My review.[/url]

item.name: Quinamid
item.comment:
Similar to Pentago in terms of goal and rules (tic-tac-toe for 5 in a row with moving board squares) but more complex strategy. I liked it more than I thought I would, and found myself wanting "just one more play".
However there is a practical problem about the covered-up spaces - is Quinamid meant to be a memory game (in which case you can accidentally see hidden information when rotating levels) or not (in which case it's a pain in the ass to see what's hidden under the levels)? I was surprised that the rules are silent on this, and the designer/manufacturer hadn't thought about this issue.
item.wishlistcomment: Neat wooden abstract strategy game. It just bugs me about the rules ambiguity whether you can see spaces hidden under the levels or not. :)

item.name: Quincunx
item.comment: More complex baroque game than [gameid=42900] (which we prefer) of laying cards in a grid and scoring by looking at triples radiating out from the played card.

item.name: Quixo
item.comment:
Enjoyable short game to get 5 in a row, and very fast to learn the rules. It's sufficiently interesting that we played 8 times in a row the first time, but it doesn't seem as interesting or unique as some other Gigamic games, e.g. lacking the 3-dimensionality of Pylos and Inside.
I did notice that our early games ended quickly, with plenty of blank cubes still in play, then we got better and entered a sort of next phase of play with all the blank cubes gone, or only in the interior, and the feel of the game shifts then. That was cool.
But it feels like just waiting for the opponent to make a blunder. Maybe my rating will change with more plays and experience and insight.

item.name: Quoridor
item.comment:
Often has surprising radical changes in the board situation due to clever wall placement.
It is best as a pure 2-player strategy game.
I've played it 4-player and found it more amusing than I recalled from long ago, despite it being less strategic and more diplomatic. But 2-player is still best.
2008-11-30: Anna won it at [[Pionek]] for third place in the Neuroshima Hex tournament!

item.name: Qwirkle
item.comment: A nice Scrabble-like experience, without the debates about whether a word is legal or not!

item.name: R
item.comment:
Very short small fun filler game of simultaneously deciding which card to play until someone has won 4 card pairs, thus it's a game of psychology + luck + calculation. It gets an admirably clever high amount of mileage from 2 identical decks of only 8 cards!
A game can be over in 2 minutes, so it seems like one often might want to play a series of games, not just one.

item.name: Racing Dwarfs
item.comment:
Fun little maze/race game. The setup phase is a bit long and (perhaps not obvious at first) very important strategically. (Perhaps like the game 9tka in that regard.)
It's easy to achieve or even start with multiple clear routes connecting opposite sides, so blocking is a crucial tactic! I.e. it's not "just" a race, but includes a lot of jockeying for position and deciding when is the right time to exit a dwarf, because once you've exited a dwarf, you become weaker on the board (you have less ability to block)! In that sense, it reminds me of YINSH, where you have to remove 3 rings to win, but each ring you remove makes you weaker on the board.
Several steps of "aha"-experience in our first few games. :)
The 3-player game of course, like many such games e.g. Quoridor, has the anomaly that 2 players face each other while the 3rd faces a neutral side.

item.name: Rail/Road
item.comment: Played at Essen 2008. Sort of like Cathedral, Blokus, Rumis, etc, you want to play as many of your pieces as possible. As in Cathedral, captures are possible, and more harshly. The rules had a little bit of unclearness, but the intent seemed clear. Enjoyable, but not as pretty as Cathedral, Blokus, Rumis.

item.name: Railroad Dice 2
item.comment: Clever odd game that blends 18xx style track and train buying with random dice luck. Enjoyable and strangely appealing, although it seemed fiddly and long given the randomness. I suspect it will go faster if I play more and get more experienced though.

item.name: RAMbots
item.comment: I used to play a lot of RoboRally, and now I prefer RAMbots. RAMbots doesn't risk dragging on too long, and its rules are more pleasing and elegant. Both give the fun core experience of "program your robots and then they run automatically, amusingly messing with each other in unexpected ways, and amusingly sometimes simply misprogrammed by their owners".

item.name: Rancho
item.comment: Educational math game for kids, fun building up your herd of animals, but certainly rather random...

item.name: Rancho
item.comment: Educational math game for kids, fun building up your herd of animals, but certainly rather random...

item.name: Rattus
item.comment: Seemed too chaotic/random for our taste. The sequel Rattus Cartus was more appealing and interesting for us.

item.name: Rattus Cartus
item.comment: Seems more interesting and less chaotic/random than original Rattus. We both liked it more than original Rattus.

item.name: Realm
item.comment: A family of games - rules for various games using the same board and pieces. We've so far explored only the main/standard game. Weird fiddly rules to wrap one's head around with some non-obvious strategy! Still not entirely sure what I think of it!

item.name: RED
item.comment:
Short fun abstract strategy tile placement. Works for 2 or 3 players, easy to teach, thus a good filler with new players, yet remains interesting for more experienced players.
New players may have trouble visualizing the overlapping regions of same-colored circles and same-colored squares. Multiply the sizes of your 2 largest circle and square regions, so overall strategy is clear, another plus for impromptu games with newbies: you want to increase both your circles and squares roughly equally rather than increasing one a lot. E.g. 8*8=64 is better than 4*12=48. It's not highly deep, but for a nice 10 or 15 minute game it presents sufficiently interesting tactics and strategy.
As we gained experience, ties became more common in 2-player games.
The tiles are not quite as nice as in most nestorgames: different colors have slightly different thicknesses, the circles are not always centered correctly, but that doesn't really affect play.

item.name: Reds! The Russian Civil War 1918-1921
item.comment: The theme appeals. The rules have too many annoying holes and there's no publisher or author support here in the forum, alas. So far, played once solo to try it out. Realistically, it looks unlikely I'll convince someone else to learn and play it with me, as there are shorter and easier to learn wargames. :/

item.name: Ricochet Pyramids
item.comment: My Looney pyramid version of Ricochet Robots... We enjoy it. :)

item.name: Ricochet Robots
item.comment: Normally I suck at games with realtime competition and don't enjoy them, but this one finally grabbed me. It's very satisfying to find a long complex route.
item.wishlistcomment:
One of the few real time games I enjoy and am even a decent player at...
...but now I've invented Ricochet Pyramids, which we enjoy just as much. :)

item.name: Risk Express
item.comment: Cute fun filler dice push-your-luck game with Risk theme.

item.name: Robber Knights
item.comment: Got it at BGG.CON 2009. Nice quick little tile-laying game! I also like the tile art. Need to play more to see how much I like it, but we both enjoyed the first play.

item.name: Robot Master
item.comment: Quick little tile placement game with nice big chunky cardstock tiles with robots on them, in a nice small portable box. Some strategy, and a fair amount of luck. Only played the 4-player partners version. I don't normally like partner games, but this was short and sweet, so I thought it was OK.

item.name: Rocket Shogi
item.comment: Fun small Shogi variant on 5x7 board with all piece types except pawn (unusually!)

item.name: RÖK
item.comment: A real time and dexterity game, neither of which I'm into. Sort of like Jungle Speed, but with neater looking components (smooth rocks with runes carved into them). A marginal bit of strategy as you occasionally have to make an obvious decision.

item.name: Roma
item.comment:
OK/interesting, but not great. It seems more random than I'd expect from a Stefan Feld game!
Also a nontrivial barrier to entry is constantly having to look up what the many different cards do in the first few games.

item.name: RRR
item.comment: Cool clever game! Perfect information game, but with fantasy art and various units with special powers, giving a euro or ameritrash vibe. The basic rules are really simple, the game plays in a short time, and the random 5 neutral cards give high replay value through variety.

item.name: Rumis
item.comment: Great game for teaching to newbies and nongamers, yet also rewards serious tactical planning. Pure strategy for 2, yet also works fine with 3 or 4!

item.name: Rummikub
item.comment: Enjoyable popular family game.

item.name: Rune Age
item.comment:
Sort of Dominion with combat... Fun, and nice that it has 4 different scenarios (defeat a tough enemy to win, kill opponents to win, get rich enough to build a monument to win, and even a coop scenario where you must all survive until the event deck runs out to win). 4 different factions with their own units with special actions. So plenty of diverse gameplay. Quick game, rarely more than a half hour.
The rulebook is sometimes sloppily written, so I was motivated to create [[Rune Age FAQ]].

item.name: Sabotażysta
item.comment: Played 2007-05-29. At first I thought it was cool, then I started to feel like it had too much chaos. The map building with secret saboteurs is a fun idea at least.

item.name: Saint Malo
item.comment:
It is ultimately a fancy version of Yahtzee. Fun in a solitaire kind of way, but too long (and complex!) for what it is, and it dragged on way too long with 5 players. The only apparent interaction is in the choice of whether to accelerate or decelerate the arrival of pirates.
Dry erase markers on the board seemed weird to me, like they were just saving costs by not giving you the various physical bits which would normally come in a game like this.
Very good art though! Everyone I played with seemed sincerely pleased with the art.

item.name: Saint Petersburg
item.comment:
This was insanely popular in my Austin group, and I was glad to finally get a chance to play it again, during Essen 2006.
Played a few times in Poland, then got our own copy in Polish Math Trade #4 (2010-03)

item.name: Salamanca
item.comment: 2008-08-26 played with 5 players. Interesting weird game. I like the gimmick of passing the card you played to the player on the left each round. The map and scoring stuff seems typical and works fine. I'll happily try it some more, and am curious if it really works with 2 players as claimed.

item.name: Samarkand: Routes to Riches
item.comment: Sort of a more elegant non-train-themed "Chicago Express", but with random card draws and hidden info. The ending can come quick, leaving you without time to gain points you thought were (effectively) going to be yours, same as in "Through the Desert", which it also reminds of.

item.name: Samurai
item.comment: A Knizia classic. We used to play this a bunch in Austin years ago. Nice abstract strategy (with a few euro-ish special effect tiles thrown in) with strangely cool appealing shiny black pieces made of some mysterious alien carapace. Place your tiles to gain control of the pieces of alien carapace in Japanese cities. The final scoring is wonky and weird in an interesting Knizia way. (Watch out for different rules versions about what happens if nobody has the most of a figure type: no winner, or most total pieces wins.)
item.conditiontext: Won at Pionek, June 2008 by a2na for winning the logical games tournament.

item.name: San Marco
item.comment: First played 2007-04-09. Vaguely reminds me of Web of Power. Gorgeous map. The core cardplay mechanism of splitting into groups which other players pick from is cool and makes for some very interesting tough decisions. Annoying misdesign on corners of score track. The expel action seems too wildly random compared to all the other actions, which are completely deterministic, but I still like the game.

item.name: Santiago
item.comment: Very cool game - elegant and dry and strategic, neat auction system, neat tile placement and scoring, but it needs 3-5 players. If it also worked 2-player, a2na and I would own it. No wait, we [i]do[/i] own it, thanks to a2na's 2011 Secret Santa! Yay! :)

item.name: Sator Arepo Tenet Opera Rotas
item.comment: Looks gorgeous, plays fun, has a famous Latin palindrome for its title... but it seems too chaotic and inelegant for me. Possibly I might enjoy it more with more plays.

item.name: Scho K.O.
item.comment: More streamlined than its sibling game Schokoly. Both are tile placement games where you want a large region of your color. Random draw makes it less appealing to me than similar pure abstract strategy games. But the pieces are delicious looking. :)

item.name: Schotten-Totten
item.comment:
Very nice short tactical card game!
I created the [[Schotten-Totten FAQ]] wiki page.
item.conditiontext: Dutch version, bought during our visit to Amsterdam in July 2008.

item.name: Schwarze Löcher
item.comment: It didn't grab us in our one play. Not bad but not exciting. Tactical maneuvering to roll the blocks into pits was initially opaque until we got the hang of it, and then it was just a race. I can imagine there being deeper strategy to it, but it didn't grab us enough to try a second game, alas.

item.name: Schweinebande
item.comment: OK light game that I wanted to be more tactical, but it has a bit too much randomness. Cute art and barnyard theme.

item.name: Score Four
item.comment: Surprisingly fun 4x4x4 hybrid of Tic-tac-toe and Connect 4... We were staying at a mountain lodge that had a nice wooden hand-made set. We thought it would be a trivial game (analogous to 3x3x3 Tic-tac-toe), but the need for 4 in a row combined with the gravity of dropping the disks to the lower level in a column seems to make it sufficiently interesting.

item.name: Scotland Yard
item.comment:
Finally played it 2008-02-28 after hearing about it for years. Enjoyed it, but it didn't live up to my over-inflated expectations.
Elegant rule system. Pure strategy except for the player-induced chaos/randomness of hidden movement. One can and should think carefully.
I'm not so into the team-vs-one aspect. For the detectives to win, they really need to cooperate and plan carefully as if they were one player running a set of detectives, while I tend to think of team games as a bit lighter and more social. It's also more abstract/dry than Mr. Jack (another chase-themed game).

item.name: Scrabble
item.comment:
I've played the Polish version since moving to Poland. On 2007-04-07 I actually won a game, thanks in large part to "marszową" on a triple word score.
Now we own an English set and a Polish set.

item.name: Seeräuber
item.comment:
Clever little game. Need to play more to form more of a firm opinion. Pretty chaotic with 5 players, but otherwise not a highly random game intrinsically, just the random revealing of ship cards. Played 2008-06-12.
Played again 2008-09-02 with 5, enjoyed again!
Played the German version Seeräuber. (Pirates)

item.name: SET
item.comment: I suck at most of these games where everyone tries to rapidly find something at the same time. (The main exception is Ricochet Robots.)

item.name: Set Cubed
item.comment: The supplied rules are surprisingly lame: vague/ambiguous and not a very interesting game, especially given that the original Set has such clear elegant rules. Hopefully we'll find or create a more interesting game to play with the neat dice.

item.name: The Settlers of Catan: The Fishermen of Catan
item.comment: More complicating chrome. Played once; it wasn't bad, but I prefer basic Settlers of Catan.

item.name: SEVEN
item.comment:
Good small short (you only have 7 turns!) abstract strategy stacking game, with nice chunky laser cut pieces.
Quick enough that it encourages "Best 2 out of 3" or "Just one more game". :)

item.name: Shear Panic
item.comment:
First played 2008-08-08. Mostly combinatorial game, but with random dice roll occasionally which is mildly displeasing to me. Need to play more to get a better idea of how much I like it. Seems like multiplayer is too chaotic.
I have played the Polish edition "Owczy Pęd".

item.name: Sheep, Dogs and Wolves
item.comment: Enjoyable quick filler abstract. I'm not sure I feel much long-term strategy in it, but it has some fun tactics.

item.name: Shipyard
item.comment:
Played it obsessively for a while, but burned out on it a bit. Also a bit too fiddly for my taste. But it is well worth checking out, especially if you like fiddly games, as it's got some neat ideas in it.
I'm undecided on the controversy about whether certain contracts are too good and inject too much luck into the game.

item.name: Shogi
item.comment:
Truly excellent classic centuries-old strategy game. Similar to familiar International Chess, yet also very different.
Being able to drop captured pieces back onto the board [i]really[/i] changes things in an interesting good way. And most pieces can be promoted, not just pawns.
After years of thinking about Shogi from afar, procrastinating due to the initial kanji learning hurdle, I finally bought a set in late 2011 and was pleasantly surprised how quickly we got used to the kanji. We started with [gameid=28389] to get used to the kanji and basic tactics, and then soon started enjoying full Shogi. For learning, there are in fact multiple small board variants using subsets of the pieces, all worth trying out.
Of possible interest: [geeklist=196102][/geeklist]
===
There are various variations of the pieces (e.g. with 1 or 2 kanji symbols; with red or black symbols on the promoted side; with neat regular "printed" kanji or less legible sloppy "hand-written" kanji; slightly different symbols in printed diagrams in problems and strategy articles)... This is an annoying barrier to entry for people who don't know kanji already. (Imagine if International Chess pieces were all just tiles with the English words "pawn", "king", "rook", "knight" etc printed on them, and different sets used different typefaces and handwriting styles, and sometimes printed "tower" and "horse" instead of "rook" and "knight", and you were someone who didn't already know the Latin alphabet...)
Too bad, because Shogi is great and deserves more attention! Instead, it remains less well-known than Chess (outside of Japan), in contrast with Go (which does not have this technical barrier to entry, its pieces being simply black and white stones). And so you usually need to mail-order shogi books & equipment instead of seeing them in most local bookstores and game stores.
But it's worth it. Great game. :)

item.name: Show Business
item.comment:
Very thematic atomospheric ameritrash/euro hybrid about the music industry, in which the creator has professional experience, and it shows. Lots of rules subsystems are more fiddly than I prefer, and the art is love-it-or-hate-it garish. But if you like medium to heavy economic games with a good strong sense of theme, well worth checking out.
I revised the English rules for Grzegorz.

item.name: Sicic
item.comment: Try to move your stars into a specific pattern. Mildly interesting tactically, but not particularly exciting.

item.name: Siege Master
item.comment: Interesting clever odd abstract strategy placement game.

item.name: SiegeStones
item.comment: Played a few times during IJF. Quick and clever idea, nice attractive bits. But the game play was ultimately not so exciting to us. At least it does indeed seem to work fine with 2-4 players, though of course (as in all such games) it's more purely strategic with 2.

item.name: Simple Shogi
item.comment:
Simple Shogi is extremely small, 3x5 and 4 pieces per player like Dobutsu = Let's Catch the Lion, but Simple Shogi uses standard Shogi pieces and rules, so is arguably better for learning the basics of Shogi.
It's unusual among Shogi variants for having players start with 2 of their pieces in hand, instead of all pieces on the board.

item.name: Six
item.comment: Sort of [gameid=11893] meets [gameid=2759] meets [gameid=2655]...

item.name: Skull & Roses
item.comment: Similar sort of bluffing game to [gameid=11971] or [gameid=45]. Fast short fun filler.

item.name: Skurðir
item.comment:
Neat! Skurðir is an abstract Age of Steam, similar to how Homeworlds is an abstract Twilight Imperium. :)
Like in Age of Steam, you want long convoluted routes, and most of the goods/passengers start on the map so you can imagine long-term strategy and route-planning from the beginning. Unlike those games, Skurðir is playable in a half hour or so.
One minor drawback is that it can be a pain computing the payout costs on long routes with lots of colors on the way.

item.name: Skybridge
item.comment: The rules seem unclear (are bridges and roofs "blocks"? 2-player using 2 colors is ambiguous about whether you must play on the lowest level possible, or on the lowest level possible for the color block you choose to play). Bummer. Usually Gigamic rules are clearer. Based on the rules supplied, we're not impressed. Possibly there's a good game here if we learn how it's intended to be played.

item.name: Slither
item.comment: Enjoyable connection game with a twist, that you may move a piece to an adjacent square in addition to the usual placing of a new piece. This plus the restriction about diagonal connections makes for some learning curve and aha-effects because not all experience from other connection games necessarily applies here. :)

item.name: Small World
item.comment: Enjoyable, but not as exciting as it was hyped to be.
item.wishlistcomment: Garish art and silly theme turned us off, but I did rather enjoy the game play and feel a bit of nostalgia for it.

item.name: Snow Tails
item.comment: Like most race games, there's no deep strategy, and I'm not sure how often I want to play it, but it was surprisingly clever and elegant, and I enjoyed the first game.

item.name: Soluna
item.comment:
Playing this, I thought "This seems like [gameid=7553]", then I come to BGG and see that it is a reimplementation indeed. :)
The varied random setups are nice. Pretty wooden pieces.
It's another of those games where the beginning feels opaque, but near the end you can read ahead with certainty and see "Player X wins". (But I have read that there is some known algorithm which solves Babylon.)
Nice quick filler. Seemed pricey for what it is, though.

item.name: Soviet Dawn: The Russian Civil War, 1918-1921
item.comment:
The "State of Siege" system never quite appealed to me as it seemed too random sounding, but I got the C3i magazine with this game (nice production quality, by the way) and darned if the game isn't addictive "just one more" fun! It can be over quite quickly if luck goes against you (e.g. in just a few minutes), but it's so easy to set up and just play "one more".
I'm interested in the Russian Revolution, so this was the State of Siege game that sounded most appealing to me. The game has lots of historical flavor on the cards, and a good accompanying historical article if you have the C3i issue edition. Pretty clear well-written short rules. (I created [[Soviet Dawn FAQ]] to cover a few common questions.)

item.name: Space Alert
item.comment: Played the 2 introductory scenarios, in suboptimal conditions (noisy room, Petr had to listen to the soundtrack on his personal music gadget and tell us what it was saying). I admire the clever system and the programming of crew actions. I'm not in the target audience, since I'm not a fan of real time games nor of cooperative games! But I am glad I finally tried it, just to see what all the fuss is about.

item.name: Space Dealer
item.comment:
Only played once 2007-09-11. I don't generally like real-time games, and in a game with various fiddly rules, the real-time pressure makes it especially chaotic for first-time players. It seemed OK for that sort of thing, and it was fun to try once to see what the hype was all about, but I feel no urge to play it again.
A practical problem is that the sand timers didn't all run for the same amount of time, which seems an inherent problem with any game that depends on multiple sand timers owned by players, like this or Tamsk.

item.name: Space Empires: 4X
item.wishlistcomment: Sounds cool except potentially too long to get to the table with my current batch of wargame friends.

item.name: Spaiji
item.comment: The game doesn't last many turns, only 15 turns total (placing 2 balls each turn until 30 are placed). A small mistake can be fatal, it seems, as it seems a player can get all their balls connected, so missing even one can be a game-losing problem.

item.name: Spangles
item.comment:
Similar style "place tiles in an unbounded grid to achieve a pattern" to David Smith's Andantino and his more famous Trax. This one is distilled down to a really minimalistic ruleset, both the placement rule and the goal!
Interesting how we find it harder to see patterns on a triangle grid; we are so used to playing games on square grids and hex grids, but triangle grids are quite uncommon.
The nestorgames edition has pleasing laser-cut tiles which have amusingly sharp corners and edges, like 50 little weapons. I'd almost be afraid to fly with the game in the US for fear the insane TSA would confiscate the sharp-cornered pieces. :)

item.name: Spanish Checkers
item.comment: Seems to be equivalent to International Checkers on 8x8 instead of 10x10 (and unpromoted pieces can not capture backwards as in International Checkers). Flying kings certainly seem to make the game more fast and decisive than English Checkers.

item.name: Spargo
item.comment:
Odd go variant with square pyramid stacking. The rules seem an elegant natural extension of go to this environment, yet they are a bit hard to wrap one's head around somehow, and the strategic/tactical implications of the stacking are surprising! Add to that the weirdness of playing on the tiny 4x4 grid instead of a larger grid (as the original Margo proposes).
Like go on drugs. :)

item.name: Spava
item.comment: Nice Shibumi version of Yavalath plus a neutral color.

item.name: Sphex
item.comment: Nifty connection game. Decide dynamically which pair of opposite sides you will connect. The 4x4 board makes it short and probably not deep, but it's a good Shibumi filler!

item.name: Spight
item.comment:
Slightly counterintuitive rules, although clearly written, just confusing to apply initially.
Unfortunately it looks very probable that the first player has a huge advantage (jump up onto the center platform).

item.name: Splice
item.comment: Cool game to play after some experience with [gameid=93164]. Various fun aha-effects due to the altered rules with addition of the red balls!

item.name: Spline
item.comment:
Good simple quick 3-dimensional n-in-a-row game!
[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/716977]My review.[/url]

item.name: Spline+
item.comment: Good n-in-a-row game and variant of [gameid=93164]. Being able to move balls makes it feel a little bit like Pylos, but with the freedom to move not only to a higher level.

item.name: Sploof
item.comment:
Another nice little Shibumi game with a couple of uncommon-to-Shibumi mechanisms (the personal stock you must replenish occasionally and the 4-in-a-row as viewed from above).
The PDF rules v1.1 doesn't clarify that you can remove a red ball that supports one other ball, but the BGG wiki description does.
[url=https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/1378175/]My review.[/url]

item.name: Spoing
item.comment: More opaque for me than Spline and Splice, but another quick simple Shibumi filler well worth trying if you have the components!

item.name: Spooky Stairs
item.comment: Basically a kid's game, with a clever magnetic mechanical system for hiding information to make it basically a memory game of which ghost cone your pawn is under, but fun as a silly quick filler with the right group.

item.name: Spot it Jr.! Animals
item.comment:
It has fewer cards and fewer symbols (which are all animals) on cards, to make it easier for kids. But several animals look too similar (e.g. dolphin and shark and whale all have a very similar shape and blue color), which seems counter to the goal of making it easier for kids.
Still, I guess kids would enjoy it OK. For me (an adult), it's OK for a change of pace, but I liked it less than regular/original Dobble / Spot It.
Maybe I'm just used to the original art? But I liked Loonacy (similar game) fine, despite it having different art from Dobble / Spot It.

item.name: Spree
item.comment: Impartial Quarto-like game.

item.name: Squava
item.comment:
As a 5x5 2-player game, it seems quite small/quick.
Tried 8x8 3-player, it seems to work more interestingly analogous to original Yavalath.

item.name: Stack Control
item.comment:
Good icehouse pyramid game! Sort of like DVONN/Focus.
[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/538203]My review.[/url]

item.name: Star Borders: Aliens
item.comment:
Fun little science fiction wargame with a variety of different-feeling scenarios, typically playable in an hour.
This worthy sequel/expansion to [gameid=86406] adds 2 alien races each with their own feel.
I helped playtest & proofread both Star Borders: Humanity and Aliens.

item.name: Star Borders: Humanity
item.comment:
Fun little science fiction wargame with a variety of different-feeling scenarios, typically playable in an hour.
Now that the physically nicer 2nd edition with laser cut counters is available, there's probably little incentive to buy the 1st edition.
item.wishlistcomment: A simple half-hour playable Imperium-like game?

item.name: Star Borders: Humanity
item.comment:
Fun little science fiction wargame with a variety of different-feeling scenarios, typically playable in an hour.
The laser cut counters and mounted boards of this 2nd edition are nicer than the 1st edition. The rules have more chrome, e.g. cloaking ships, flagships, planetary fortifications and assault, etc.
I helped playtest & proofread Star Borders.

item.name: Stawvs
item.comment: I designed & playtested it with various people during a time I was quite interested in pyramid games and also playing Amazons a lot. If you enjoy games like Amazons or Hey That's My Fish, I think this is worth trying. We still enjoy playing it. :)

item.name: Stax
item.comment: A little bit like Hive (perhaps with some DNA from Pikemen) at first glance, but also significantly different! Cool game. Every hex-shaped piece is a unique combination of arrows from 0 to 6, and pieces can only move in one of the 6 directions in which they have an arrow pointing.

item.name: Steam
item.comment:
Wow, we liked it more than we thought we would, after hearing how it was some devolved version of Age of Steam. We played with the full AoS style auction system. The chance-free production system seems better! The tile-laying costs do seem more elegant, once Petr pointed out the unifying logic behind them.
However we found the hieroglyphic role tiles to be annoying and hard to get used to, and the map's naturalistic art is prettier but provably less functional (as Macike got confused over whether a certain hex was mountain or not). Nice that it comes with 2 standard maps instead of 1. Need to play some more.
I have read various of the criticisms, and some seem valid:
1. Steam is more tactical and has less long-term planning because of the new production rules. 2. Steam's urbanization may be too powerful. 3. Issuing shares seems less costly, and possibly creates a runaway leader problem as a result of the ability to keep raising cash by issue shares once you're out of the hole and always win the auction while other players struggle to have cash. 4. The split VP/income tracks means whoever starts earning VPs first will probably win the game, and that ultimately only the final runs matter for victory. In AoS all of your runs have some direct effect on your score in the end. 5. Points for links instead of track removes minor tactics of building more track for points, using engineer, and urbanizing to cost someone track points. It seems done only to save time in scoring.
Maybe the best option is simply to play AoS with insta-production like from the London map?

item.name: Stein im Brett
item.comment: For this kind of game where you're placing multiple pieces of you and your opponents, I'd prefer no randomness, e.g. something like Omega. But for a lighter version of such games, this is nicely done with good bits, and I enjoyed it fine.

item.name: Stephensons Rocket
item.comment: Played a bunch years ago - would enjoy playing again now, but I don't know anyone in Poland who owns it.
item.wishlistcomment: Good little-known luckless Knizia classic we used to play in my old game group in Austin.

item.name: Stlts
item.comment:
Played against the AI at http://www.zoo.co.uk/~z8001271/stlts/stltshome.html and it seems interesting. Vaguely reminds me of TZAAR, where you stack to be more powerful or move to capture; in Stlts you add pins to move farther or move to capture. But in Stlts a very fast piece is still capturable by any piece in range, so that's a big difference.
Unsure how much I like it. Adding a pin is normally much stronger than moving.

item.name: Stone Age
item.comment: Works well with 2-4 players. Clever worker placement game with random resource production and several diverse ways to earn victory points.

item.name: Stoner Fluxx
item.comment:
Basic game play is similar to standard Fluxx, which we seem to play more in practice. (This one has a fair amount of atmospheric stoner slang that's more of a stumbling block for non-native English speakers.) One interesting difference is that one particular keeper has many instances.
There are several cards about doing real-world actions, which is less pleasing to me in a game.
I applaud the real-world political agenda of the game and part of its proceeds.

item.name: La Strada
item.comment: Good pure strategy game with some clever ideas, including a clever mechanism to add up victory points at the end which more games should use. 2-4 players, but requires a rules tweak to work for 2, which is aesthetically displeasing to me.

item.name: Stratego
item.comment: Childhood nostalgia!

item.name: Stratopolis
item.comment:
Nice clacky L-shaped tiles with various color combinations on the 3 squares of each tile. (which don't stack quite as perfectly as they look like they should) with a Taluva-ish rule that you can cover existing tiles, if you cover at least 2, not just 1. The restriction that you can't cover one player's color with the other player's color is good and works. (There is a 3rd neutral color.)
Score = size of connected group * maximum height of the group, for your single best group.
The standard game has you play tiles in a random order. There are several variants. We were surprised there was no pure strategy variant, i.e. simply choose which piece you want (like Blokus, Quads, Zaic, etc). We tried playing with choice (no randomness) and it seems to work as well!
NOTE!!! There IS a luckless variant! It's just mistranslated into a random variant in the English [i]and[/i] Polish rules! See [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/873602/inconsistent-rules-translations-there-is-a-luckles]my thread about the mistranslated variant[/url].

item.name: StreetSmart
item.comment: Programmed movement of RoboRally combined with role selection each turn (e.g. Puerto Rico, Citadels, etc). Chaotic, fun, not too long, not too deep. (Played 3-player version twice.) Certain roles are much more useful/important than others. Nice art and physically high quality components, especially for a self-published limited edition game, but a graphic design problem in card design forces you to spread your hand of cards to see their values.

item.name: The Struggle for Catan
item.comment: I liked it more than expected! I am no longer fond of negotiation/trading games like original Settlers of Catan, and this clever card game does away with that aspect of Catan while still preserving the rest of the feel of Catan (roads, villages, cities, 5 resources, interchanging resources on the game's market, etc).
item.wishlistcomment: There is a Polish edition, which would be best for me since I would be playing mostly with Polish speakers...

item.name: Subdivision
item.comment:
A good short strategic placement game!
[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/5089512]My review.[/url]

item.name: Sultan
item.comment:
Nice bits and fast fun game play. Much random chaos from semi-simultaneous secret decisions, but it's fast enough that this doesn't bother me, and it's a clever elegant system.
[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/4495800]My review.[/url]

item.name: Sunda to Sahul
item.comment: Ordered as a gift since a2na like jigsaw puzzles also! The game definitely uses one's jigsaw puzzle pattern matching skills. Very pretty, but as a game seems a bit long and not highly compelling.

item.name: Survive: Escape from Atlantis!
item.comment: Cute idea, but a bit too random.

item.name: Symbol
item.comment:
Cool pieces, cool idea; not sure how well it comes together in practice. Also the rules are noticeably more complex and less clear than other nestorgames. The idea of having a basic version and an advanced/full version is fine in principle, but in practice it means a lot of stuff you learned must be unlearned and it was cumbersome to look up questions.
Chess skill seems useful here, as my chess-playing friend demolished me multiple times. :)
item.wishlistcomment: An interesting looking abstract strategy game with vaguely Magic The Gathering war theme.

item.name: Synapse-Ice
item.comment:
Quick little tactical game that starts out amorphous, then at some point you become able to feasibly and enjoyably read ahead to the end.
Good quick use of 2 Icehouse pyramid stashes!

item.name: Ta Yü
item.comment: Addictive tile placement track-building game. Played a lot years ago in Austin with first white-tile edition. At Essen 2007 played with new edition with cheaper-feeling plastic red tiles and new plastic board with different layout of the bonus exit points. Doesn't look as nice to me, but they improved it by having you draw from a sack, since the original rules were annoyingly unworkable with pulling tiles from a prebuilt block, since you could see the edges of the tiles and know what you were pulling.
item.wishlistcomment: The original set with the ivory colored Bakelite tiles is cool and definitely more desirable... :)

item.name: Taj Mahal
item.comment: I played this sometime years ago in Austin, then finally played again in Poland 2008-06-19 and really enjoyed it, enough to immediately propose and play a second time. The rules are a little more fiddly and less elegant than I usually prefer, but it's nonetheless a Knizia classic.

item.name: Talat
item.comment:
Looks nice at first, but didn't quite grab us in the end. Ultimately a crossing game with a small number of pieces on each board; not sure how much staying power it would have. We tried 2-player at Essen and found it felt a bit contrived playing on 3 boards.
Also (nitpick alert!) I was annoyed that the pieces looked so great on the outside, but looking down at them during play I could constantly see the big ugly molding seam inside the hollow part of each piece. If I would pay for a game with classy looking GIPF-project-like plastic pieces, I would want them to really look good everywhere I can see them...

item.name: Taluva
item.comment:
Once upon a time several years ago we were turned off by this game after an incompetent explanation by someone at Essen.
But I was curious since people praised it, so finally we played it again at Brzeski Festiwal 2010-01-31 and liked it enough to impulse purchase it that very day. Nice simple clear elegant rules - I don't know why the explainer had such trouble explaining it to us at Essen. :)
It's one of those games where the strategy seems quite nonobvious the first time you play. That gives us a fun sense of aha-discovery. And it seems to work fine with 2, 3, and 4 players (with different feel for different number of players).
Plus the tiles are really thick and chunky and sturdy and nice feeling.
Finally, the game is very quick to set up and put away, and doesn't take too long to play. A big plus for us!

item.name: TAMSK
item.comment: I don't like the hourglass realtime idea, which seems very out of place in the Gipf series of pure strategy games.

item.name: Tantrix
item.comment: Placing tiles to form as long a line as possible in your color, earning double points if you close it into a loop. The loop scoring sometimes creates a very interesting tough decision (Is my line big enough to close and probably win with its points? Is my opponent's line small enough that I should close it and double its score?) Very pleasing bakelite tiles, and it works well with 2, 3, or 4. The extensive rulebook with solitaire and puzzles is a nice bonus.
item.conditiontext: Bakelite tiles in a pouch = pleasing.

item.name: Tara: Ireland's Royal Board Game
item.originalname: Project Kells: Sacred Hill, High Kings of Tara & Poisoned Chalice
item.comment: A game of tile-laying and forming Celtic-looking loops and knots. Seemed simple and dull at first, then interesting weird aha-insights appeared! When I was forced to capture an opponent's tile and suddenly my nice big single-loop group turned into 3 interlocking loops, we decided there is more here than meets the eye!

item.name: Terra Nova
item.comment: Played a couple times at Essen 2006 and enjoyed it. And again in Essen 2007. No chance or hidden information, but it didn't feel that way, interestingly. Interesting endgame tactical subtleties can cause big swings. I like playing green in games, so I'm annoyed that they do the pseudo-clever cheap thing of giving fewer number of player pieces of some colors, so that green is only usable in a 4-player game, and not in 2-player which is how I usually play games. But a guy at Essen gave me the necessary extra green dudes, hurray.

item.name: Texas Glory: 1835-36
item.comment:
Relatively simple member of the block game family. Rules are mostly clear. Texans need to fall back as the Mexicans advance. Seems to take a couple hours. After a long hiatus from Columbia block games, this is the first one I've played in years. EastFront's still the best and classic. But I give Texas Glory bonus points for being about Texas history, since I'm from Texas. :)
I made the [[Texas Glory FAQ]].
item.wishlistcomment: Texas history!

item.name: Thebes
item.comment:
I like the core mechanism of moving and spending time on various tasks. This felt like it fit the theme well and leads to genuine strategizing and non-obvious decisions.
But the random draws for digging are ridiculously too variable. This also fits the theme, but in a different incompatible "light fluffy" way that clashes with the weightier strategizing of the map movement.

item.name: Thricewise
item.comment: More elegant (and pleasing to us) than the similar [gameid=37097]. Lay cards in a grid, score based on triples radiating out from the newly played card.

item.name: Tic Tac Doh!
item.comment: Very short pure strategy game playable with only 1 stash of Icehouse pyramids! I don't know if it will have a lot of staying power (given that it's a 3x3 grid, after all), but it's surprisingly nice and interesting as a short combinatorial game mini-brain-burn filler. Depending on how many trees (creating many possible 3-in-a-rows) vs nests (not as many) there are, it can play out interestingly different!

item.name: Tiku
item.comment: Odd surprise found on the shelf at Portal during [[Pionek]], a Knizia [[combinatorial game]] from 1993. Nice wooden pieces, interesting strategy, a bit cumbersome to play due to having to always pick up and put down disks.

item.name: Tile Chess
item.comment:
Neat chess variant that is like chess crossed with Hive.
The thin cardstock tiles of Tile Chess are disappointing compared to the clacky bakelite tiles of Hive, though.

item.name: Time's Up!
item.comment: So far, I've only played Anna's homebrew Esperanto version. :)

item.name: Timeline
item.comment: Clever history trivia game based on sorting cards chronologically. Not sure it would have high replay value as you start to know the cards.

item.name: Timeline: Diversity
item.comment: Clever history trivia game based on sorting cards chronologically. Not sure it would have high replay value as you start to know the cards.

item.name: Torpedo
item.comment:
Very fast to explain and play. Simpler scoring than Light Speed, plus the fact that it can be played simply with a pyramid stash for each player instead of needing a dedicated set of cards, makes me think I'll prefer this to Light Speed.
Because of the continuous space instead of a grid, occasional inevitable problematic ambiguities about whether a ship hit another arise.

item.name: Tortuga
item.comment: A checkers variant with attractive "native art" style turtles. A jumped piece is flipped onto its back and temporarily neutralized, then the next time someone jumps it, it joins their side. A practical problem is that the turtle backs are round, so they rock inconveniently when on their back, and the turtles are a bit too large for the hexes, so crowded areas of the board become cumbersome. Possibly a good checkers variant, but the practical issues turned us off.

item.name: Toscana
item.comment:
Pretty Tuscany-inspired art on the tiles. Quick playing enjoyable strategic placement game with randomly drawn tiles, sort of a mix of Cathedral and Tantrix.
The thin cheap plastic white scoring disks for the sort of cumbersome scoring are a pain to pick up off the tiles, and not up to the same aesthetic standard as the tiles and board.
[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/2424114]My review.[/url]
