2010-10-18: We have started playing it with no luck: simply choose what piece you want to play each turn from your entire set. We prefer this way! This caused me to change my rating from 6 to 7.

item.name: Totem
item.comment: Fast, vaguely like [gameid=9441] (racing with secret goals). Multiplayer too chaotic for my taste; 2-player becomes more tactical.

item.name: Trans Europa
item.comment: Easy rules make it good fun for playing with casual gamers.

item.name: TransAmerica
item.comment: "The simplest possible railroad game" as my friend Matt says... railroad gaming boiled down to its essence. Perhaps a bit too boiled down, since everyone shares the same track and it sometimes feels like it's rather arbitrary who ends up getting all their cities connected first, but it's a nice occasional filler.

item.name: Trax
item.comment:
Played some online and decided to buy it 2007-06-30. 2-player pure strategy game of tile placement to close a loop or make a long line meeting certain conditions, with very simple rules and pieces, but non-obvious strategy. When I first encountered Trax, I thought its rules and components were so simple that it couldn't offer much diversity, but it seems to. I've seen plays of it develop in quite different interesting ways. It also makes a huge difference whether you play with unlimited tiles and grid or restricted to an 8x8 grid; both are interesting, in different ways.
[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/2088884]My review of "Trax Strategy for Beginners".[/url]
item.conditiontext: Bakelite tiles in a pouch = pleasing.

item.name: Treehouse
item.comment: Seems silly and random, but a cute fast filler/introduction to the pyramids (which we bought to play Homeworlds and other excellent Icehouse pyramid games).
item.wishlistcomment:
It could be cool to get another of the [b][i]GRAY[/i][/b] (out of print, harder to find) sets, in case any accident ever happens to the gray set I have...
I do [b][i]NOT[/i][/b] currently need more Xeno or Rainbow sets - I have more than enough, and they are not out of print.

item.name: Trias
item.comment:
Enjoyed playing with the designer at Essen 2007! Cool concept of the continents drifting apart, nice clean clever system with some aha-tactics. I'd played a couple times years ago in Austin and was eager to try again at Essen, and was not disappointed.
The 2-player version is OK but less interesting than multiplayer, which adds additional tactics as intermediate scoring happens when islands are formed.
item.conditiontext: Signed by Ralf Lehmkuhl.

item.name: Trio
item.comment: Similar to Set: simultaneous search for patterns. 12 visible cards with arrangements of 3 pawns, but you can move a pawn once to achieve a pattern.

item.name: Triplexity
item.comment: Only played the basic game and it seemed boring. The advanced may be better since it presumably uses the numbers on the pieces, which are unused in the basic game.

item.name: Trucizna
item.comment: Nice quick short filler, pleasant art, some interesting tactics and strategy. I can't believe I never played it till now. :)

item.name: Tumblin-Dice
item.comment: Silly filler dexterity game I've played a few times at cons.

item.name: Turkish Checkers
item.comment: Fun version of checkers which becomes really fast and extremely bloody once the flying kings come into play! The opening seems slow, especially with the ability of pieces to move side ways back and forth, but then when someone breaks through and promotes a piece, the pace really accelerates!

item.name: Twilight Struggle
item.comment:
Finally played this popular game, at Pionek 2009-06-13. Want to play more; can't decide on rating yet. Kinda fiddly, a lot of rules subsystems to absorb.
2010-05-14: Received in [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/53295/item/1245082#item1245082]geekgold auction[/url] from Skadar. Thanks!

item.name: Twixt
item.comment:
Modern classic, and one of the few connection games my SO a2na enjoys. :)
2011-02-16: [url=http://boardgamegeek.com/geeklist/62317/item/1511583#item1511583]Received in Games for Geekgold - thanks very much, bulldog93![/url]

item.name: TZAAR
item.comment:
Played a lot in Essen 2007, and bought it. My first reaction is that it's my new favorite of the Gipf project, and many plays later, that's still true.
I like pure strategy games with a random setup, which Tzaar has. (There are 2 variants included for people who hate random setup.)
It seems to have a higher variety of qualitatively different possible higher level strategies than the other Gipf games. I have played in games ending by each of the various possible victory conditions (opponent runs out of any of the 3 kinds of pieces, or can't move).
Some people dis the Essen prototype for looking bland, but I actually like the board a lot.
item.conditiontext: Signed Essen copy 736/1000.

item.name: Ubongo
item.comment: The core of the game is real-time competition at fitting irregular pieces onto an irregularly shaped rectangular grid. When you get into the zone and are doing well, it's fun and satisfying and an adrenalin rush. But there are silly intricate scoring rules that break that energy flow. Better to ignore their scoring system and just give a point to the person who fit their pieces first (we do that by letting them keep their tile while everyone else tosses their tile aside), and rush through all the tiles in rapid fun.

item.name: Ubongo 3D
item.comment: For some reason I won this handily every time at BGG.CON 2009. :) We liked that the 3-D pieces fit together much better than the cardboard 2-D versions. Pleasing tactile experience, and a worthy addition to the Ubongo series.

item.name: Ubongo Extreme
item.comment: Harder than the original. Unfortunately we thought the tiles were physically too small and annoying to manipulate. Too bad they weren't bigger. The box is too huge for the components, so there would have been room for bigger tiles. [gameid=34969] is still our favorite.

item.name: Ubongo: Duel
item.comment:
Good small portable box. We like it more than original Ubongo. This one's all about solving the puzzles in frantic real-time, with no lame tacked-on weird scoring stuff. Each player solves the exact same puzzle (same map, same pieces) as the other.
And the puzzles are harder (in a good way)!
On the downside, some tiles don't fit together easily (tab in slot too snug), and the black plastic insert has 2 spaces to hold the 2 bags of pieces but these spaces are a little too small - poorly designed. We're thinking of just ditching the black plastic insert.

item.name: Ultimate Mastermind
item.comment: Not very interactive at all, and so arguably not a good "game" in the normal sense of the word, but it's a clever, enjoyable, satisfying logic puzzle game that I loved in my childhood and finally played again 2007-12-23.
item.conditiontext: We have some old Polish edition of it we found in our apartment.

item.name: Unikato
item.comment: Not particularly exciting abstract Scrabble/Qwirkle sort of game.

item.name: Union Pacific
item.comment: A classic we used to play a lot in Austin. A bit random and fiddly for my taste now, but still fun. It was nice to play it again finally in Poland after many years!

item.name: UNITY
item.comment:
Enjoyable game of trying to combine your remaining pieces into a single group, analogous to [gameid=3406], but different in detail: hex grid, move in a line to any empty space, and 2 types of pieces which can explode and destroy adjacent pieces or pieces in one direction.
So far, I think self-destructing is a stronger strategy than Nestor wants it to be. But it's still fun.

item.name: Uptown
item.comment:
A surprise hit for me. I'd never heard of it till [[Pionek]] September 2008, where I got roped into a 5-player game and quite enjoyed it. Sudoku-like map, neat idea for a goal (have as few connected groups as possible), attractive bits.
2009-05-26: played 2-player for the first time, with Maks, and enjoyed it. It uses the common annoying method of having each player take 2 colors, but each turn you can freely choose which of your colors you will play, so that was neat. (Unlike, e.g., 2-player Blokus where I always get confused which of my 2 colors I'm supposed to be playing...)
2009-11: finally purchased. :)

item.name: Vasco da Gama
item.comment: Choosing the numbers for when your worker will activate is a neat twist on worker placement.

item.name: Veletas
item.comment:
Amazons turned inside out... :)
We like playing it with red Looney pyramids + go stones.

item.name: La Venise du Nord
item.comment: Based on one 4-player game. Enjoyable, clever way of using the 2 dice, seemed a little too long and fiddly for the amount of randomness.

item.name: Versus
item.comment: Played at Essen 2008. Nice wooden bits, some clever rule ideas, seems like potentially interesting tactics, simply didn't have time to explore it more than one play to decide if it seems special or not.

item.name: Victory: World War II
item.comment:
Clever & reasonably simple system of generic WW2 unit types.
There are various ways to avoid its reputed deadlocks, e.g. start with few units on a large map, use the optional 2-point cost to build a new unit, use pre-designed scenarios findable in the web, etc.
I created [[Victory FAQ]].

item.name: Vimbre
item.comment: Interesting connection game. Superficially reminds me a bit of Slither: both are square-grid connection games with a rule that your pieces can't be diagonally adjacent unless a 3rd piece orthogonally connects them. But Vimbre has a capture rule instead of a movement rule and thus plays quite differently. Need to play more to say more...

item.name: Vineta
item.comment: Played and enjoyed a couple times at Essen 2008. Some clever fun mechanisms and pretty components. But we didn't buy it due to the unnecessarily large board with useless large margin, all packaged in a wastefully large box. (Also, the red and orange were too similar, so I spent one game saving red houses the whole time, only to discover I'd given 6 points to a red opponent, while I was orange.)

item.name: Viva il Re!
item.comment: Clever amusing elegant little game of psychology/bluffing, with simultaneous voting on whether a character should be king or not. Definitely has random luck, but also has skill, and it's a great filler since it plays quickly and is easy to learn.

item.name: Volcano
item.comment: Tough clever tactical puzzle game. Each turn you want to figure out how to get the best set of pieces, and hopefully deprive the opponents of a good move. The jumping mechanism reminds me a little bit of Army of Frogs somehow! But the eruption mechanism is interesting and different. I suck at it, but I like it. Works fine 2-player or with more.

item.name: Volo
item.comment: Odd game, a little bit reminiscent of Ayu. I have a hard time wrapping my mind around it. Need to play more. Playable on a YINSH board!

item.name: Wadi
item.comment: A pure strategy game that I wanted to like more than I did. The rules were a little less clear than they should be for such a simple elegant game, the components were a bit clunky and odd, and setting up the fixed-design map from individual tiles at the start was mildly annoying. Enjoyed enough to play a few times in a row just to see how it goes, but it just doesn't grab me strongly.

item.name: Waggle Dance
item.comment:
Sort of reminded me of Roma (roll dice and allocate them to various actions).
OK game with some strategic and tactical decisions (e.g. when to stop increasing your number of worker bees=dice and start building honey), but didn't excite either of us very much, alas. (We played 2 player short game twice and long game once.)
The queen bee cards felt like a bit too much random chaos in what is otherwise a fairly simple clean open-information design; before one knows all the cards, needing to look up card effects (and you can't just ask your opponent since card draws are secret) felt a bit bogging down (same as in Roma, coincidentally!), compared to the rest of the game which usually flowed smoothly and quickly with no real need to look up rules (although the organization of the rulesheet was odd, and we did have to resolve some questions, e.g. all examples show 1 or 2 bees of same type on a tile: is it legal to but different type bees? Is it legal to put more than 2? Seemingly yes, by rules as written, but we weren't 100% sure that was the intent. Rules about setting up the queen bee deck were unclear, especially with one card type having only 2 instead of 3 cards due to manufacturing error. Etc.)
Also it suffers from an annoying graphic design / ergonomic problem:
We're not colorblind, but 3 of the 6 nectar cube colors are WAY too similar (red, orange, pink). I see others commented on this problem in the forum, so it's not just us.

item.name: Warhammer: Invasion
item.comment:
Had it taught to me at a con; seems like a sufficiently simple pleasing core system. I'm not so into these kind of CCG-type "every card has wacky special effects" card games any more, but I had nostalgic fun with it. :)
I think for "this kind of game" I prefer Gosu, which is a little more elegant.

item.name: WarpWar
item.comment:
I played it back when it came out in 1977 or so, and then bought it again for nostalgia in 2009. Finally got it to the table 2010-10-25. It's got a lot of bookkeeping compared to popular modern games. And info is secret so you can't assist and check each other. This proved to be more bookkeeping than my 20-something opponent liked. Generation gap. :)
The rules are actually pretty nice and elegant and minimalist. (And explicitly lend themselves to adding new ideas and house rules, if one is so inclined.) There is no randomness except that of simultaneous decisions in combat. There is hidden information. Each ship is individually designed, but without too much bookkeeping.
Also, then and now, I am not sure whether I like the random chaos of simultaneous decisions in the combat system. But if several ships are involved, it starts to become possible to make more educated guesses and rational analysis of the battle - which was pleasing.
And the rules are unclear about the important issue of how much information you reveal to the opponent (e.g. if you fire a beam and miss, do they know what your beam strength was? Do you tell how much damage your shields ignore? Etc.)
I'd enjoy playing it more. It's dated and kind of minimalist in some ways, and if I'm in the mood for a minimalist space war game, I'd more often prefer [gameid=14634]. (And I'm curious to try the purely deterministic more recent tactical space combat game [gameid=28949].)
But I still have WarpWar nostalgia (which probably makes my rating a point higher than it might be if this were a new game, to be honest). It's a classic MicroGame certainly worth exploring for anyone who likes "design spaceships and attack each other" type games.
item.wishlistcomment: Nostalgia.

item.name: Was sticht?
item.comment:
A trick-taking game I enjoy! The first part (picking cards) is sort of like Zendo (as Maks mentioned), and then you get to pick which of your goal tiles you'll go for. It's fun and clever.
2010-06-12: Received in Polski Math Trade 5 from monga! :)

item.name: Wasabi!
item.comment:
Colorful cute game of laying tiles to create sets in a row; OK game, but clearly depending on its trendy theme of sushi and gimmicky toy value (e.g. little plastic sauce cups and green "wasabi" cubes).
2010-12-20: a2na receives Wasabi from her Secret Santa!

item.name: Wąż
item.comment: I played this at [[Pionek]] (September 2008) and was impressed by the interesting and seemingly nonobvious strategy that arose from such simple elegant rules. I need to play more to see how it holds up, but my first experience was quite favorable!

item.name: Web of Power
item.comment: I played this a bunch in Austin, then enjoyed again when revisiting. Wish I knew people in Poland who played it. A great elegant card-play and area-control game. If it worked 2-player, I'd own it.

item.name: What's That on My Head?
item.comment: A logical deduction game to figure out the 3 numbers on your head; you can only see the other players' numbers. The headbands are a little awkward/uncomfortable, but it's a fun clever game when you're in the mood for a deduction game. So far I just keep track of what I directly know, but I can imagine playing it at a more serious level and using meta-information about the other players not yet guessing their numbers, and what I can infer from that, given that they are rational...

item.name: Wikingowie
item.comment:
2008-12-17: First game, 2-player. Soldiers and Gold are important! Second game: Fish are also important. :)
2008-11-30: Won as prize at [[Pionek]] for being 1st place in logical games tournament.
2010: got reinterested in it, and the advanced rules add value.
Setup and teardown is a bit too fiddly, but overall a good game.

item.name: Wilki i owce
item.comment: Too much luck, and hand size can get cumbersome, but also has tile-laying tactics, and I like this kind of tile-laying map-building game, and it has cute art.
item.conditiontext: Received Polish "Wilki i Owce" for Christmas 2007; thanks Santa!

item.name: Wind & Wetter
item.comment: A lot of chaos, no real point to planning, a lot of interacting types of weather to learn, and it didn't grab me. I like the idea of different kinds of weather and terrain interacting, but this game, while not bad, just left me cold.

item.name: Witch Stones
item.comment:
Good combinatorial / abstract strategy game of removing pieces from a grid! Very simple elegant rules.
Like Alien City and Synapse-Ice it starts off rather opaque, as you both take 1 point each turn, but then at some point you are able to read ahead and realize "aha, these are the ways it can proceed" with potentially large amounts of points being taken back and forth.
The fact that your own color pieces are worth 0 to you and 2 to your opponent works well for sometimes creating neat asymmetrical situations and forced moves.
The random setup gives variety, like in TZAAR or Hey! That's My Fish!

item.name: Witch's Brew
item.comment: A clever fun but rather chaotic game (possibly too chaotic for its length). The central mechanism is: pick 5 of your 12 role cards to use in a round. Then in sequential order we reveal our cards of a given role if we have them, saying if we want to be that role (risking that a later person with the card will steal the role from us) or say "so be it" and use the secondary power of the card. Nifty. Attractive bits.

item.name: Wits & Wagers
item.comment: We liked the European version Gambit 7 better since its questions often seemed more interesting and less US-centric or TV/sport/stupid-pop-culture-oriented.

item.name: Wrong Chemistry
item.comment: Pattern matching of hexagonal "molecule" arrangements. Spend actions rearranging the pieces to match cards from your hand of random cards to earn points. Seems like a clever idea, but repetitive and not so exciting gameplay.

item.name: Wysokie Napięcie
item.comment:
I like the mostly non-random nature of it. The first few times it takes a long time, but experienced players go quickly, and 2-player (we play that way at home, though it's not as good 2-player, and most people seem to not like it at all 2-player) is often under an hour.
But gameplay is longer than I prefer with a large group, or with newbies. And newbies can be lose terribly from a single early mistake, then suffer for a long time. Game length and its not being as good for 2-player is the main reason I don't rate it even higher. It's a very cool interesting game.
I created the [[Power Grid FAQ]]. Please read before playing or posting rules questions!
item.conditiontext: 2008-03-10: I won the Polish edition "Wysokie napięcie" at [[Pionek]] 6 (thanks to winning the logical games tournament)!

item.name: Wysokie Napięcie - Europa Centralna / Beneluks
item.comment:
I am happy that my city [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wroc%C5%82aw]Wrocław[/url] is on the Poland map!
The special rules add some specific flavor, and in any case it's fun to play on different maps from the standard set.

item.name: Wysokie Napięcie - Nowe karty elektrowni
item.originalname: Power Grid: The New Power Plant Cards
item.comment: A fine variation, playable with base set or expansion maps. There are some much higher-powered plants in it! Diverse variants, e.g. simply use this deck instead of the base set, or mix them together in various ways.
item.conditiontext: I have the Polish edition "Wysokie Napięcie: Nowe Karty Elektrowni".

item.name: Władca pierścieni - Konfrontacja
item.originalname: Lord of the Rings: The Confrontation
item.comment: Playing the Polish version is nice Polish practice for me! :) We bought our own used copy in 2008-12.

item.name: Xe Queo!
item.comment: Nice elegant idea, but I felt lost in the bluffing element, like it was totally random; perhaps I'm just not good at this sort of game? Got my butt kicked twice. Short and simple, so I'd try it again, but right now I feel a bit frustrated by the game.

item.name: Xodd
item.comment:
This and the hex-board version Yodd are both cool clever games.
A practical problem occurs if there are many groups in play: sometimes we don't notice that the number of groups has accidentally/illegally become even. For that reason I recommend saying "3 4" or whatever after each turn, to consciously confirm the current number of groups each side has.

item.name: Yavalanchor
item.comment:
Good quick tactical abstract filler. Very simple rules are easy to teach/learn. Nothing deep or epic, just a nice clever quick little game.
[url=http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/856584/fun-simple-fast-abstract-strategy-filler-game]My review.[/url]

item.name: Yavalath
item.comment:
Simple elegant abstract with nifty gimmick: 4 in a row wins, but exactly 3 in a row loses. Leads to amusing aha-effects as players learn strategy.
2-player games always seem to end decisively.
3-player is a fun less serious twist. So far they usually seem to end fairly soon (but not as fast as 2-player), but sometimes they enter an interesting endgame where you need to try to maximize your number of "safe spaces" where you can play but opponent's can. We had at least one game where one player lost (due to 3 in a row) and the others tied.
Great filler game for a con or club meeting - portable, very easy to teach, works with 2 or 3 players.

item.name: YINSH
item.comment:
I feel like I should like this one more than I do. I simply can't read ahead very well in it. Besides, Dvonn has the prettiest pieces of all the Gipf games.
Update (2007-04): I'm starting to like it more and have a better feel for it.
2008-12: Anna received it from her Secret Santa! Thanks! :)

item.name: Yodd
item.comment:
This and the square-board version Xodd are both cool clever games.
A practical problem occurs if there are many groups in play: sometimes we don't notice that the number of groups has accidentally/illegally become even. For that reason I recommend saying "3 4" or whatever after each turn, to consciously confirm the current number of groups each side has.

item.name: Yonin Shogi
item.comment:
Sort of wacky 4-player variant. Diplomacy/negotiation naturally becomes significant. OK as a light silly variant, it seems, but a bit long; maybe next time we'd play that the first person to mate anyone wins, instead of that the sole survivor wins. (That would also remove some ambiguities about how to handle the pieces/turn of the eliminated player.)
We found that the rules were a bit tricky and have various variants mentioned inline, so a bit of discussion beforehand seems wise to confirm everyone is on the same page.

item.name: Zaic
item.comment:
Surprisingly subtle non-obvious strategy in this placement game of trying to have the largest visible region in your color! A combination of several clever little rules makes it interesting.
Our first 2 games we played by the wrong rules (more obvious/natural rules - entirely my fault from having read the rules months earlier and trying to remember/reconstruct them) and even that was fun. But then with the [i]real[/i] rules we were [i]really[/i] impressed!
I've played various games of the type "take turns placing a piece of your color and try to make as big a group as you can of your color" and usually the groups get bigger and bigger and you can see roughly how things will progress and where the big scoring group will be. In Zaic, due to the way the cutting rules work, the ending is often not at all what you might expect, and sometimes the winning group is surprisingly small.
The pieces look and feel great. Wish they were a little thicker to make it easier to see levels of stacks at a glance.

item.name: Zanzibar
item.comment: Not sure why I didn't like it more. Maybe from feeling a bit screwed by my card draws. It has an interesting kind of clever movement mechanic with the ranked pieces. But the game never really clicked for me.

item.name: Zark City
item.comment: Icehouse pyramid game with luck of the draw, a sort of shorter abstracted Zarcana/Gnostica. Played it 2-player several times and developed more appreciation for it after each game, though the card luck certainly requires that you not view it as a serious deep strategy game. Curious to try it multiplayer.

item.name: Zbuduj swoje miasto
item.comment: Addictive quick little game. Virtually no interaction, but still fun. We have successfully taught it and played it with non-hardcore gamers.

item.name: Zendo
item.comment:
A very clever enjoyable induction game. Like a game version of doing science, or debugging a program. I play it with colored wooden cubes, and online here with emoticons.
The ability to play with a variety of pieces makes it easy to play in unexpected circumstances. It's also useful to play in a foreign language to practice speaking about logical stuff in the language.

item.name: Zero
item.comment: A pleasant filler card game. Try to collect cards so that your hand has as low a value as possible, ideally 0. Some nice clever mechanisms.

item.name: ZÈRTZ
item.comment: Despite having read [url=http://www.scat.demon.co.uk/zertz/strategy.htm]a good article by Stephen Tavener[/url] about tactics, specifically the use of setting up forced jumps for your opponent from which you benefit more, and getting these techniques demonstrated to me by stronger players, my brain refuses to grok it. Nonetheless I admire it and enjoy the game!

item.name: Zombiaki
item.comment:
A 2-player card game with zombies advancing toward the barricaded humans, who are doing their best to stop the advancing hordes. Lots of special effect cards showing typical actions from zombie movies.
Amusing, quick, nice art. Polish text on the cards, but good icons remind you of what each card does. It plays well and fast, and seems reasonably balanced.
Mechanically it's like a weird cross between Neuroshima Hex (draw up to 4 cards, discard one, play or hold the others) and Lord of the Rings: Confrontation (the fellowship of the zombies tries to get past the humans' barricade at Mordor...)
The rules are a bit frustratingly unclear in places, and the English translation leaves out info from the Polish original, but most questions are eventually solvable.
[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/2084908]My review.[/url]
Received as a Valentine's Day gift in 2008!

item.name: Zombiaki 2: Atak na Moskwę
item.comment:
Sequel to Zombiaki, a good thematic 2-player zombie card game. This new version is evolutionary, not revolutionary. The cards are larger and better quality.
We did the English translation.
I think I like the actual gameplay of the original Zombiaki more than the sequel. This one introduces some different zombies/abilities that just feel weirder to me somehow. But it does have the amusing "American Shit" card. :)

item.name: Zombies!!!
item.comment:
I'd read this was a lame game, and it is indeed the most disappointing game I've played in a long time. Vague parts in the rules, ambiguous confusing map tile art (another triumph of cool art over functionality), but worst of all it has very little excitement and doesn't really capture the feel of a zombie horror film. It's more like a tedious repetitive dice fest that drags on forever. Your randomly rolled movement points each turn are too few, so it takes forever to move around the map. It dragged on and on, and we eventually got too tired to continue and just went to sleep. The game box doesn't tell how long the game takes, and I wonder if it's because they don't know because no one ever finished a game.
A hundred plastic zombies are a fun idea, but it feels like that was the core idea of the game, and the rules were just slapped together to have an excuse to sell a hundred plastic zombies in a box.
It was also annoyingly inconvenient that the life and bullet counters are printed only one one side (red life, black bullets) with indistinguishably identical white backs. They get moved around and accidentally flipped over a lot, so they really should have been printed on both sides.
The 2-player card game Zombiaki is playable in less than half an hour and much better captures the feel of a zombie film.
===
Meanwhile the game has a bogus misleading high rating with roughly a thousand people "temporarily" rating it "10" due to [url=https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/940650]a campaign in March 2013 to raise its rating as high as possible[/url] (and people like me who had rated it low even received direct geekmails pressuring them to change their rating).
Despite this "10" campaign being "temporary" with people supposed to restore their honest ratings soon thereafter, most of those "10" ratings still remain, years later.

item.name: Zooloretto
item.comment: Might like it more with additional play, or not. Seemed OK but for some reason didn't grab me.

item.name: Zoom
item.comment: Tried in Essen 2011. Seemed OK but didn't thrill us. Move balls along lines and try to make a 2x2 formation in your color.

item.name: Łowcy Zwierząt
item.comment: The print-it-yourself hex pieces have murky dark photographs that are too hard to distinguish when printed in black and white. There's some ambiguity in the rules about scoring animals. But hey, it's the first Polish boardgame I've played. And the basic idea and movement system was pleasing.
